questions.text: As an anesthesia consultant, you're planning to insert a central venous line for a patient requiring inotropes and parenteral nutrition for a prolonged period. Which of the following veins will you choose so as to have reduced long-term complications?
questions.solution:
Among the given options subclavian is the best vein for long-term cannulation.

The usual complications of prolonged cannulations include line infection, sepsis, air or thrombus embolism, arrhythmias, hematoma, hemothorax, and thrombosis.

As compared to cannulation of other veins, subclavian vein cannulation has a reduced risk of complications due to prolonged cannulations. It is, however, associated with a maximum risk of pneumothorax.

Other options:

Option B- The internal jugular vein on the right side is better than the left side. Left-sided insertion has an increased risk of pleural effusion and chylothorax.

Option C- The external jugular vein is less preferred because it enters at an acute angle into chest veins, hence there are decreased chances of easy access.

Option D- Femoral veins are less preferred for long-term usage because they are associated with frequent line-related sepsis.

questions.text: The ENT resident uses the following system to classify the maxillary carcinoma. The 2 horizontal lines shown as "A" and "B" in the below image are known as _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows Lederman’s classification and the two horizontal lines shown as "A" and "B" in the above image are called as Sebileau lines, one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through the floors of antrum.

 Sebileau lines divides the area into:

  • Suprastructure: It contains ethmoid, sphenoid, and frontal sinuses and the olfactory area of the nose.
  • Mesostructure: It has a maxillary sinus and the respiratory part of the nose.
  • Infrastructure: It contains the alveolar process.

This classification further uses vertical lines, extending down the medial walls of orbit to separate ethmoidal sinuses and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses.

Other options:

  • Ohngren’s line is an imaginary line passing through medial canthus of eye and angle of mandible
  • Lefort's lines are used for the classification of maxillary fractures

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden painless loss of vision. Fundoscopy findings are shown below. Which of the following findings do you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Sudden painless monocular loss of vision with fundoscopy showing Hollehorst plaque is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen in these cases.

Hollenhorst plaques are cholesterol emboli that are seen in retinal arterioles. On fundus examination, it gives an appearance of a refractile yellow-white color substance in the retinal vessels. 

Note: Although elevated intraocular pressure has been implicated as a cause of central retinal artery obstruction, it is unlikely that intraocular pressure can be raised high enough to block arterial inflow to the eye 

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: You performed extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) in a 30-year-old male who was diagnosed with renal calculi.  Following the procedure, you discharged him without performing a check X-ray of KUB post-operatively. In the followup visit after one week, the X-ray KUB showed the following finding. Identify the correct order of the involvement of ureteric sites in this condition?

choices.text: Distal ureter >  Mid ureter > Proximal ureter
Distal ureter > Proximal ureter > Mid ureter
Proximal ureter > Mid ureter > Distal ureter
Proximal ureter > Distal ureter > Mid ureter

questions.solution:
The X-ray KUB shows collection of stone fragments in both right and left ureters (arrows). The condition is known as steinstrasse. Option B indicates the correct order of involvement of ureteric sites in steinstrasse.

Stone fragments collecting in the ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse (a german word, which means 'street of stones'). Steinstrasse usually develops 1 day to 3 months after stone fragmentation by extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL).

The most common site of the column of stone fragments obstruction is the distal ureter, followed by the proximal ureter and mid ureter.

Treatment: Usually, the stone fragments pass spontaneously, but in about 25% of patients. In some, retrograde stenting may be required to release the ureteral obstruction until the stone fragments become displaced and pass.

questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of the frequent dropping of handheld things and tripping while walking. On examination, the patient appeared as shown in the image below. Strength is 4/5 in the intrinsic muscles of the hand. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing the patient with frontal balding, and a typical hatchet-faced appearance are suggestive of type 1 myotonic dystrophy.

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused due to CTG trinucleotide repeat in DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It is mainly of two types: myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), and myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2).

Clinically, patients will have a typical hatchet-faced appearance due to wasting of the temporal and masseter muscles. Frontal baldness and a high-arched palate are also seen. 

It is associated with weakness in the distal muscles of the wrist, fingers, and foot. Involvement of the palatal, pharyngeal, and tongue muscles causes dysarthria and dysphagia. Involvement of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles leads to respiratory insufficiency. Proximal muscles remain unaffected.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. ECG shows conduction abnormalities in the form of first-degree heart block. Electromyography may show myotonia in DM1, however, it is patchy in DM2. Creatine kinase levels in the serum may be normal or mildly elevated.

The histopathological finding of muscle biopsy in both DM1, and DM2, shows internalized nuclei seen in individual muscle fibers, and the presence of several atrophic fibers with pyknotic nuclear clumps.

Treatment is mainly symptomatic. However, mexiletine is indicated for both DM1 and DM2 help in reducing myotonia.

Other options:

Options A and B: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies present with proximal muscle weakness. These are x-linked recessive dystrophies. Therefore, family history would reveal that mainly men in the family are affected.

Option D: In Pompe's disease or acid maltase deficiency is a glycogen storage disease. Affected children present with hypotonia, myocardiopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Respiratory muscle weakness leading to ventilatory insufficiency may be a prominent feature.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to you with the complaints of swelling in the groin region. He also gives a history of similar complaints at the same site in the past for which he got operated. While performing the following test, you were able to feel the impulse over the ring finger. What is the Nyhus classification of this groin hernia?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent femoral hernia, which is a Type IV C hernia according to the Nyhus classification system of groin hernia.

The test being performed in the above image is 3 finger test or Zieman’s test which is used to differentiate groin hernias.

Zieman’s test:

After reducing the hernia, The examiner places his index finger on the deep inguinal ring, middle finger on the superficial inguinal ring, and ring finger over the saphenous opening.

Now the patient is asked to cough or to hold the nose and blow.

Interpretation: When the impulse is felt on the,

  • Index finger: The given case is one of the indirect herniae.
  • Middle finger: The given case is one of the direct herniae.
  • Ring finger: The given case is one of the femoral herniae.

Note: This test can only be applied only after the hernia has been completely reduced.

Related Pearl: Nyhus classification of groin hernia

  • Type I - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring normal (e.g., pediatric hernia)
  • Type II - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated but posterior inguinal wall intact; inferior deep epigastric vessels not displaced
  • Type III - Posterior wall defect
    • A- Direct inguinal hernia
    • B - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the transversalis fascia of Hesselbach triangle (e.g., scrotal, sliding, or pantaloon hernia)
    • C - Femoral hernia
  • Type IV - Recurrent hernia
    • A - Direct
    • B - Indirect
    • C - Femoral
    • D - Combined

questions.text: An 18-year-old unmarried female patient presents with an abdominal mass, menstrual irregularities, abdominal pain, and fever. On palpation of the abdomen, it has a doughy feel. What could be the most likely causative agent in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of genital tuberculosis and the most likely causative agent, in this case, is Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Genital tuberculosis occurs secondary to primary foci. It initially affects the fallopian tubes bilaterally following which it spreads to other genital organs. The presenting features include a mass abdomen and associated menstrual irregularities. On palpation, the abdomen has a doughy feeling. Other features include dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and pelvic inflammatory disease (fever, nausea and vomiting, menstrual irregularities, vaginal discharge, cervical motion tenderness, adnexal tenderness, etc)

Hysterosalpingography reveals features suggestive of genital tuberculosis such as

  • Lead pipe appearance of the tubes
  • Beading and variation in the filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx

The pelvic inflammatory mass in an unmarried woman is mostly tubercular in origin. A pelvic inflammatory disease that doesn't respond to treatment and recurs is likely to be due to tuberculosis.

Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhea, and Mycoplasma hominis are sexually transmitted and can cause pelvic inflammatory disease.

questions.text: The maternal mortality rate is expressed as "number of maternal deaths in a given period per ____ during the same time period".
questions.solution:
The maternal mortality rate is expressed as the "number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 women in reproductive age during the same time period".

Note: The maternal mortality ratio is expressed as the "number of maternal deaths during a given period per 100,000 live births during the same time period".

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: The USG of the gall bladder of a forty-year-old obese female patient appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ultrasonography of the gallbladder shows acoustic shadow, indicating the presence of stone in the gallbladder (cholelithiasis).

Cholelithiasis is commonly seen in women. Over 70% of the gallstones are composed of cholesterol, while the pigment gallstones composed of calcium carbonate constitute most of the remaining 30%.

Radiological features:

X-ray: Only calcified stones are visible.

Ultrasonography:

  • The gallstones appear as echogenic foci, which cast acoustic shadow. Stone mobility may be demonstrated, if it is not impacted.
  • In contrast, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow.
  • In gallbladder full of stones, there is a dense acoustic shadowing with the presence of two parallel curved echogenic lines separated by a thin anechoic space. This characteristic appearance is referred to as ‘Double-arc shadow sign’, or wall-echo-shadow sign.

The image-below shows wall-echo-shadow sign due to the presence of a large gall stone.

Other options:

Option A: Porcelain gallbladder refers to calcification of the gallbladder wall. The image below shows calcification in the gall bladder wall(on CT) suggestive of a porcelain gall bladder.

 

Option B: On USG, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow. The image below shows a gallbladder polyp on USG:

Option C: In emphysematous cholecystitis, intraluminal gas appears as a bright curvilinear echogenic band with ‘dirty’ shadowing. CT scan shows gas within the wall of the gallbladder (shown below).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with compensated cirrhosis is being posted for a liver transplantation. As an anesthetist on duty, which of the following induction agents will you use?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane and isoflurane are commonly used for induction in patients with liver disease.

Hepatic arterial blood flow is reduced in cirrhosis. Sevoflurane and isoflurane are known to maintain hepatic blood flow and improve oxygen delivery to the liver.

Sevoflurane due to its nonpungency and rapid onset makes it an excellent choice for smooth and rapid inhalation inductions in pediatric and adult patients.

Compound A is the nephrotoxic end product formed by the interaction of sevoflurane with CO2-absorbent soda lime. Accumulation of this product occurs on long-duration anesthesia, high sevoflurane concentrations, and dry barium hydroxide absorbent.

Other options-

Option (A): Methoxyflurane is a hepatotoxic and highly nephrotoxic drug. Its use gradually declined after the 1970s. 

Option (B): Thiopentone, also known as thiopental, is a barbiturate that is excreted primarily via the liver. Hence, it would lead to toxicity is used in patients with liver disease.

Option (D): Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic agent that accumulates in the liver and undergoes rapid metabolism. It is also known to cause hepatotoxicity which presents as an elevation in liver enzymes. These two reasons make ketamine unsuitable for use in patients with liver disease.

questions.text: Which among the following enzymes does not contribute in the reversible phase of the pentose phosphate pathway?
questions.solution:
6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase is involved in the irreversible oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway. Transketolase, keto-isomerase, and phosphohexose isomerase are involved in the reversible non-oxidative phase.

The pentose phosphate pathway, also known as the HMP shunt pathway, is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It contributes by two major ways:

  • Formation of NADPH for the synthesis of fatty acids and steroids and maintenance of reduced glutathione for antioxidant activity
  • Formation of ribose for the synthesis of nucleic acid and nucleotides

The enzymes for this pathway are found in the cytosol. There are two phases:

  1. Irreversible oxidative phase: Glucose-6-phosphate is dehydrogenated and decarboxylated to form ribulose-5- phosphate.
  2. Reversible nonoxidative phase: Ribulose-5-phosphate is converted back to glucose-6-phosphate.

Clinical significance:

  • Protection against hemolysis: NADPH is utilized for the reduction of oxidized glutathione. Reduced glutathione removes H2O2, thereby preventing oxidative damage to RBCs and hemolysis. Thus, deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase results in hemolytic anemia.
  • Formation of glucoronate: Glucose-6-phosphate gives rise to glucoronate via the uronic acid pathway. Glucoronate is important as a precursor for proteoglycans and as a conjugate for substances like steroid hormones and drugs for their excretion in bile or urine. A deficiency in the uronic acid pathway results in essential pentosuria.
  • Fructose and galactose metabolism: Fructose bypasses the regulatory step in the HMP pathway and undergoes rapid glycolysis in the liver. This results in increased fatty acid synthesis and VLDL secretion. Galactose formed from glucose is an essential constituent of lactose, glycolipids, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins. Deficiencies of enzymes in these reactions lead to metabolic diseases like essential fructosuria, hereditary fructose intolerance, and galactosemia.
  • Formation of amino sugars: Amino sugars are formed from glucose and are important components of glycoproteins, glycosphingolipids, and glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was brought to you with the complaints of serous discharge from the cutaneous opening on the right side of the neck i.e. just below and behind the angle of the mandible. During ear examination, you noticed the presence of another cutaneous opening on the floor of the external auditory canal. Fistulogram showed the connectivity between the 2 openings. This fistula is due to a developmental defect of:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of collaural fistula, which results from developmental defect of  first branchial cleft.

Collaural fistula:

This fistula has two openings:

  • One situated in the neck just below and behind the angle of mandible and
  • The other one in the external canal or the middle ear.

The track of the fistula traverses through the parotid in close relation to the facial nerve.

Surgery is the main treatment modality for this disorder.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of not being able to conceive even after trying for 3 years. After investigations, you decide to prescribe her clomiphene citrate 50 mg/day for 5 days for ovulation induction. Which 5 days of the menstrual cycle would you advise her to take the treatment?
questions.solution:
Ovulation should be induced with Clomiphene citrate, with a dose of 50 mg/day for 5 days from day 2 to day 6 of the cycle.

If there is no satisfactory response, the dose can be increased to 100mg/day from day 2 to day 6. If this therapy fails even after 6-8 cycles, FSH and hCG therapy can be recommended.

questions.text: A young chemist notices a reaction system in which the rate of conversion of substrates to product is equal to the rate at which products are converted back to substrates. Which of the following properties regarding this reaction system is true?

choices.text: The equilibrium constant is a ratio of the reaction rates
The rate constants  of the forward and backward reactions are equal
The value of equilibrium constant increases with increase in catalyst or enzyme concentration

questions.solution:
Among the given options, Equilibrium is a dynamic state is the correct option.

In an equilibrium state, Although there is no net change in the concentration of substrates or products, individual substrate, and product molecules are continually being interconverted and hence it is said to be dynamic.

Some important properties of a system at equilibrium are:

  • The equilibrium constant (Keq) is a ratio of the reaction rate constants (not the reaction rates). 
  • At equilibrium, the reaction rates (not the rate constants) of the forward and back reactions are equal. 
  • The numerical value of the constant can be calculated by finding the concentrations of substrates and products.
  • If Keq is more than 1, the forward reaction is favoured. In such instances, the reaction is spontaneous and exothermic.
  • The concentration of the enzyme does not affect the Keq. The concentration of enzyme certainly increases the rate of reaction; but not the Keq or the ultimate state. Catalysts increase the rate of reaction but do not alter the equilibrium.

questions.text: During your ENT viva, the examiner shows the following image and asks you to name all the paranasal sinuses which open into the space present behind the structure marked as "?". You would answer all the following paranasal sinuses except:
questions.solution:
The structure marked as "?" in the above image is the middle turbinate and the space present behind it is known as the middle meatus. All the above paranasal sinus opens into the middle meatus except the Posterior ethmoidal sinus, which opens into the superior meatus.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group: It includes,

  • Maxillary sinus(Antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal.

All of the above sinuses open into the middle meatus and their ostia lie anterior to basal lamella of middle turbinate.

Posterior group: It includes,

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus 
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text:
As per the recent updates in the American Diabetes Association 2020 standard of care guidelines, which of the following statements are true?
1. Intranasal glucagon and glucagon solution for subcutaneous injection have been approved for the treatment of hypoglycemia.
2. SGLT2 inhibitors are preferred to GLP-1 receptor agonists for treating patients with diabetes, when atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) predominates.
3. Oral semaglutide has been approved for the treatment of type II diabetes mellitus.
questions.solution:
Options 1 and 3 are correct. GLP-1 receptor agonists are first preferred in patients with diabetes, when atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ACSVD) predominates.

Key Recent updates in ADA 2020 standard of care guidelines:

  • Intranasal glucagon and glucagon solution for subcutaneous injection for treatment of hypoglycemia have recently got FDA approval, and are now included in ADA recommendations.
  • Early combination therapy is suggested for some patients with type 2 Diabetes mellitus to extend time to treatment failure based on the findings from VERIFY trial.
  • Oral semaglutide has been recently approved by FDA, and is now included in the ADA recommendations for the treatment of type 2 Diabetes mellitus.
  • GLP-1 receptor agonists and SGLT2 inhibitors are recommended for the treatment of patients when atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, heart failure, or CKD preodminates.
  • For patients in whom ASCVD predominates, GLP-1 RA are initially preferred, while in patients in whom HF or CKD predominates, SGLT2i are initially preferred.

questions.text: A Biochemist while studying the granules present in the mononuclear cells shown in the below image noticed the presence of glycosaminoglycans. Which of the following repeating sugars are present in the identified glycosaminoglycan?
questions.solution:
Heparin is the glycosaminoglycan present in the granules of the given mononuclear cell / mast cell. The repeating units found in this are Glucosamine + Iduronic acid.

Heparin is an important anticoagulant. It is present in the liver, lungs, spleen, and monocytes. It is released into the blood from capillary walls by the action of lipoprotein lipase.

questions.text: A family consisting of a husband and a pregnant wife, along with 2 daughters aged 7 and 9 years, they stay in a house with 2 rooms. According to the accepted standards with respect to overcrowding, which of the following is false?

choices.text: The floor space of the house should be >110 sq ft
The house of this family is overcrowded
The family requires at least two rooms

questions.solution:
This family does not live in overcrowding presently. 

This family counted as 3 units (husband+wife+daughter+daughter= 1+1+0.5+0.5=3), who are living in 2 rooms, which is in accordance with the accepted standards.

Overcrowding is considered to exist if 2 persons over 9 years of age, not husband and wife, of opposite sexes are obliged to sleep in the same room.

The accepted standards of persons per room against overcrowding are as follows.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female was diagnosed with a large pituitary mass on MRI scanning. The presence of high circulating levels of which of the following hormones avoids the need for surgical resection of the pituitary gland?
questions.solution:
Circulating prolactin levels should always be assessed in cases of pituitary adenomas, as the presence of high prolactin levels indicates prolactinoma, which can be treated with dopamine agonists, thereby avoiding unnecessary surgical resection.

Dopamine agonists are first-line therapy in most patients with prolactinoma. Commonly used dopamine agonists include bromocriptine, cabergoline, and quinagolide.

Dopamine agonists reduce serum prolactin concentration and cause a significant reduction in the tumor size after several months of therapy. If the patient has any visual defects due to tumor suppression effects, they tend to improve within a few days after the administration of dopamine agonists.

Prolonged use of ergot-derived dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline may cause fibrotic reactions in the heart due to interaction with 5-HT2B receptors. These effects are mostly seen in patients with Parkinson's disease. Hence, if prolonged treatment is required, then non-ergot agents such as quinagolide are indicated.

In patients who achieve normoprolactinemia and significant reduction of the tumor mass, the dopamine agonist can be withdrawn after two years of therapy.

Note that surgical decompression is usually necessary only when a macroprolactinoma does not respond adequately to dopamine agonist therapy.

questions.text: A young enthusiastic college student started going to the gym. On the first day, he started exercising aggressively without a regular warmup. By the end of the day, he had pain in the back of the thigh. Consultation revealed his hamstring muscles were affected. What is the root value of the nerves supplying the affected muscles?
questions.solution:
The nerve supply of the Hamstring muscles is a sciatic nerve (L4 to S3).

Hamstring muscles are present in the posterior compartment of the thigh and include semimembranosus, semitendinosus, and biceps femoris.

They cause the flexion of the knee joint and extension of the hip joint. In addition to this, semimembranosus and semitendinosus cause medial rotation of hip and knee joint, and biceps femoris causes lateral rotation of hip and knee joint.

  • Semitendinosus, semimembranosus and the long head of biceps femoris are innervated by tibial division of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, and S2)
  • The short head of biceps femoris is innervated by the common peroneal division of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: While performing cardiac catheterization, a cardiac biopsy was obtained in a young male patient aged 27 years, who recently developed heart failure. The image below shows a congo-red stained specimen, observed directly (A) and under polarized light (B). Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows a congo-red stained cardiac biopsy specimen with (A) focal positive staining of amorphous extracellular material, and (B) apple-green birefringence under polarized light, diagnostic of amyloidosis.

The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry. 

Amyloidosis is a disease characterized by the extracellular deposition of insoluble protein fibrils. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. Proteins that are misfolded are normally eliminated. In amyloidosis, there is an accumulation of misfolded proteins in the extracellular space.

Amyloid diseases are classified depending on whether they are systemic or localized, acquired or inherited, and their clinical patterns. 

  • AL is the most common form of amyloidosis and is termed primary systemic amyloidosis. It occurs due to a plasma cell or B cell disorder. 
  • ATTY occurs due to mutations in transthyretin and is termed familial amyloidosis. 
  • AA involves amyloid A, an acute phase reactant and is termed secondary amyloidosis. It is usually associated with chronic inflammatory conditions.
  • AB2M amyloidosis occurs due to the accumulation of misfolded B2 microglobulin in patients with chronic renal disease. 

Many of the systemic features of the types of amyloidosis are overlapping. Thus, clinical diagnosis is not sufficient for treatment. In addition, the treatment of amyloidosis is type-specific. Thus, immunohistochemistry should be done to confirm the type of amyloidosis. Once it has been confirmed, then appropriate, type-specific treatment can be begun. 

Other options: 

Option A: Orthotropic liver transplantation is used to treat ATTR amyloidosis. Immunohistochemical staining must be done to confirm the diagnosis. 

Option B: Treatment of the underlying inflammatory disease or infectious is done in AA amyloidosis. 

Option D: Oral melphalan and prednisone is given in AL amyloidosis to reduce the plasma cell burden.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman in her 30th week of gestation was found to have an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4 cm. Which among the following options could be a cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid index (AFI) less than 5 cm suggests oligohydramnios, among the given options amnion nodosum is a cause of oligohydramnios, the other options are causes of polyhydramnios.

Oligohydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume less than 200 ml
  • AFI less than 5 cm
  • The maximum vertical pocket of liquor is less than 2 cm

Causes of oligohydramnios are amnion nodosum (failure of secretion by the cells of the amnion covering the placenta), postmaturity, renal agenesis, obstructive uropathy, maternal usage of prostaglandin inhibitors, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, etc.

Polyhydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume of more than 2L
  • AFI more than 25 cm
  • A deepest vertical pocket is more than 8 cm 

Causes of polyhydramnios are anencephaly, cleft palate, facial clefts, hydrops fetalis, maternal diabetes, esophageal or duodenal atresia, open spina bifida, aneuploidy, chorioangioma of the placenta, infections like cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is the electrocardiograph changes seen in early stages of acute pericarditis?

choices.text: ST-segment depression with flat T waves
ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression

questions.solution:
ECG showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression is seen in early stages of acute pericarditis.

The ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolves through four stages:

  • Stage 1- Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression. 
  • Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal
  • Stage 3 - Diffuse T wave inversion
  • Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months

Echocardiography findings are usually normal or may show evidence of a pericardial effusion. If abnormal, regular echocardiographic monitoring is recommended.

The ECG below shows acute pericarditis causing diffuse ST-segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF, and V2 to V6, with reciprocal ST depressions in lead aVR.

Other options:

Option A: ST-segment depression with flat T waves are seen in hypokalemia. Prolongation of QT interval is also seen.

ECG given below shows ST depression and broad flat T waves seen in hypokalemia.

Option B: Electrical alternans of P, QRS, and T waves are seen in cardiac tamponade.

ECG given below shows electrical alterans seen in cardiac tamponade.

Option D: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.

ECG given below shows tall peaked T waves seen in hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A dietician advising a patient regarding diet plans considers the specific dynamic action (SDA) values for proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates. Identify the correct sequence of SDA values in these substrates.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, option C represents the correct sequence of specific dynamic values (SDA) of proteins > lipids > carbohydrates.

Specific dynamic allowance (previously called the thermic effect of food): This refers to the increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food (diet-induced thermogenesis).

The values of SDA are

  • 30% for proteins: This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.
  • 15% for lipids, and 
  • 5% for carbohydrates.

Importance: It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein-rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling.

questions.text: Which of the following events can lead to an increase in potassium secretion by the cortical collecting tubule?

choices.text: A diuretic that decreases sodium reabsorption from loop of Henle
A diuretic that inhibits the action of aldosterone

questions.solution:
Among the given options a diuretic that causes decreased sodium reabsorption from the loop of Henle causes increased secretion of potassium.

The factors that stimulate the secretion of the potassium from cortical collecting duct include:

  • Aldosterone
  • Increased plasma potassium concentration
  • Increased flow rate in cortical collecting tubules
  • Alkalosis

A diuretic such as furosemide, which inhibits the sodium reabsorption from the loop of Henle, causes increased flow rate, that eventually causes increased secretion of the potassium by the cortical collecting tubule.

Other options:

  • Option a: Decreased plasma potassium concentration causes reduced aldosterone secretion, and decreased extracellular potassium gradient, which causes decrease in cortical secretion of potassium.
  • Option b: Decreased dietary intake of sodium does not affect potassium secretion, due to the counterbalancing effects of increased aldosterone secretion and decreased tubular flow rate.
  • Option d: A diuretic such as spironolactone, that inhibits the secretion of aldosterone causes decreased potassium excretion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient had to undergo a cesarean section in a hospital due to a complicated delivery. She was discharged on her 5th-day postpartum. How many visits by an ASHA worker is recommended in this case?
questions.solution:
As this case is an institutional delivery through LSCS, the patient would be discharged after 5-6 days from the hospital, therefore 5 visits by the ASHA worker are recommended here.

The total incentive received by ASHA for HBNC (Home-based newborn care) is Rs. 250 if she completes all her visits.

ASHA visits all newborns on proper schedule up to their 42 days of life. The number of home visits will be,

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42).
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1).
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS (no visits on day 1 and day 3).

In case a newborn is discharged from SNCU, then ASHA will receive a full incentive after completing the remaining visits. ASHA will do additional follow-up visits every month for low-birth-weight newborns up to two years, and SNCU discharged babies up to one year. For each follow-up visit, ASHA will receive an additional Rs. 50.

If the woman delivers at her maternal house and returns to her husband’s house or vice versa, the visits might have been done by two ASHAs at the two different places. In such cases, if each ASHA completes at least 3 visits, they will receive Rs 125 each. If ASHA completes less than 3 visits, they will not receive any incentive.

In the case of twins/triplets, then ASHA will receive twice (Rs. 500) or thrice (Rs. 750), the regular payment.

The payments are made to ASHA on the 45th day, subject to the following conditions:

  • The birth weight is recorded in the Maternal and Child Protection (MCP) Card.
  • Ensuring that the newborn is immunized with BCG, first doses of OPV and DPT/Pentavalent, and entered into the MCP card.
  • Enabling birth registration.
  • Both mother and newborn are safe until the 42nd day.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A 9 year old child is referred to immunologist with multiple staphylococcal abscesses and eczema. He also suffers fractures after trivial trauma. Examination shows increased IgE levels and eosinophils. What could be a possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of immunodeficiency fit the description of Hyper IgE syndrome or Job syndrome.

Job syndrome arises due to deficiency of Th17 cells due to STAT3 mutation. It is a primary immunodeficiency disorder inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. Features can be summarised as:

F: Coarse Facies

A: Cold staphylococcal Abscesses

T: Retained primary Teeth

E: Increased IgE

D: Dermatologic problems (eczema)

  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

questions.text: A 40-year-old female is undergoing a hysteroscopic myomectomy. The Gynaecologist is using monopolar electrocautery for this procedure and bleeding is expected. Which of the following distension media is most suitable for this case?
questions.solution:
Dextran solution is suitable as a distension media of choice for hysteroscopy when electrocautery is used.

In procedures like myomectomy, septum cutting, or endometrial ablation electrocautery is used. In these cases, the distension medium that is used should be nonionic (not normal saline(Option D)) to prevent the spread of electrical energy. The medium should not get mixed with blood as this would interfere with the visualization of the procedure. Hyskon (concentrated dextran solution) and glycine are commonly used. Hyskon is not miscible with blood and has good optical qualities.

Commonly used media is CO2, which is delivered through a hysteroflator to a maximum rate of 70mL/min and pressure less than 100 mmHg. Liquid media used are Normal saline, 5% dextrose, and Ringer lactate solutions. Intrauterine pressure of 40-50 mmHg is needed for adequate distension.

Hysteroscopy is an operative procedure that provides the endoscopic view of the endometrial cavity and tubal ostia via the cervix. It can be diagnostic or therapeutic. 

Therapeutic indications of hysteroscopy Diagnostic indications of hysteroscopy
  • Uterine septum
  • Asherman syndrome
  • Retained IUCD
  • Polypectomy
  • Submucous fibroid
  • Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Tubal sterilization using sclerosing agents
  • To study the endocervical mucosal lining
  • Congenital malformations of the uterus
  • Endometrial tuberculosis
  • Asherman syndrome
  • Misplaced IUCD
  • Endometrial lesions
  • Endometrial polyp
  • Cornual tubal blockage

Complications of hysteroscopy include :

  • Early complications:
    1. Anesthesia complications- air embolism can occur
    2. Uterine perforation
    3. Thermal injury with cautery and laser
    4. Sepsis
    5. Allergic reaction to dextran and glycine
    6. Fluid overload occurs and can lead to pulmonary edema if the fluid deficit is more than 1000 mL. It can be managed by diuretics.
    7. Cerebral edema
    8. Cardiac failure
  • Late complications:
    1. Hematometra following cervical stenosis
    2. Pelvic inflammatory disease
    3. Uterine rupture during pregnancy
    4. Dysmenorrhea
    5. Amenorrhea

Other options:

Option B: CO2 cannot be used as it obscures the vision in the presence of blood and cannot be employed in the presence of bleeding.

Option A: There is a risk of combustion with N2O if electrocautery is used.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman nearing her due date was admitted on presenting with labor pain. The resident doctor examined the patient and told the intern that the head is at +3 station. Where is the exact position of the head?
questions.solution:
The exact position of the head when it is at +3 station is 3 cm below the ischial spine.

The station of the head is described in relation to ischial spines as they are the most prominent bony projections felt on internal examination.

The level of ischial spines is halfway between the pelvic inlet and outlet. This level is known as station zero (0). The levels above and below the spines are designated based on centimeters, 1 cm away from station 0 is either +1 or -1 station. If the presenting part is above the spines, it is stated with a minus sign (such as -1 cm, -2 cm) and if it is below the spines, it is stated with a plus sign (such as +1 cm, +2 cm).

questions.text: What is the oxygen delivery rate of the device shown below?
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is a non-rebreather mask. It can give up to 10-15 liters of oxygen per minute.

The non-rebreather mask is a low-flow device that can be used to deliver oxygen at higher concentrations (FiO2 80-95%). It is used in patients who are severely hypoxic but are ventilating well. It uses a reservoir bag to let the oxygen get concentrated while a one-way valve doesn't allow it to breathe in expired air.

Other examples of low-flow devices are:

  • Nasal cannula
  • Face mask
  • Face tent
  • Non-rebreather mask.

High-flow devices include:

  • Venturi mask
  • High flow nasal cannula
  • Mechanical ventilation
Oxygen delivery devices Flow rate (liter/min) 
Nasal cannula  1-6 
Simple face mask  6-10
Non-rebreathing mask 10-15
Venturi mask  2-15

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the muscle marked "A" in the image given below?

choices.text: Originates from anterior superior iliac spine
The aponeurosis forms part of pes anserinus
Abducts and laterally rotates the thigh

questions.solution:
The structure marked "A" is sartorius. It is innervated by the Femoral nerve (L2, L3).

The sartorius muscle is known as the tailor muscle and is also the longest muscle in the body. The word "sartorius" is derived from the Latin word sartor, which translates to tailor, due to the way the individual will position one's leg while working.

Origin: Anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it.

Insertion: Into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity (joins aponeurosis of gracilis and semitendinosus to form pes anserinus).

Action: Flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh; and flexion of the leg.

Innervation: By femoral nerve (L2, L3, and L4)

questions.text: An infant was born at 32 weeks of gestation. He is being examined 12 weeks postnatally. What is the age of the child to be considered while undertaking developmental assessment?
questions.solution:
The corrected age (in weeks) to be assumed while undertaking developmental assessment is 4 weeks.

Corrected age (in weeks) = (Gestational age + postnatal age) - 40 weeks

Here, the gestational age is 32 weeks and postnatal age is 12 weeks. Therefore, with the above calculation, the corrected age is 4 weeks.

In babies born preterm, corrected age is used for their developmental assessment until 2 years of age.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of major depression was brought to the hospital after a suicide attempt due to a drug overdose. He reportedly consumed several tablets of a mecamylamine. Which of the following signs or symptoms would be consistent with the overdose of this drug?
questions.solution:
Mecamylamine is a ganglion-blocking agent, which results in decreased blood pressure, bowel activity, and sweating. Because the parasympathetic system dominates the sinoatrial node, ganglion block causes tachycardia.

Ganglion blocking agents block nicotinic cholinoceptors on postganglionic neurons in both sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia.

Although both sympathetic and parasympathetic responses are blocked, at certain sites either one of those predominates:

  • The sympathetic system predominates in arterioles veins and sweat glands.
  • The parasympathetic system predominates in heart, iris ciliary muscle, GIT, urinary bladder and salivary glands.

Examples of ganglion blockers include mecamylamine and trimethaphan.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came to the OPD with blurred vision. His fundus examination was done. The fundus appearance is as shown in the image given below. This appearance is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the fundal image showing laminar dot sign is suggestive of Glaucoma.

Laminar dot sign is an advanced glaucomatous change in the optic disc. It is because the pores in the lamina cribrosa are slit-shaped and are visible as grey dots due to thinning of neuroretinal rim in these patients.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc

Early glaucomatous changes

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup: 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertically oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayoneting sign: Sharp angulation of vessel at margin of excavated cup
  • Laminar dot sign

Note: As the damage progresses, all the neural tissue of the disc is destroyed and the optic nerve head appears white and deeply excavated resulting in Glaucomatous optic atrophy.

In Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD), the fundus shows yellowish-white spots in the macular region called drusens (shown in the image below) 

Related Pearl: Classification of optic atrophy

  • Simple optic atrophy: (Primary) Image below
    • Pathology lies in portion of optic nerve behind lamina cribrosa.
    • Causes are multiple sclerosis, neurosyphilis, and traumatic optic neuropathy.
    • Well defined disc margin and chalky white in color.

Post-neuritic optic atrophy: (Secondary)

  • Occurs after disc edema.
  • Causes are Papillitis and papilledema
  • Blurred disc margin and dirty white in color
  • Consecutive optic atrophy
    • Extensive pathology of retina.
    • Causes are retinitis pigmentosa and any cause of diffuse chorioretinitis
    • Well defined disc margin and pale waxy disc.
  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy/Cavernous optic atrophy:
    • 100% cupping
    • Bayonetting of vessels
    • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with acidity and abdominal pain for the past few months, not relieved by taking antacids. Endoscopy revealed prominent gastric folds and ulcers on the second part of the duodenum. Investigations revealed elevated serum gastrin levels and increased basal acid secretion. Which of the following is the next best investigation?

choices.text: Endoscopic ultrasound guided deep gastric biopsy
Blood gastrin levels following secretin administration
Monoclonal antibody-based H. pylori stool antigen test
Double contrast barium study of proximal  GI tract

questions.solution:
The presence of peptic ulcers and poor response to antacids, together with elevated serum gastrin levels and increased basal acid secretion are suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The next best investigation to confirm the diagnosis is to perform a secretin stimulation test.

In normal individuals, the administration of secretin causes no change or a slight decrease in blood gastrin levels. However, in patients with ZE syndrome, the circulating gastrin levels paradoxically increase following secretin administration.

Other investigations include:

  • Tumor localization and staging using a combination of CT and endoscopic ultrasound
  • Radio-labeled somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • 68gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Other options:

Option A: Endoscopic ultrasound-guided deep gastric biopsy is usually done to diagnose infiltrating gastric tumours such as linitis plastica (GLP) and gastric lymphoma.

Options C and D: Monoclonal antibody-based H pylori stool antigen test and double-contrast barium study of proximal GI tract are the tests indicated for the diagnostic evaluation of H. pylori peptic ulcer disease.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty holding his limb close to his chest and unable to complete the range of motion. He was trying to break open a locked door with his shoulder. His vitals are otherwise stable. X-ray of his shoulder is as shown below. Which of the following methods cannot be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
All of the given options are the methods used for the reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation, except Sushruta's method.

Anterior dislocation is the commonest shoulder dislocation and can be caused due to trauma from behind the shoulder pushing the head out anteriorly. It is also caused due to falling on an outstretched hand in an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. It can be diagnosed on clinical examination with flattening of the shoulder contour and ability to place a rule (Hamilton ruler test) and the inability to touch his/her opposite shoulder (Duga's test). X-ray confirms the diagnosis and may show associated Hill Sachs or bony bankart lesion. The most common complication is a recurrent shoulder dislocation.

It can be adequately treated by prompt reduction by any of the described methods.

The image shows common associated Xray findings in anterior shoulder lesion. 

Hill Sach's lesion is due to impingement of glenoid labrum into the humeral head, causing posterolateral depression.

Bankart lesion is due to stripping of the glenoid labrum from the glenoid cavity as the head dislocates. It sometimes may be associated with bony avulsion of the anteroinferior glenoid rim as seen in this image.

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side. 

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: The fontanelle marked “C” usually closes within  ________  after birth.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "C" is sphenoid fontanelle and it closes at around 2-3 months of age.

Fontanelle of the skull:

  • The anterior fontanelle is present between the two frontal and two parietal bones. It closes at around 18 - 24 months. The junction is marked by bregma where the coronal and sagittal sutures meet.
  • The posterior fontanelle is present between the junction of the sagittal and lambdoid suture and closes at around 2-3 months of birth.
  • The sphenoid fontanelle corresponds to the pterion and also closes at around 2-3 months of birth.
  • The mastoid fontanelle closes around the end of the first year.

questions.text: A dead body is brought in for post mortem immediately after the death. You notice that the temperature of the body remains raised for about the first two hours after death. This is explained by:
questions.solution:
Condition in which the temperature of the body remains raised for about first two hours after death is termed as postmortem caloricity. 

Strychnine poisoning, septicaemia and sun stroke lead to increase in body temperature for first 2 hours following death.

The condition occurs:

  • When the regulation of body temperature has been severely disturbed before death as in sunstroke, pontine haemorrhage.
  • Increased heat production in muscles due to convulsions as in tetanus and strychnine poisoning.
  • When there has been increased bacterial activity as in septicaemia, cholera.

Other options:

  • Cooling of the body after death is termed as algor mortis
  • Suggillation is same as livor mortis and refers to postmortem staining

questions.text: Mothers having any of the following conditions are advised not to breastfeed their infants, except _______

choices.text: A mother who is undergoing breast cancer treatment
A mother who has active tuberculosis
A mother who has hepatitis C infection
Mothers who do not control their alcohol use

questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in mothers having a hepatitis C infection.

Maternal Hepatitis C is not a contraindication because breastfeeding has not shown to transmit the infection.

Contraindications of breastfeeding:

Do not Breastfeed

Do not give expressed breastmilk

Infant factors:

  • Classic galactosemia

Maternal factors:

  • Human T-cell lymphocyte virus (HTLV) infection
  • Ebola virus infection
  • PCP/cocaine abuse

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Do not give expressed breastmilk  (Temporarily)

Maternal factors:

  • Brucellosis
  • undergoing Diagnostic imaging with radiopharmaceuticals
  • Active herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection with lesions on the breasts

Do not Breastfeed (Temporarily)

Can give expressed breastmilk

Maternal factors:

  • Untreated, active Tuberculosis
  • active Varicella infection

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought with an unprovoked Category-III dog bite. He was not immunized previously. After washing the wound, and vaccination, you have decided to give immunoglobulin. Your hospital provides equine rabies immunoglobulin. The maximum dose that can be given is ______
questions.solution:
The maximum dosage of equine rabies immunoglobulin that can be given is 40 IU/kg body weight.

Rabies immunoglobulin is provided in 2 types and their doses should be:

  • Human rabies immunoglobulin (hRIG): 20 IU/kg body weight.
  • Equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG): 40 IU/kg body weight.

Rabies immunoglobulin is administered only once at or as soon as possible after the initiation of post-exposure vaccination. Beyond the seventh day after the first dose of vaccine, rabies immunoglobulin is not indicated because an active antibody response to the vaccine has already occurred.

The use of monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus as alternatives for RIGs in PEP is under study.

Management of category III bite:

A category III wound is single or multiple transdermal bites, scratches, or licks on broken skin. It includes contamination of mucous membrane with saliva from licks or contacts with bats. 

  • In previously unimmunized patients, Immediate vaccination and rabies immunoglobulin administration is needed with local wound treatment. 
  • The wound and adjoining area should be cleaned with plenty of soap and water, preferably under running water for at least 15 minutes to minimize the risk of contracting rabies. 
  • After cleaning, the wound should be treated with virucidal agents like alcohol or tincture iodine.
  • If the wound needs suturing, it should be done 24-48 hours after the incident with minimum sutures. Immediate suturing may spread the virus into deeper tissues. 

Post-exposure prophylaxis in previously unimmunized patients

  • Essen regimen:
    • 5 dose regimen: One intramuscular dose each on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 days 
  • Zareb regimen:
    • 4 dose multisite regimen, 2 intramuscular doses on day 0, and 1 intramuscular dose each on days 7 and 21 
  • Intradermal regimen:
    • 2 site regimen, two intradermal doses on days 0, 3, 7, and 28. 

Zero by 30 : is the Global strategic plan to end human death from dog mediated rabies by 2030.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to you with the following lesion over the eye.  All the following statements regarding this condition are true except:

choices.text: It is usually a stationary condition
Associated with deposition of amorphous hyaline material in the conjunctiva
Temopral side is affected first and then the nasal side
There is elastotic degeneration of collagen fibres of conjunctiva

questions.solution:
The image shows pinguecula, which affects the nasal side first and then the temporal side.

Pinguecula is a degenerative condition of the conjunctiva, characterized by the formation of a yellowish-white patch on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus.

Features:

  • Usually found in elderly people, especially those exposed to strong sunlight, dust, wind, etc.
  • There is an elastotic degeneration of collagen fibres of the substantia propria of the conjunctiva, coupled with deposition of amorphous hyaline material in the substance of conjunctiva.
  • It is a stationary condition

Complications of pinguecula include its inflammation, intraepithelial abscess formation and rarely calcification.

No treatment is required. When inflamed, it is treated with topical steroid.

questions.text: A 17-year-old student comes to the clinic with a history of four episodes of arthritis involving large joints and was recently admitted for new-onset atrial fibrillation. A holosystolic murmur with early diastolic rumbling is heard at the apex. An early diastolic murmur is also heard at the right second intercostal space near the sternal edge. Which of the following is recommended for long-term prophylaxis of the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has clinical features and a history suggestive of recurrent episodes of acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Monthly penicillin G injections are recommended for long-term prophylaxis.

The findings of mitral regurgitation and aortic regurgitation indicate the diagnosis of ARF. The presence of atrial fibrillation indicates severe rheumatic heart disease. Prophylaxis with either oral phenoxymethylpenicillin (250 mg twice daily) or preferably, benzathine benzylpenicillin (1.2 million U IM monthly) is considered the best method to prevent further episodes of ARF, and therefore prevent further valvular damage.

ARF is an autoimmune disease that develops in response to group A streptococcal infection. It is commonly seen in children between the age of 5-14 years. An upper respiratory tract infection with some M serotypes of the organism is the trigger. The concept of molecular mimicry is used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. 

Since one attack of ARF increases the risk for further episodes and development of RHD, secondary prophylaxis is recommended by the American heart association (AHA) as follows:

  • Rheumatic fever without carditis: For 5 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer). 
  • Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual valvular disease: For 10 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer).
  • Rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease, evident clinically or on echocardiography: For 10 years after the last attack or till the age of 40 (whichever is longer). Sometimes lifelong prophylaxis can be given.

Symptoms usually present after a latent period of about three weeks. Indolent carditis and chorea are the exceptions that can present even six months later. Migratory asymmetric polyarthritis which affects large joints and high-grade fever are common features. Cutaneous manifestations include erythema marginatum and subcutaneous nodules. Sydenham's chorea is commonly found in females and frequently affects the head and upper limbs.

Other options:

Option A: Glucocorticoids are recommended at a dose of 1–2 mg/kg per day (maximum, 80 mg), usually for a few days or up to a maximum of 3 weeks.

Option C: Doxycycline is not a first-line agent for group A Streptococcus, the pathogen that causes ARF.

Option D: Daily aspirin is the treatment of choice for the migratory arthritis of large joints and fever which are common manifestations of ARF. 

 

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: The x ray image shown is that of an individual with history of multiple episodes of painful swelling of the foot. Which of the following is incorrect regarding management of his condition?

choices.text: Allopurinol is the drug of choice for him even if his renal function is compromised
Colchicine can be used for acute attacks
Weight loss causes more severe and frequent attacks

questions.solution:
Weight loss does not cause more severe or frequent attacks.
The image shows Martel’s Sign/ G Sign/ Rat bite erosion which is suggestive of chronic tophaceous gout.
Allopurinol is the drug of choice in chronic tophaceous gout as well as in those with renal insufficiency(with dose adjustment).

Preventive Measures:

  1. Low Purine Diet
  2. Increased fluid ingestion
  3. Decreased Alcohol intake
  4. Weight loss
  5. Avoiding Diuretics

Treatment of acute attack:

  1. Colchicine
  2. NSAIDs
  3. Glucocorticoids

Treatment of chronic Gout (always started under the cover of NSAIDs)

  1. Uricosuric Drugs (Probenecid or Sulfinpyrazone)
  2. Allopurinol

Note: Febuxostat is a hypouricemic drug that does not require dose adjustment in renal disease. Allopurinol is the drug used in gout with renal disease with dose adjustment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman who is G2P1 in the 32nd week of gestation was found to have a blood pressure of 160/98 mmHg without proteinuria. Her BP recorded during the previous ANC visits were 144/92 mmHg and 150/96 mmHg during the 16th week and 24th week of gestation respectively. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is  ____.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is chronic hypertension because her blood pressure at the 16th week of gestation was >140/90mmHg. 

Gestational Hypertension

Pre-Eclampsia

Chronic Hypertension in pregnancy

Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

Rise in BP >140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of pregnancy

Previously known hypertensive or BP  >140/90mmHg before 20 weeks of gestation

No Proteinuria

Proteinuria present(>300 mg in 24 hrs urine or >30 mg/dl in the random urine sample or urine dipstick 1+)

No proteinuria

BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

BP returns to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

BP does not come to normal within 12 weeks of delivery

 

  • Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as BP of >140/90 mmHg measured 2 times with at least 6-h interval.
  • Also, diastolic BP is determined by the disappearance of Korotkoff V sound (normally, in adults we take Korotkoff IV for measuring DBP).

questions.text: You are a forensic medical officer; you have been asked to evaluate the gender of a skull found on a crime scene. Which of the following trait in the skull would suggest to you that it is a male skull?

choices.text: Mastoid process is narrow and pointed
Frontal and parietal eminences are smaller
Orbits are round with sharp margin

questions.solution:
Frontal and parietal eminences are smaller in a male skull; hence, option C is correct.

Differentiating features between male and female skulls:

Trait Male Female
General size Large (1500 to 1550 mL) Small (1350 to 1400 mL)

Forehead

 Steeper, less rounded  Vertical, round, infantile
Architecture Rugged Smooth
Supraorbital ridges Prominent and rounded Less prominent
Mastoid process

Wider, longer, round, blunt.

Narrow, short, smooth, pointed.
Occipital region Marked muscle markings, protuberance prominent No marked muscle markings, nonprominent
Frontal eminences Small Large
Parietal eminences Small Large
Orbits Square with round margins Round with sharp margins
Mandible Large, less obtuse, and prominent  ramus Small, more obtuse, and non-prominent ramus
Chin shape U-shaped V-shaped

The features given above develop after puberty and are modified by senility. The determination of sex is based mainly upon the appearances of the following bone:

  • Pelvis
  • Skull
  • Sternum
  • Long bones 

Frontal eminence is located on the frontal bone of the forehead and is more pronounced in children, marking where the two halves of the frontal bone fuse. Parietal eminence is located on the parietal bones, marking the widest point of the skull, important for cranial measurements and skull development.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who is a known case of ulcerative colitis presented to the emergency department with severe exacerbation of the symptoms. His stool frequency suddenly increased to 10 times in the past 24 hours, with the presence of blood in stools for more than six times. He was on 5-ASA agents for the past several months. On examination, the temperature is 100.2°F, blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg, and heart rate is 90 beats/min. Investigations revealed a CRP of 78 mg/L. The patient was immediately put on supportive therapy with IV fluids. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Withhold 5-ASA agents, and administer IV glucocorticoids and LMW heparin
Continue 5-ASA and administer IV Infliximab or ciclosporin
Withhold 5-ASA agents, and administer IV cyclosporin and LMW heparin

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presented with acute severe ulcerative colitis. Current guidelines recommend withholding of the 5-ASA agents, correcting dehydration, and administration of IV glucocorticoids (hydrocortisone or methylprednisolone) and LMW heparin for 3 days followed by re-assessment of the condition.

Acute severe ulcerative colitis:

Truelove–Witts criteria define acute severe colitis as the presence of:

  1. ≥ 6 bloody stools/24 hrs
  2. Plus, one or more of the following features suggestive of systemic toxicity:
    • Anemia (Hemoglobin <10 g/dL).
    • Mild fever (>100.04°F).
    • Tachycardia (Pulse ≥90 beats/min).
    • High inflammatory markers (ESR > 30 mm/hr or CRP >30 mg/L).

Management of acute severe ulcerative colitis:

  • Administer IV glucocorticoids (hydrocortisone or methylprednisolone), along with low molecular weight heparin to prevent venous thromboembolism. Withhold 5-ASA agents.
  • Sigmoidoscopy is usually done within 24 hours to check for the presence of CMV colitis. 
  • The patient's condition is assessed at the end of 3 days. If the patient does not respond to the glucocorticoids, then second-line drugs such as ciclosporin or infliximab are administered.
  • If the patient improves, then IV steroids are switched with oral prednisolone. Treatment with thiopurine is commenced and 5-ASA agents are restarted.
  • Emergency colectomy is indicated for the patients who develop colonic dilatation (>6 cm), those whose clinical condition or laboratory results deteriorate, and those who do not respond after 7–10 days of maximal medical treatment.
