questions.text: 5 people out of 60 who landed from an international flight were positive for COVID-19. Totally, 75 people were in contact with these 5 cases, out of these 15 were found to be positive within 2 weeks of the incubation period. Calculate the secondary attack rate in this?
questions.solution:
The secondary attack rate, in this case, is 20%

In this scenario, the total number of primary cases were 5.

The total number exposed people who were in contact with the primary cases were 75 and the total number of exposed people developing the disease were 15.

Secondary attack rate=(Number of exposed people developing the disease within the incubation period/Number of people exposed)×100

=(15/75)×100

=(1/5)x100

=20

Therefore the secondary attack rate is 20%

 

Note:

The incubation period of COVID-19 may extend up to 14 days, with a median incubation period between 4-5 days from exposure to symptoms onset.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes for advice on diet, he would like to know about foods that favor the slow release of sugar. Which among the following is considered to have a low glycemic index?
questions.solution:
Pasta foods have a low glycemic index, all the other options have high.

Glycemic index (GI) is the area under the two-hour blood glucose response curve (AUC) following the ingestion of a fixed portion of test carbohydrate as a proportion of the AUC of the standard (glucose or white bread).

This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

The classification of foods according to Glycemic index (GI) is as follows,

  • Low GI foods (GI = 55 or less): Most fruits and vegetables (except potatoes, watermelon, and sweet corn), whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils.
  • Moderate GI foods (GI = 56 to 69): Sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice.
  • High GI foods (GI = 70 or more): Corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, candies, and syrupy foods.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male is brought to the emergency due to persistent vomiting. The patient is in an inebriated state with a high blood alcohol level. The patient's friends say that he had been drinking all night. As the CBG was only 54mg/dl, an IV glucose infusion was started by the intern. 30 minutes after the infusion the patient develops ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion. Deficiency of which of the following is responsible for the condition?
questions.solution:
This patients clinical features are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is seen due to the deficiency of Thiamine/Vitamin B1. Thiamine is a cofactor for several important enzymes and also involved in the conduction of the axon potential and synaptic transmission.

Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder. Glucose infusions may precipitate Wernicke’s disease in a previously unaffected patient or cause a rapid worsening of an early form of the disease (as in this patient). For this reason, thiamine should be administered to all alcoholic patients requiring parenteral glucose.

The triad is (GOA):

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia (first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  • Ataxia

Alcohol abuse leads to thiamine deficiency by the following mechanisms:

  • Poor nutritional habits
  • Folate deficiency which reduces thiamine absorption from the gastrointestinal tract
  • Direct damage of the intestinal mucosa

Treatment:

It is a medical emergency and requires immediate administration of thiamine 100 mg IV or IM for 3 days followed by two to three times a day orally for 1 to 2 weeks.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient presented to casualty with extensive burns as shown below.  Which of the following is the most likely etiology of infection in her?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most likely cause of infection in the case of a burn.

Pathogenesis

  • It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by means of diphtheria like exotoxin A and slime layer.
  • Breach in primary body defenses as in burns predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Diagnosis:

  • It grows well on most media and pigment production makes its identification easy. 
  • Species identification is made possible by biochemical tests - arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction. 

Clinical features:

  • It is characterized by blue-green pus.
  • It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas.

Note:

Aeruginosa is a Latin word meaning verdigris, which is the common name for a green pigment obtained through the application of acetic acid to copper plates.

The P. aeruginosa species is named so, as the blue-green pus caused by its infection resembles the green-pigment of verdigris.

questions.text: Which of the following is increased in a patient under inhalation anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Work of breathing is increased under the effect of General anesthesia.

Work of breathing is the energy required to carry out inspiration and expiration. Normally only inspiration requires energy, to overcome the elastic recoil of the lung and chest by the diaphragm, whilst expiration is passive. However, under anesthesia, muscle tone is reduced and work of breathing is increased. It can be circumvented by controlled mechanical ventilation.

Other options are decreased under the effect of general anesthesia.

Compliance is the change in volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure. It is measured in terms of elastic recoil. With reduced diaphragmatic tone, the abdominal contents push the lung cephalad, making it difficult for lung expansion during inhalation. Hence compliance is decreased under anesthesia.

Functional residual capacity or FRC is the volume of air in the lung after quiet expiration. It is greatly affected by sex, body habitus, and posture. It reduces from standing or sitting to supine and even furthermore in the prone position. In the supine position (which is usually the case in inhalation anesthesia), the abdominal contents push the lung upwards, causing a decrease in FRC.

Closing capacity is the minimum lung volume after which the smaller airways start collapsing. The smaller airways lack cartilaginous support and to keep them open, it needs to have air inside it. Thus further reducing the lung volume would cause them to close. It is generally agreed that it decreases in anesthesia.

questions.text: The government uses the following sign at public places in order to directly or indirectly alter human behavior. This is an example of which of the following approaches towards health education?
questions.solution:
The "No smoking" sign is an example of a regulatory approach.

A regulatory approach with respect to health education is defined as a government intervention, which is designed to alter human behavior either directly or indirectly. Regulations may take many forms, from prohibition to imprisonment.

Examples of this approach include The Child Marriage Restraint Act and the use of compulsory seatbelts. However, there are many failures to this approach, as some of these approaches involve areas related to personal choices as well like diet, exercise, smoking, etc

The four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach
  • Service approach
  • Health education approach
  • Primary health care approach

The service approach (option B) is a government intervention aimed at providing all the health services needed by the people at their doorstep so the people would use them to improve their own health. An example of this approach is the free-of-cost latrines provided by the government. But many people in the rural areas did not make use of this because its need was not felt.

The health education approach (option A) is an intervention to provide necessary behavioral changes in people to make their own choice for a healthy life through health education. Examples of this approach are cessation of smoking, use of safe water supply, fertility control through health education. 

The primary health care approach (option D) is an intervention with active involvement from the people in the planning and delivery of health services based on the principle of primary health care. This actually deals with community involvement and intersectoral coordination.

questions.text: In which of the following marked areas, the liver is not covered by visceral peritonium?
questions.solution:
The part of the liver marked with 'B' is the bare area of the liver, as this area marks the portion of the liver which is not covered by visceral peritoneum.

The bare area of the liver is a triangular area of the liver that is devoid of peritoneal covering. It is formed by the two layers of the coronary ligament. In this bare area, the liver is attached to the diaphragm by areolar tissue.

questions.text: While performing a Purkinje image test in a patient having a mature cataract, you notice only 3 images.  Which of the following images are absent in this patient?

choices.text: Erect image formed by anterior surface of the lens
Erect image formed by posterior surface of the lens
Inverted image formed by anterior surface of the lens
Inverted image formed by posterior surface of the lens

questions.solution:
Image 4 i.e Inverted image formed by the Posterior surface of the lens is absent in patients with mature cataract.

Purkinje images are reflections of objects from the structure of the eye. They are also known as Purkinje reflexes or Purkinje–Sanson images.

Normal 4 images are formed from four different reflecting surfaces i.e.

  • Image 1—Anterior surface of the cornea: Erect
  • Image 2—Posterior surface of the cornea: Erect
  • Image 3—Anterior surface of the lens: Erect
  • Image 4—Posterior surface of the lens: Inverted
  • In aphakia: Image 3 and Image 4 are absent.

questions.text: A primigravida experienced precipitous labor while being transported in an ambulance. Upon arrival at the hospital, the given injury is observed. What type of injury is most likely?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a perineal tear extending up to the rectal mucosa, therefore, it is a grade 4 perineal tear.

The involvement of rectal mucosa as shown in the image differentiates it from grade 3 tear. Grade 3 tear involves the vaginal mucosa, perineal skin, perineal muscles, and the anal sphincter complex (external and/or internal), but not rectal mucosa, while grade 4 tear involves all these layers including the rectal mucosa.

Minor perineal injuries are quite common, especially during the first birth. Gross injures like third or fourth degrees of perineal tears are a result of mismanagement of the second stage of labour. This can be prevented by proper conduct of the second stage labour.

Management is as follows:

All recent tears should be repaired immediately after the delivery of the placenta. If there is a delay of 24 hours, the repair has to be withheld and the patient has to be started on antibiotics to prevent infection. Complete perineal tears that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery.

In 3 months of time, any local infection that might have been present would subside, the general condition of the patient will also improve. However, if the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms and making the surgery difficult.

questions.text: A patient was referred to the ICTC for HIV screening. He turned out to be positive by HIV spot test. A confirmation regarding the type of HIV was done using immunoblot for ART selection. Presence of which of the following proteins differentiates HIV2 compared to HIV1?
questions.solution:
Presence of gp36 points towards a diagnosis of HIV2.

HIV2 is genetically similar to HIV1 by only 40%. Moreover, it is intrinsically resistant to NNRTI, hence it should be differentiated from HIV1 for optimum ART prescription. Its prevalence is low in India (less than 3%), however widespread studies are needed. Clinically, HIV2 is slower to progress than HIV1

Western blot (WB) detects specific antibodies against multiple proteins of all 3 major HIV genes - gag, pol, and env. WB has a high specificity and is therefore used as a confirmatory test.

Note: In India, NACO provides western blot confirmatory testing only to resolve indeterminate results on previous serological testing and not for routine confirmation after a positive result on screening tests. Drawbacks of WB include low rates of detection during acute HIV infection and misclassification of HIV-2 infection.

Apart from Western blot, Line immunoassays (LIA) and PCR to detect vpu or vpx genes, in HIV1 and HIV2 respectively can be carried out for confirmation.

questions.text: The enzyme involved in the process of oxidative deamination shown in the below reaction is allosterically activated by ______
questions.solution:
Glutamate dehydrogenase is involved in the process of oxidative deamination reaction. It is allosterically activated by ADP.

Transfer of amino nitrogen to α-ketoglutarate forms glutamate. Hepatic glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), which can use either NAD+ or NADP+, releases this nitrogen as ammonia.

Conversion of α-amino nitrogen to ammonia by the action of glutamate aminotransferase and GDH is often termed “transdeamination.” 

Liver GDH activity is allosterically inhibited by ATP, GTP, and NADH, and is activated by ADP.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female patient presented with complaints of chest pain, palpitations, and fatigue. On auscultation, a high-pitch diastolic heart murmur was heard over the second intercostal space to the left of the sternum. The mean-QRS axis on ECG is 150 degrees. The arterial blood oxygen content is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most-likely diagnosis is pulmonic regurgitation.

The heart murmur was heard over the 2nd left intercostal space, to the left of the sternum, which is the pulmonary area for cardiac auscultation. The high-pitch indicates regurgitation.

The mean-QRS vector is normally oriented at +59 degrees.  In the given patient, the mean-QRS axis on ECG is 150 degrees which is suggestive of right-axis deviation, indicating hypertrophy of the right side of the heart.

Among the given options, both Tetralogy of Fallot and pulmonic regurgitation are associated with a right-axis deviation. However, in tetralogy of the Fallot, the arterial oxygen concentration is low. However, in the given patient the oxygen concentration is normal, which rules out TOF.

questions.text: As you were the only doctor in your family, one of your close relatives shows all his radiological reports which he got done for an insurance policy. You notice thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm extending from the sixth intercostal space to below the renal arteries. Based on Crawford classification system, you would categorize this aneurysm into which of the following types?
questions.solution:
Thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm extending from sixth intercostal space to below the renal arteries is categorized as type 3 based on Crawford classification system.

Crawford classification of thoraco-abdominal aortic aneurysm:

  • Type I - Extends from distal to the left subclavian artery to above renal arteries.
  • Type II (most extensive type) - Extends from distal to the left subclavian artery to below the renal arteries.
  • Type III - Extends from the sixth intercostal space to below the renal arteries.
  • Type IV - Extends from the twelfth intercostal space to the iliac bifurcation (total abdominal aortic aneurysm)

Note: Modified Crawford classification includes an additional Type V: which extends from below the sixth intercostal space to just above the renal arteries.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male patient presented with a 3-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. There is a history of similar episodes 2 years back. Occasionally, he has noticed dark-colored urine. LFT is given below. A liver biopsy, stained with Fontana-Masson stain is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin - 4.4 mg/dL (Predominantly conjugated)

Serum AST, ALT- Normal
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the liver biopsy showing characteristic deposition of pigment are suggestive of Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver which can lead to a gross black appearance of the liver. The disease is caused by the mutation in the multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) gene in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes.

Total bilirubin concentrations are typically between 2 and 5 mg/dL and can fluctuate widely in patients. Hyper-bilirubinemia may be increased by current illness, oral contraceptive use, and pregnancy. Aside from elevated serum bilirubin levels, other routine laboratory tests (eg Liver Function tests) are normal. 

Other options:

Option A: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs due to a decrease in UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UDPGT) activity. Type 1 has absent/trace UDPGT enzyme activity and type 2 has <10% of the normal UDPGT enzyme activity.

Option C: Budd Chiari syndrome is characterized by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow. It is a clinical complex characterized by hepatomegaly, ascites and abdominal pain.

Option D: Gilbert syndrome is a type of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that occurs due to reduced UDPGT enzyme activity (10-33% of Normal).

questions.text: A 36-year-old male chronic smoker was diagnosed with pulmonary bleb a few months ago. He now presented with acute-onset breathlessness and right-sided pleuritic chest pain. Examination revealed oxygen saturation of 94% breathing room air, decreased air entry on the right side of the chest with hyper-resonant percussion note. Chest X-ray revealed right-sided pneumothorax. Therapeutic needle aspiration was done, and about  2 L of air was aspirated. However, there was no change in the X-ray appearance. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of the patient?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of the condition is to insert an intercostal chest tube.

The clinical features are suggestive of primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP) most likely due to the rupture of the pulmonary bleb. Therapeutic needle aspiration was the appropriate first step, however, as aspiration failed, intercostal chest tube insertion is indicated.

Primary spontaneous pneumothorax:

  • The condition is caused spontaneously and most commonly seen in smokers with underlying subclinical lung disease.
  • Spontaneous pneumothorax commonly occurs due to rupture of the apical pleural blebs, small cystic spaces. 
  • Recurrence of the cases may be seen in over half of the patients.
  • Therapeutic aspiration is the first-line therapy.
  • If the patient has a recurrent pneumothorax, thoracoscopy with stapling of blebs and pleural abrasion is indicated as a definitive management. But for the first episode in primary spontaneous pneumothorax, definitive management is not indicated as it is unlikely to be recurrent.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a history of weakness and fatigue for the past three months. There is no history of alcohol consumption or intake of any drugs. A complete blood count and peripheral smear show evidence of megaloblastic anemia and a normal reticulocyte count. He is found to have vitamin B12 deficiency on further laboratory testing. What is the most likely cause of anemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Autoimmune gastritis refers to a chronic, diffuse inflammatory disease of the stomach that is restricted to the body and fundus. This disorder typically features diffuse atrophic gastritis, antibodies to parietal cells and the intrinsic factor, and increased serum gastrin due to G-cell hyperplasia. Due to the neutralization of the intrinsic factor, there is decreased absorption of vitamin B12. As a result, all lineages of bone marrow precursors show asynchronous maturation between the nucleus and cytoplasm (megaloblastic cells), and the peripheral blood displays megaloblastic anemia.

Megaloblastic anemia that is caused by malabsorption of vitamin B12, due to deficiency of the intrinsic factor, is called pernicious anemia. Circulating antibodies to parietal cells occur in 90% of patients with pernicious anemia. Two-thirds of patients display an antibody to the intrinsic factor that prevents its combination with vitamin B12, thereby preventing the formation of the complex that is later absorbed in the ileum.

The other options are not the causes of pernicious anemia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: An elderly lady presented with the following skin lesions on the face. They do not cause any symptoms except for cosmetic appearance. She is concerned as they have increased in number over the years. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding seen in the case scenario provided is seborrheic keratosis.

Seborrheic keratoses are common epidermal tumors consisting of a benign proliferation of immature keratinocytes. They present as well-demarcated plaques or papules, round, or oval lesions with a dull, verrucous surface and a typical stuck-on appearance. They are usually multiple. They typically occur on the chest and back but are also found commonly on the face, scalp, neck, and extremities. These lesions can be easily removed with liquid nitrogen or curettage or both.

Other options:

Option B- Malignant melanoma is a malignant proliferation of melanocytes. It is usually solitary unlike multiple in this case. Moreover, it is fast-growing, has color changes, and asymmetrical appearance. In case of doubt, a biopsy can be done.

Option C- Dermatosis papulosa nigra are smaller flat lesions limited to the upper part of the face. They usually occur after the 2nd decade unlike so late as in this case.

Option D- Verrucae vulgaris refers to benign warts. They have a cauliflower-like warty surface, unlike a smooth surface as in this case.

questions.text: In an anatomy practical exam, a student was shown the anterior surface of the spinal cord as shown below and was asked to identify the marked structure. The structure marked as '?' is a modification of:
questions.solution:
The structure marked as "?" in the above image is ligamentum denticulatum. It is a modification of the pia mater.

The ligamentum denticulatum(Dentate ligament) is a flat, fibrous sheet on either side of the spinal cord between the ventral and dorsal spinal nerve roots. Its medial border is continuous with the subpial connective tissue and the lateral border forms a series of 21 triangular processes on each side connecting it to the dura mater giving it a serrated appearance. The lowest projection of ligamentum denticulatum lies at the level of T12 and L1 spinal nerves.

The first projection crosses behind the vertebral artery where it is attached to the dura mater and is separated by the artery from the first cervical ventral root. Its site of attachment to the dura mater is above the rim of the foramen magnum.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with a fractured femur after a road traffic accident. Complete blood count revealed a WBC count of 22,000/μl. The intern who saw the result immediately reported the finding to the resident who suggested to repeat the test after 6 hours. A repeat blood test revealed a WBC count of 7,000/μl. Which of the following is likely responsible for an initial increase in WBC count?

choices.text: Transient increased production of WBCs due to stress
Release of pre-formed mature WBCs into the circulation
Increased concentration of WBCs due to sudden loss of blood

questions.solution:
The initial rise in WBC concentration is due to the release of pre-formed mature WBCs into the circulation.

Majority of the mature WBCs, which is almost three times the circulating WBCs, are stored in the bone marrow, and are released into the circulation when stimulated by an increased level of cytokines. However, in conditions such as trauma, there is an increased release of the pre-formed mature WBCs into the circulation, in response to stress, leading to the elevated WBC count.

However, the rise in WBC count is transient, and will return back to the normal levels within a few hours.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with psychosis and visual hallucinations that began several months ago. He now has dementia,  memory loss, impaired judgment, and intermittent myoclonus. He passes away 1 year after the onset of symptoms. Brain biopsy reveals PrPsc proteins accumulations. Which of the following is this agent sensitive to?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests Creutzfeldt Jakob disease, a condition caused by prions. Prions are sensitive to phenol.

The patient with psychosis, visual hallucinations, dementia, memory loss, impaired judgment, intermittent myoclonus, death one year after onset of symptoms, and brain biopsy significant for PrPSc accumulations is likely to have Creutzfeldt Jakob disease.  

Prions are the proteinaceous infectious particle that lacks nucleic acid, composed entirely of alternatively folded proteins that undergo self-propagation. PrPSc is the disease-causing isoform of the prion protein. Diagnosis can be established by detecting PrPSc proteins in brain biopsy. However, the diagnosis can be made clinically.

Prions are resistant to formaldehyde, urea, dry heat, boiling, ethanol, proteases, deoxycholate, and ionizing radiation. They are sensitive to phenol, household bleach, ether, sodium hydroxide, strong detergents, and autoclaving. 

Other diseases caused by prions include:

  • Creutzfeldt­ Jakob disease
  • Gerstmann­ Sträussler ­Scheinke syndrome 
  • Fatal familial insomnia                       
  • Kuru in humans                          
  • Scrapie in sheep and goats   
  • Bovine spongiform en­cephalopathy in cows

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman came to the emergency department with severe pain in both legs, after she underwent an induced abortion using ergotamine. On examination, her legs were cold and pale, and peripheral arterial pulses were not felt. Which of the following drugs can be used as an antidote in treating the condition?
questions.solution:
Nitroprusside can be used as an antidote to reverse the ergot-induced vasospasm.

Nitroprusside is a non-selective vasodilator. It acts by releasing NO, which activates the guanylyl cyclase - cyclic GMP – protein kinase G pathway, leading to vasodilation. This mechanism mimics the production of NO by vascular endothelial cells.

Therapeutic uses:

  • It is primarily used in the treatment of hypertensive emergencies.
  • To lower blood pressure during aortic dissection. It is important to administer beta blocker with nitroprusside in aortic dissection to reduce heart rate, because if nitroprusside is given alone, it causes increased myocardial contractility, which in turn increases the rate of increase in aortic pressure and may further aggravate the dissection.
  • To improve cardiac output in patients with congestive heart failure, especially with hypertension and pulmonary edema, who are refractory to other treatments.
  • To decrease myocardial oxygen demand after myocardial infarction.
  • To induce controlled hypotension during anesthesia, and reduce bleeding during surgical procedures.
  • To reverse the vasospastic action of the ergot alkaloids, such as ergotamine and ergonovine.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents with a history of chronic constipation since birth. Physical examination shows marked abdominal distension. Abdominal radiography reveals distended bowel loops with the absence of air in the rectum. A rectal biopsy shows an absence of ganglion cells in the muscle wall and submucosa. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities may be associated with the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with a rectal biopsy showing an absence of ganglion cells in the muscle wall and submucosa is suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. Among the given conditions, the abmormality most likely to be associated with Hirschsprung disease is trisomy 21, i.e., Down syndrome.

Hirschsprung disease, or congenital aganglionic colon, is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexus. In the fetus, migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel wall for the formation of the enteric nervous system is completed by the 24th week of life. Abnormalities in this migration due to premature arrest or death of ganglionic cells result in Hirschsprung disease.

It is more common in males. Risk factors include Down's syndrome and RET oncogene mutations affecting neural crest cell migration. 

Hirschsprung disease is associated with various conditions:

  1. Trisomy 21/Down syndrome
  2. Smith–Lemli–Opitz syndrome
  3. Shah–Waardenburg syndrome
  4. Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2 syndrome
  5. Neurofibromatosis
  6. Neuroblastoma
  7. Urogenital or cardiovascular abnormalities.

It causes a muscular spasm of the distal intestinal segment, resulting in functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation (megacolon). The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

The image given below shows dilated ganglionic and contracted aganglionic segments in Hirschsprung's disease:

 

The imaging modality of choice in Hirschsprung disease is a contrast radiograph with barium or gastrograffin enema.

The most important film is a lateral or oblique view of the rectum during slow filling. It typically shows a low bowel obstruction. The rectum is seen as a narrow tube and a cone-shaped transition zone, seen proximal to the dilated ganglionated bowel.

The image given below shows a contrast enema in Hirschsprung's disease:

 

A rectal suction biopsy is a gold standard for the diagnosis and operative intervention is the definitive treatment.

Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum and then the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: A surgeon while performing a laparotomy procedure uses the following instrument. Which of the following option is true about this instrument?

choices.text: Safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.solution:
The given instrument is Monopolar electrocautery. Both cutting and coagulation modes are possible with monopolar electrocautery.

  • Application of Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms is responsible for the cutting of tissues.
  • Application of High voltage current for a short duration(intermittent waveform) is responsible for the coagulating of tissues

A short circuit is established in bipolar electrocautery between the tips of the instrument. This makes the chances of burns lesser compared to monopolar electrocautery. Bipolar electrocautery has less lateral dissipation of current so it is safer in procedures closure to vital structures.

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

questions.text: In a suspected case of fetomaternal hemorrhage of an Rh-negative pregnancy, Kleihaeur Betke's test is done. The findings are as shown below. In the following image, some RBCs remained red, and some appear as ghosted cells after the addition of reagent. This is mainly due to  ____ and ____ respectively.
questions.solution:
After performing the Kleihauer–Betke test, the RBCs that remain red are the fetal erythrocytes containing Hb-F, and the RBCs that appear as ghosted cells are the adult/maternal erythrocytes containing Hb-A.

Kleihauer–Betke test is the most commonly used quantitative test for measuring the fetal red cells in the maternal circulation. The reagent used for the Kleihauer–Betke test is citric acid. It is also known as the acid elution test.

Principle: Fetal erythrocytes contain haemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than haemoglobin A in the maternal erythrocytes.

After exposure to acid, only fetal haemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as “ghosts.” These fetal cells are counted and expressed as a percentage of adult cells.

Fetomaternal haemorrhage can also be quantified using flow cytometry to measure red cell size. It is unaffected by maternal levels of fetal haemoglobin F or by fetal levels of haemoglobin A. Flow cytometry has been reported to be more sensitive and accurate than the Kleihaeur Betke test.

Significance: This test can be performed when large(>30mL) fetomaternal haemorrhage is present. It is used in helpful in determining the additional amounts of Rh IgG needed to be administered. The amount of Rh IgG needed for treatment after sensitization is at least 20mcg/mL of fetal RBCs.

questions.text: A child aged 10 years presented with perianal pruritus which is worse in night. Routine stool examination didn't reveal parasite cysts or eggs. The following examination is done to recover eggs which are non-bile stained. Identify the organism causing the infection.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing scotch tape method to collect perianal egg deposition by (Enterobius vermicularis) is  suggestive of infestation with Pinworm 

Characteristics of Pinworm egg:

  • It is colorless, non-bile stained.
  • It floats in the saturated salt solution.
  • The egg is planoconvex. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent.

Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens.

Scotch tape method involves:

  1. Take a clear cellophane tape almost 4 cm long
  2. Hold it in such a way(or make a loop) so that sticky surface faces upwards or towards the perianal skin.
  3. Place the sticky surface of tap in the perianal area momentarily
  4. Place the sticky surface down on the glass slide. Examine under microscope.

Other eggs that can be collected by scotch tape method are Taenia solium, Taenia saginata, and Schistosoma mansoni. 

Other eggs which are non-bile stained can be remembered as NEHA - Necator americanus, Enterobius vermicularis, Hymenolepsis nana, Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: You have been posted as an intern in the labor room where you have to monitor the number, duration, and intensity of uterine contractions in a 34-year-old, G2 P1 with a term pregnancy. She has moderate contractions. How long do they last?
questions.solution:
Moderate uterine contractions lasts for 20-40 seconds.

  • Weak contractions: <20 s
  • Moderate contraction: 20–40 s
  • Strong contractions: >40 s

Uterine contractions have to be documented in the partograph based on the number of contractions palpated in 10 minutes and the duration of each contraction. The partograph has to be updated every 30 minutes. 

Uterine contractions are felt as intermittent pain per abdomen. They are associated with the hardening of the uterus. At first, they are not strong enough to cause discomfort and come at an interval of 15-30 minutes lasting 30 seconds. As labor progresses, the interval shortens. 

True labor pains are characterized by painful contractions at regular intervals, increasing frequency, intensity, and duration of contractions, association with 'show', progressive effacement and dilation of the cervix, the descent of the presenting part, formation of 'bag of forewaters' and not relieved by enema or sedatives. 

They have to be differentiated from false labor pains which are dull in nature, confined to lower abdomen and groin, not associated with hardening of the uterus, relieved by enema or sedative.

Braxton-Hicks contractions are painless, irregular, and do not affect the cervix. 

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presented to you during your rural posting as a part of a routine checkup camp to show the lesions as below. The red papular lesions do not cause him any discomfort and have been present for 6 months. His spot blood sugar is 300mg/dl. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given maculopapular lesions on the shins along with uncontrolled blood sugar point towards a diagnosis of diabetic dermopathy.

Diabetic dermopathy:

  • It presents as asymptomatic, oval, dull‐red papules 0.5–1 cm in diameter that evolve slowly on the shins, forearms, thighs, and over bony prominences, producing a superficial scale and, ultimately, atrophic brown scars.
  • Binkley's spots or diabetic shin spots is another name for diabetic dermopathy. The phrase diabetic dermopathy was coined by Binkley in 1965.
  • Pathologically, there is hyperpigmentation of the epidermal basal layer, deposition of haemosiderin and melanin in the dermis, and arteriolar basement membrane thickening.
  • Diabetic dermopathy is common and is a marker for complications of diabetes such as retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy.

Other Options:

Option A: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare chronic and granulomatous skin disorder that is seen in diabetic patients. The most likely etiology is microangiopathy. Most rashes are located on the legs, especially above the tibiae. The patches are initially brown and later may progress to yellow atrophic plaques.

Option C: Granuloma annulare is most commonly found in children and females <30 years. It manifests as groups of 1-2mm papules that range from skin-colored to violaceous, in an annular arrangement over distal extremities. There is no confirmed association with diabetes.

Below image shows granuloma annulare:

Option D: Furuncle/ boil is caused by Staphylococcus. It is painful and usually situated in the neck area. It is pustular and later becomes necrotic and forms a scar.

questions.text:
In a village with 200 eligible couples, family planning data of contraceptive methods is as follows:

Vasectomy – 30 Tubectomy – 30 IUD users – 12 Oral pill users – 30 Condom users – 18

What is the couple protection rate in the village?
questions.solution:
Couple protection rate (CPR) is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

In this scenario, a total of 120 couples out of 200 eligible couples are using contraceptive methods.

Therefore, CPR = (120/200) x 100 = 60% 

Eligible couple: It refers to a currently married couple, wherein the wife is at the reproductive age, which is generally assumed to lie between the ages 15 and 45 years.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presented with progressive difficulty in hearing for the past 3 years. An MRI of the brain shows bilateral cerebellopontine angle tumors that are consistent with schwannomas. There is also a family history of gliomas and meningiomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is neurofibromatosis type 2.

Neurofibromatosis type 2 refers to a syndrome characterized by bilateral schwannomas of the eighth cranial nerve, meningiomas, and gliomas. This is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to a mutation in the NF2 gene.

The image below shows bilateral schwannomas seen in a patient with neurofibromatosis type 2.

Other options 

Option A: Neurofibromatosis type 1 presents with gliomas of the optic nerve, hamartomas, and pheochromocytomas. These patients have other features like intellectual disability, Lisch nodules (pigmented nodules of the iris), and cafe au lait spots (hyperpigmented macules on the skin).

Option C: Sturge-Weber syndrome presents with port-wine stain lesions of the skin in the area supplied by the trigeminal nerve. They might also have venous angiomas and intellectual disabilities.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis presents with hamartomas and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. Hamartomas appear as cortical tubers and subependymal nodules. This is associated with various cutaneous manifestations like angiofibromas, shagreen patches (localized leathery thickenings), ash-leaf patches (hypopigmented areas), and subungual fibromas.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented with complaints of abdominal discomfort and dark-coloured stools for the past 2 months. Investigations revealed microcytic hypochromic anemia. A barium swallow radiograph revealed a leather bottle appearance on the stomach. Histopathological examination showed diffuse infiltration of the stomach wall and cells with a signet ring appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario with leather bottle appearance of the stomach in barium swallow and the signet ring cells in histopathology, the most likely diagnosis is diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumour and comprises more than 90% of all stomach malignancies.

Patients with gastric cancer present with unexplained weight loss, abdominal discomfort, upper GI bleeding (hematemesis and melena), anemia, early satiety and anorexia. Based on the gross appearance, it is classified into two types:

  • Diffuse: characterized by gastric wall thickening due to infiltrates
  • Intestinal: associated with malignant masses composed of glandular structures

Diffuse adenocarcinoma is characterised by a diffuse infiltrative growth pattern leading to the thickened stomach wall with diffuse rugal flattening. Barium studies reveal a leather bottle appearance as shown in the image below, also known as linitis plastica.

Most gastric cancers do not follow any pattern of hereditary inheritance. However, loss-of-function mutation of the CDH-1 gene results in the loss of E-cadherin which plays a vital role in the pathogenesis of diffuse gastric cancer. Mutation of TP53 is found in a majority of sporadic gastric cancers of both diffuse and intestinal types.

Histopathology shows diffuse infiltration of the gastric wall with signet ring-shaped cells. The cells are so named because intracellular mucin displaces the nuclei to the periphery of the tumour cells. 

The below H&E-stained image shows normal gastric mucosa (red arrow) and the characteristic signet cells (green arrows) in a patient with diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

The most effective predictors of the prognosis of gastric cancer are the depth of tumour invasion and metastasis.

Surgical resection and lymph node clearance is the mainstay treatment in early gastric cancers. When there is local invasion into the duodenum, pancreas, and retroperitoneum, treatment is focused on chemotherapy, radiotherapy and palliative care.

Other options:

Menetrier's disease is a hypertrophic gastropathy characterized by massive overgrowth of mucous cells (foveolar cells) lining the stomach, resulting in large gastric folds with antral sparing. It is associated with hypoproteinemia, weight loss and diarrhoea and an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

Gastric leiomyosarcoma is a type of mesenchymal tumour commonly grouped under GIST(gastrointestinal stromal tumour) and is named according to its resemblance with smooth muscle tumours and usually positive for CD117(c-kit) in immunohistochemistry. The patients present with mucosal bleeding, anaemia and mass effects.

Gastric lymphomas are extranodal B cell lymphomas arising in cases of chronic gastritis and are positive for CD19, CD20 and CD43. Patients present with upper GI bleeding and dyspepsia due to H.pylori infection.

questions.text: A 7-month-old male baby is brought to the emergency room with a history of recurrent lung infections. Further assessment reveals that though his cellular immunity is normal, there is negligible circulating IgG. His brother had the same disease and he died as a result of viral encephalitis but the IgG levels in both his parents and his sister are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of recurrent lung infections, the same disease in another male sibling and the presence of negligible IgG in presence of normal cellular immunity are suggestive of Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

The congenital disorder Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia occurs in male infants at 5 to 8 months of age, the period during which maternal immunoglobulins are depleted. It is caused by mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase located on the long arm of the X chromosome, called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk)  which is the gene that encodes an enzyme critical to B-lymphocyte maturation). The patient(usually an infant) suffers from recurrent pyogenic infections associated with severe hypogammaglobulinemia and there is an absence of mature B cells in peripheral blood and plasma cells in the lymphoid tissues. 

The classic form of this disease has the following characteristics:

  • B-cells are absent or markedly decreased
  • Serum levels of all classes of immunoglobulins are decreased
  • Plasma cells are absent
  • Germinal centres of lymphoid organs are underdeveloped.

It is treated using replacement therapy with immunoglobulins.

Other options:

Option A: DiGeorge syndrome is a developmental disorder resulting in failure of development of the thymus gland and there is an absence of cell-mediated immunity.

Option B: Selective immunoglobulin A deficiency is commonly asymptomatic and symptomatic patients commonly present with diarrhoea and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. In addition, patients also have extremely low levels of both serum and secretory IgA.

Option C: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is also an X-linked genetic disease but is characterized by defects in both humoral and cellular immunity.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about chemoradiotherapy (CRT) except:

choices.text: Radiotherapy component also acts as radio-sensitizing agent
Chemotherapy mainly helps in reducing distant metastases
Radiotherapy mainly results in disease control locally

questions.solution:
Chemotherapy component of the CRT acts as radio-sensitizing agent.

Chemoradiotherapy (CRT) is the combination of chemotherapy with radiotherapy.

  • CRT can be of two types: concurrent, where both chemotherapy and radiotherapy are given simultaneously; or sequential, where they are given one after the other.
  • The chemotherapy component acts as the radio-sensitizing agent.
  • In various cancers, chemoradiotherapy has shown to be effective as neoadjuvant therapy before the surgery.
  • The radiotherapy mainly results in the local disease control, while the chemotherapy component, mainly helps in reducing the chances of distant metastases.

questions.text: A patient with hematemesis was evaluated and his liver biopsy revealed hepatic fibrosis progressing towards the cirrhosis stage. Which of the following cells is responsible for the development of hepatic fibrosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hepatic stellate cells (Ito cells) take part in the development of hepatic fibrosis.

Hepatic stellate cells (Ito cells) are present in the space of Disse and store vitamin A. They are mesenchymal in origin. These cells have 2 states:

Dormant state:

  • Ito cells are in a dormant state for majority of the duration. 
  • They store the fat-soluble vitamin A in their lipid droplets and are a signiﬁcant source of growth factors involved in liver homeostasis and regeneration.

Active state:

  • Ito cells get activated as a result of liver injury and replace damaged hepatocytes with collagenous scar tissue leading to hepatic ﬁbrosis.
  • They secrete intralobular matrix components, including collagen type III (reticular) ﬁbres.

Other options:

The endothelial cells are typically flat cells, each with a central nucleus, and they are joined to each other by junctional complexes. Their cytoplasm contains numerous transcytotic vesicles.

Kupffer cells are hepatic macrophages, which are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defence.

Hepatic stem cells are undifferentiated, pluripotential cells and are understood to reside around the canals of Hering.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient reports to the emergency room with fever and cough for 2 days. The real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) test for COVID-19 is found to be positive. The respiratory rate is 18/min, Heart rate is 90/min, and oxygen saturation of haemoglobin is 96% on room air. The chest x-ray is normal. As per the National Institutes of Health COVID-19 Treatment Guidelines, which of the following is recommended?

choices.text: Remdesivir 200mg IV on day 1 and then 100mg daily for 4 days
Dexamethasone 6mg PO or IV for 10 days
Both Remdesivir and Dexamethasone at above doses
No specific antiviral or immunomodulatory therapy recommended

questions.solution:
The above patient has a mild illness and therefore no specific antiviral or steroid therapy is recommended. As per the NIH guidelines, the patients of COVID-19 who are not hospitalized or who are Hospitalized but do not require supplemental oxygen, the Panel does not recommend any specific antiviral or immunomodulatory therapy for the treatment.

The patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection can be grouped into the following categories as per increasing severity of illness.

  • Asymptomatic or Presymptomatic: Asymptomatic with positive virologic test
  • Mild Illness: Positive history of any of the following symptoms (e.g., fever, cough, sore throat, malaise, headache, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of taste and smell) but there is no shortness of breath, difficulty in breathing, or abnormal chest imaging.
  • Moderate Illness: Individuals with positive evidence of lower respiratory disease during clinical examination or imaging. They have hemoglobin saturation of oxygen (SpO2) ≥94% on room air at sea level.
  • Severe Illness: Individuals who have SpO2 < 94% on room air at sea level, respiratory rate of >30 breaths/min, PaO2 /FiO2 <300mm Hg, and lung infiltrates >50%.
  • Critical Illness: Individuals who have respiratory failure, septic shock, and/or multiple organ dysfunction.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in her 27th week of gestation is suspected to have gestational diabetes mellitus. Which of the following tests can be done to arrive at the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The glucose tolerance test is considered as the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus.

Diagnostic criteria with 75 g are as follows:

  • Fasting: 92 mg/dl 
  • 1hour: 180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hr: 153 mg/dl

Note: Earlier, a two-step approach was being used to diagnose GDM. In this, the first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). The patients having a positive result for this test were then subject to the second step, a 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT), which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus. This has now been replaced by the one-step approach that omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used in Ilizarov ring fixator.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Kirschner wire (K-wire).

Kirschner wire or K-wire has multiple uses. Insertion is stress-free, associated with less soft tissue damage, and allows for early exercises after removal. The diameter of the K-wire is 1 to 3 mm. The wire is pointed at both ends for both antegrade and retrograde insertion. The shape of the tips could be trocar or diamond or threaded.

Uses of K-wire:

  • To fix fractures in children
  • To give traction e.g. for olecranon fracture
  • To fix small bone fractures
  • In llizarov ring fixator

Other options:

Steinman pin - It is a stout, straight steel rod used to provide skeletal traction. Its diameter ranges from 3 to 6 mm. The common sites where it is used include the upper end of the tibia, supracondylar region of the femur, and the calcaneum. 

Cortical screw: They are threaded throughout the entire length and function as a positional screw or a lag screw for interfragmentary compression.

Cancellous screw - It has larger threads and therefore has more purchase in soft cancellous bones. 

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: In patients with which of the following type of choledochal cyst, would you advise endoscopic sphincterotomy?
questions.solution:
A type III choledochal cyst is the cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles. Patients with type III choledochal cyst are managed with endoscopic sphincterotomy. 

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the extrahepatic and/or intrahepatic biliary tree. Females are more commonly affected than males. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain.

Diagnosis is confirmed using ultrasound abdomen but ERCP or MRCP is required to analyze the anatomy of the cyst, classify the type, and plan the surgical procedure accordingly. 

Choledochal cysts are classified according to the Todani Classification, and the management for each type is summarized in the table below:

Type of choledochal cyst  Management

Type I 

 
  • Excision of the cyst with cholecystectomy
  • Reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

Type II
  • Excision of the diverticulum with cholecystectomy
  • Suturing of the CBD wall
  • Reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy can be done

Type III (choledochocele)
  • Endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is preferred
  • Cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy can be done

Type IV
  • Extrahepatic- cyst excision and Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure)
  • Intrahepatic- segmental resection of the liver by hepatectomy
  • Lily’s operation- if the cyst is adherent to the portal vein posteriorly, that part of cyst wall is left behind but mucosa of the part is removed
  • Definitive- liver transplantation

Type V (Caroli disease)
  • Liver transplantation

questions.text: Which of the following is correct with respect to decreasing order of oxygen required for growth?
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the organisms in descending order of oxygen requirement for growth is Mycobacterium TB > Mycobacterium bovis > Clostridium, which are obligatory aerobes, microaerophilic, and anaerobes, respectively.

Depending on the influence of oxygen on growth and viability, bacteria are divided into aerobes and anaerobes. They are further divided as;

  • Obligate aerobes will grow only in the presence of oxygen. They obtain their energy and intermediates only through oxidation, using oxygen as the ultimate hydrogen acceptor. This process of conversion of ADP to ATP using oxygen is called oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Facultative anaerobes are ordinarily aerobic but can also grow in the absence of oxygen, though less abundantly. Most bacteria of medical importance are facultative anaerobes.
  • Anaerobes can grow even in the absence of oxygen. They obtain energy by the process of fermentation and substrate-level phosphorylation.
  • Obligate anaerobes may even die on exposure to oxygen. This is because of the absence of the enzyme catalase, which acts on the toxic metabolite hydrogen peroxide formed in the presence of oxygen. Another reason is that they possess essential enzymes that are active only in the reduced state.
  • Microaerophilic bacteria grow best in the presence of low oxygen tension.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman was found dead at a cafe around midnight. Her face was congested with marked petechiae and her tongue was protruded and swollen. On examination, signs of struggle and a pale transverse mark completely encircling her neck below the thyroid cartilage were noted. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and examination findings of a pale transverse mark completely encircling her neck below the thyroid cartilage with signs of struggle point toward a diagnosis of strangulation by ligature.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument.

When strangulation is done by using a ligature like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark which is transverse and completely encircling the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth.

Other options:

Option A: In a cafe coronary syndrome, the victim is usually healthy but grossly intoxicated and dies suddenly and unexpectedly during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or of asphyxia. The autopsy reveals a bolus of food lodged in the pharynx or larynx. The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition.

Option B: Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impression and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck. It is characterized by autopsy findings showing carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma with nail marks on the neck and absence of ligature marks.

Option D: Mugging is a method of strangulation wherein the neck of the victim is caught in the bend of the assailant's elbow as shown below. Pressure is usually applied either in front of the larynx or at one or both sides of the neck.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality shown below:
questions.solution:
The imaging modality shown is called diffusion tensor imaging (DTI).

Diffusion tensor imaging is a variation of diffusion-weighted imaging, where the diffusion of the fluid, is assessed in six or more directions. The technique is based on the principle that the diffusion in the brain is directionally dependent (anisotropic), which is more in the compacted white matter tracts, and least evident in grey matter.

The technique is used for mapping of the white matter tracts and hence is useful in evaluating the connectivity between various brain regions, and identifying any disease process that affects it.

The image below shows diffusion tensor tractography:

Arcuate fasciculus (AF), the superior longitudinal fasciculus (SLF), the inferior longitudinal fasciculus (ILF), the uncinate fasciculus (UF), and inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus (IFOF). (Arrows at bottom right. A: Anterior, L: Lateral).

Other options:

  • Option a: Dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI refers to the serial MRI acquisitions following IV contrast agent.
  • Option b: Dynamic susceptibility contrast MRI measures induced alterations in the transverse relaxation times (T2 and T2*). This results in signal loss causing transient darkening of the tissues.
  • Option d: Functional magnetic resonance imaging detects changes in the regional cerebral blood flow during various brain activities. It is used to study the eloquent cortical activation.

Related Pearl: Investigation of choice in Neurology

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

Conditions in which MRI is used include:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Vestibular schwannoma
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Spinal cord tumor
  • Neurofibroma
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Hippocampal volumetry.

CT scan is preferred when the timing is critical. So, the investigation of choice for stroke is an NCCT. This helps to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman who had previous recurrent abortions was found to have APLA (antiphospholipid antibody) syndrome. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
In pregnancy, low-molecular-weight heparin (5000 units S/C twice daily) with low dose aspirin (50 mg daily) up to 34 weeks is the most efficacious regimen for APLA.

Aspirin in doses of 60-80mg blocks conversion of arachidonic acid to thromboxane A2 while sparing prostacyclin production. Heparin therapy prevents thrombosis in the microcirculation including decidual trophoblastic interface. 

Warfarin is not used due to its potential teratogenic effects.

The most common congenital defect due to warfarin in APLA mothers is Craniofacial anomaly and most characteristic is Chondrodysplasia punctata.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with acute severe chest pain and shortness of breath. An emergency cardiac catheterization showed occlusion of the anterior descending branch of the left coronary artery. Laboratory reports and ECG support the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction. Which of the following is the most likely pathological change in the heart muscle after 6 weeks?
questions.solution:
The most likely pathological change in the heart muscle after 6 weeks is a collagen-rich scar. It usually develops 2-8 weeks after myocardial infarction (MI).

The gross and microscopic appearance of the myocardial infarct depends on the duration of survival of the patient following the ischemic injury. Areas of damage undergo a progressive sequence of changes. These include ischemic coagulative necrosis, inflammation, and finally repair with fibrosis. 12 to 24 hours after the MI, it appears reddish-blue due to congestion and extravasated blood.

The sequence of microscopic findings in acute myocardial infarction include:

  • 1-3 days after the occlusion: 
    • Gross: Yellowish-tan infarct center with mottling
    • Microscopic: Signs of coagulative necrosis with nuclear pyknosis, myocyte hypereosinophilia, and marginal contraction band necrosis. It is followed by the loss of nuclei and striations. Myocyte vacuolization is seen at the margins which indicate that the myocytes are viable but poorly contractile.
  • 3-7 days:
    • Gross: Yellowish-tan center softens, and borders become hyperemic
    • Microscopic: Polymorphonuclear leukocytes and macrophages are seen, with the disintegration of dead myofibers, and neutrophils. Phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border.
  • 7-14 days:
    • Gross: Maximal softening of yellowish-tan area, margins are depressed and reddish-tan to reddish-gray
    • Microscopic: Capillary-rich granulation tissue at the margins, collagen deposition, further phagocytosis of dead material
  • 2- 8 weeks:
    • Gross: Greyish white scar
    • Microscopic: Replacement of the necrotic myocardium with collagen-rich scar tissue from the border to the infarct core. The scar is well developed by the end of the sixth week.

Left anterior descending coronary artery is involved in 40% to 50% cases. The infarct involves the anterior wall of left ventricle near the apex, the anterior portion of ventricular septum and the apex circumferentially.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male underwent an orthopantomogram as a part of a general dental check-up. All of the following statements are true regarding the finding marked with the arrow in the orthopantomogram except?
questions.solution:
The finding marked with the arrow in the orthopantomogram is called the Stafne bone cyst. It is more common in males.

Stafne bone cyst:

It is the most common type of ectopic salivary tissue. It presents as an asymptomatic, clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion at the angle of the mandible, characteristically below the inferior dental neurovascular bundle.

Malignant transformation of this ectopic salivary tissue is possible but rare. Therefore reassurance and periodic radiographic observation is required.

questions.text: According to sigmund freud in the interpretation of dreams, which of the following terms refers to the representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected with the idea or object being represented?
questions.solution:
Symbolism refers to the representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected with the idea or object being represented.

According to the Interpretation of dreams written by sigmund freud, dreams represent unconscious wishes or thoughts which are not accepted by the conscious mind. They manifest through the following mechanisms:

  • Symbolism: Representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected. 
  • Displacement: Transfer of mental energy from one object to a substitute or symbolic representation of the object. 
  • Condensation: Mechanism by which multiple unconscious wishes combine into a single image. Converse to it is called irradiation or diffusion, where, one unconscious wish gets distributed into multiple images. 
  • Projection: Attributing one’s own unacknowledged feelings to others. 
  • Secondary elaboration: Process by which the ego organizes illogical, bizarre and absurd images into a more coherent form in dreams. 

 

Related Pearl: Contributions by Sigmund Freud

Contributions of Sigmund Freud to the field of psychiatry

  • Free association
  • Interpretation of dreams
  • Psychoanalysis
  • Psycho-sexual development 
  • Psychodynamic theory 
  • Topographic theory of the mind-unconscious, preconscious, conscious
  • Structural theory of mind- id, ego, superego
  • Cocaine in psychiatry

questions.text: An ENT resident uses the following instrument to examine the patient in OPD. The resident could see all of the following structures except _______
questions.solution:
The image shows posterior rhinoscopy mirror. Posterior ends of nasal turbinates are seen with this instrument (not the anterior ends).

St. Clair Thompson mirror is the other name for Posterior rhinoscopy Mirror. It has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.

The structures seen in posterior rhinoscopy are:

  • Adenoids
  • Posterior ends of nasal turbinates
  • Opening of the eustachian tube
  • The posterior border of the nasal septum
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller
  • Torus tubarius
  • The upper surface of the soft palate

Note : Laryngeal Mirror is straight without any bends with a mirror at end.

questions.text: All of the following transport mechanisms are rate limited by an intrinsic Vmax, except:
questions.solution:
Simple diffusion is not mediated by carrier, and hence, the rate of simple diffusion shows a linear relationship with increase in concentration of the substance, and there is no intrinsic maximum velocity (Vmax).

In contrast, the rate of transport in carrier mediated mechanisms is limited by the number of carrier proteins available. Once all the carrier proteins are saturated, the transport reaches a maximum velocity (Vmax), and further increase in concentration of the substance, will not result in an increase in the rate of transport.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common morbidly adherent placenta encountered in clinical practice?
questions.solution:
Placenta accreta is the most common morbidly adherent placenta encountered in clinical practice. 

Placenta accreta, increta and percreta, these variants are encountered during clinical practice are in an approximate ratio of 80:15:5, respectively.

Placenta accreta is described as abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta. It is due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer.  

Nitabuch layer is a layer of fibrin between the compact endometrium and the cytotrophoblastic shell in the placenta. This layer is absent in the placenta accreta.

Types of the morbidly adherent placenta:

  • Placenta accreta : Villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta : Villi invade the myometrium. 
  • Placenta percreta : Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with fever, neck rigidity, and disorientation. He had been taking antibiotics by himself for the past 2 weeks as he also had an ear infection. Lab reports showed increased neutrophil counts and raised CRP and procalcitonin. A CSF examination showed turbidity and decreased glucose but turned out to be negative on gram stain microscopy or culture. Which of the following can be done to diagnose the likely cause of meningitis?

choices.text: ZN stain of the CSF fluid

questions.solution:
In this patient with clinical features of meningitis associated with a previous ear infection and raised CRP, the likely etiological agent is Pneumococcus.

In the case of negative CSF microscopy on gram stain(consider the history of antibiotic exposure prior to being evaluated), a Latex agglutination test can be done to detect antigens in CSF or Blood. A newer immunochromatography test can also detect the antigen in CSF. Sometimes culture may be negative due to poor yield of the organism in the sample, a subculture on liquid broth improves the yield, which can then be cultured on solid media.

Other options :

Option b: Antibody testing in serum is generally done to assess for viral causes of meningitis, which is unlikely in this case due to the presence of fever, decreased glucose in CSF which makes bacterial cause more likely.

Option c: Capsule visualisation can be done for if capsulated organisms are suspected. In this case, even though Pneumococcus is a capsulated organism, it needs to be visualised first on microscopy, to confirm the presence of the capsule later.

Option d: ZN stain on CSF fluid would likely be done if tuberculous organisms are suspected. It would, however, present more later and would have lymphocytosis, cobweb coagulum in CSF. Moreover, a history of contact with a TB case or any primary focus of pulmonary TB would be present in the history.

In vitro rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) can be used for detection of pneumococcal antigen in the urine of adult patients with pneumonia and in the CSF of patients of all ages with meningitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is posted for a hysterosalpingogram, but she is now in the premenstrual phase. All of the following are noted risks associated with hysterosalpingogram done during the premenstrual period except?

choices.text: If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it can dislodge

questions.solution:
All the options are risks associated with a hysterosalpingogram done in the premenstrual period except tubal block. In fact, HSG is done to detect it.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a technique used for visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes by the injection of a radioopaque dye, and visualization of the dye by fluoroscopy as it passes through the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

It is best performed between the end of the menstrual period and ovulation (i.e 9th or 10th day of the cycle).

10-15ml of the dye is injected using a Leech-Wilkinson cannula, Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter. If the tubes are patent, the dye will spill out of the tubal Ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

It is used to detect:

  • Tubal block. This can be due to strictures (fibrotic block), inspissated amorphous material, or spasms. The tubal spasm can occur in an apprehensive woman and this is prevented by premedication with atropine and analgesia.
  • Uterine anomalies
  • Uterine polyps
  • Uterine synechiae
  • The feasibility of tuboplasty, by studying the location and extent of tubal pathology.

Contraindications:

  • Presence of genital tract infection and bleeding
  • Genital tuberculosis, due to the risk of spreading infection.
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Allergy to the dye
  • Premenstrual phase.
    • If by chance pregnancy has occurred, it may be dislodged.
    • Thick endometrium might prevent the smooth flow of the dye, at the cornual end.
    • There is a risk of embolism and endometriosis if HSG is done during this phase.

Note: Tubal spasms can occur in any phase of the menstrual cycle, including the premenstrual phase. But, the other options are more common in the premenstrual phase as compared to tubal spasm mimicking a tubal block.

The instrument in the given image below is Rubin's cannula and is used in hysterosalpingogram recording.

The instrument in the given image is Leech-Wilkinson canula and is used in hysterosalpingogram recording.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman came to the OPD with complaints of increased thirst, polyuria, and nocturia for the past 2 months. She was drinking about 5 to 6 litres of water per day. Fasting and random plasma glucose are 72 mg/dL and 124 mg/dL respectively. The urine osmolality was initially low, which then increased after the water-deprivation test. On unrestricted fluid intake, the urine volume was 50 mL/Kg/24hrs, and urine osmolarity 240 mosm/L. Which of the following is the next best step in the evaluation of the patient?
questions.solution:
The next step is to assess basal plasma arginine vasopressin (AVP).

Increased urine osmolality after water deprivation test may indicate psychogenic polydipsia / partial central DI / partial nephrogenic DI.

These conditions can be differentiation by assessment of 24-hour urinary volume and osmolarity on unrestricted fluid intake:

  • If the 24-hour urine volume is > 40mL/Kg and osmolarity is <300 mosm/L, the next step is to evaluate the basal plasma AVP. If AVP is normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL), the patient has nephrogenic DI.
  • However, if plasma AVP is low (<1 pg/mL), the patient has either pituitary DI or primary polydipsia. In such a case, a brain MRI is done to determine the presence/absence of a pituitary bright spot on T1-weighted midsaggital images. If the pituitary bright spot is present, then it indicates primary polydipsia. If it is absent, it indicates pituitary diabetes insipidus.

In case genitourinary abnormalities, the 24-hour urine volume is < 40mL/Kg and osmolarity is >300 mosm/L.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality.
