Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

questions.text: A male infant with a history of not passing meconium was referred to you. On examination, abdominal distension was noted. The findings of barium enema are shown below. You can manage this case surgically by all of the following surgical procedures, except ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium enema showing a dilated right colon, with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon, are together suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. All the above procedures are used in the surgical management of this case, except Bianchi procedure, which is an intestinal lengthening procedure used in short bowel syndrome. 

Hirschsprung disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious vomiting. There is a failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The imaging method of choice for diagnosis of Hirschprung disease is a contrast enema. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is a rectal biopsy. The biopsy specimen shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing: This method is now being widely used and is considered superior to acetylcholinesterase staining in confirming the diagnosis.

Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum; then, the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of ingestion of one uncrushed seed similar to that shown in the image below. He is asymptomatic at presentation. Which of the following can be anticipated in this case?
questions.solution:
The image shows seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica. No poisonous action is anticipated.

If swallowed uncrushed, the seeds of nux vomica have no poisonous action, as they are not dissolved in the gastrointestinal tract and are passed entirely in the feces.

Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postganglionic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to increased activity in the motor neurons. 

The fatal dose is 15-30 mg of strychnine or one crushed seed. When crushed seeds are ingested, the symptoms are delayed for an hour or more.

Convulsions are produced as the reflex centers of the spinal cord are directly affected. The convulsions are first clonic but eventually become tonic.  Risus sardonicus results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back. The convulsions are most marked in anti-gravity muscles so that the body typically arches in hyperextension, the posture known as opisthotonos. If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos), or to the side (pleurosthotonos). If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, as in strychnine poisoning, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

Related Pearl: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

  • Convulsions - clonic-tonic type
  • Reflex increased
  • Awful taste
  • Mind is conscious
  • Pupils dilated
  • Opisthotonos: arching back
  • Emprosthotonos: arching forward
  • Pleurothotonus: bending sideward
  • Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

questions.text: Histological image of the cerebellum is given below. What is false about the cells marked in the given image?

choices.text: These cells are arranged in a layer between the molecular and granular layers
They are the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex
These cells are inhibitory in nature

questions.solution:
The cells marked in the above histological image are Purkinje cells and they use γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) as their neurotransmitter.

Characteristics of Purkinje cells:

  • Purkinje cells are the flask-shaped cells present in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum.
  • The cells are evenly spaced and are arranged in a single layer.
  • A dendrite arises from the neck of each flask-shaped cell, which passes upward to enter the molecular layer, which then branches extensively to form a dendritic tree.
  • The axon of each cell passes downwards, crosses the granular cell layer to enter the white matter.
  • Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex.
  • The initial segment of the axon receives synaptic contacts from basket cell axons.
  • The main axon terminates in one of the cerebellar or vestibular nuclei.
  • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.

Pathological significance:

  • Negri bodies in rabies, are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells.
  • Loss of Purkinje cells and granule cells is seen in ataxia-telangiectasia.
  • In patients with subacute cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells. Some patients show circulating the PCA­1 antibody (anti­Yo) against Purkinje cells.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department after a nervous breakdown. He says that he got divorced about a week ago, and has been feeling depressed since then. He has also started hearing voices for the past few days, saying he is useless and telling him to kill himself. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A brief psychotic disorder is the best answer in this scenario, as the symptoms are present for less than 30 days.

The diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder in DSM-5 is based on the presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms for a period of at least 1 day but less than 1 month:

  • Delusions
  • Hallucinations
  • Thought disorder as evidenced by disorganized speech
  • Disorganized or catatonic behavior.

DSM-5 specifies that one of the first three symptoms must be present for the diagnosis to be made.

Other options: 

Option D: Major Depressive Disorder is diagnosed by the presence of depressive symptoms for at least two weeks, including persistent feelings of sadness, anhedonia, changes in appetite or weight, sleep disturbances, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, difficulty concentrating, and thoughts of death or suicide. Patients experiencing a major depressive episode may exhibit delusions and hallucinations, which is known as psychotic depression. These delusions and hallucinations are usually mood-congruent and often revolve around themes of guilt and self-deprecation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented with horizontal diplopia, nystagmus, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy. The patient subsequently succumbed to Pneumonia. Brain autopsy shows evidence of cerebral atrophy, cerebellar degeneration, and optic neuropathy. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency is common in chronic alcoholics and causes Wernicke-korsakoff syndrome. It is characterized clinically by the rapid onset of a disturbance in thermal regulation, altered consciousness, ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, and ataxia and pathologically by lesions in the hypothalamus and mamillary bodies, the periaqueductal regions of the midbrain, and the tegmentum of the pons.

Atrophy of the superior portion of cerebellar vermis also occurs. The syndrome arises most commonly in association with chronic alcoholism. The wernicke-korsakoff syndrome may progress rapidly to death but is reversed by the administration of thiamine.

Other options:

  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive motor neuron disease that occurs due to loss of UMN in the cerebral cortex and LMN in the spinal cord and brainstem.
  • Hepatic encephalopathy may occur several days to months after an acute liver injury. The neurological signs include rigidity, hyperreflexia, and asterixis. Nonrhythmic, rapid extension-flexion movements of the head and extremities. The patients may have disturbance in consciousness, ranging from subtle behavioural abnormalities to marked confusion and stupor, to deep coma and death.
  • Hepatorenal syndrome refers to renal failure occurring in individuals with liver failure in whom there is no intrinsic morphologic or functional cause for kidney dysfunction. It is associated a drop in urine output and increasing levels of urea and creatinine in the blood.

questions.text: The afferent nerve endings for the Hering-Breuer reflex are the mechanoreceptors that are located in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The Hering-Breuer reflex mechanoreceptors are located in the bronchi and bronchioles and respond to increased stretch to limit respiration.

Hering-Breuer reflex is stimulated in response to the inflation of the lungs and protects the lungs from hyper-inflation, by switching off the inspiratory ramp, and stopping further inspiration.

The afferent nerve endings of the Hering-Breuer reflex are the slow-adapting pulmonary stretch receptors present in the smooth muscles of the bronchi and bronchioles. The receptors are activated in response to the distention of the lungs.

The impulse travels in vagus nerve via the large myelinated fibres into the dorsal respiratory group of neurons. The response is similar to the activation of pneumotaxic center, and causes cessation of the inspiratory ramp, thus stopping further inspiration. The reflex also increases the rate of inspiration.

Hering-Breuer reflex is usually activated when the tidal volume reaches or exceeds three times the normal tidal volume (≥ 1500 mL/breath). Hence, the reflex is mainly involved in the protection from excessive inflation than in normal control of ventilation.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male with seizure disorder was hospitalized due to a recent exacerbation of seizure episode, for which he was prescribed lacosamide as adjunctive therapy. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
Lacosamide blocks the voltage-gated sodium channels.

Lacosamide is a stereoselective enantiomer of the amino acid, l-serine. It is used as adjunctive therapy for focal-onset seizures in patients older than 17 years.

It is the first anti-seizure drug, which prolongs the slow inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels and to limit sustained repetitive firing, the neuronal firing pattern characteristic of focal seizures. Lacosamide also binds to collapsing response mediator protein-2 (CRMP-2), which is a phosphoprotein mainly expressed in the nervous system and involved in neuronal differentiation and control of axonal outgrowth.

The role of CRMP-2 binding in seizure control is unknown.

Therapeutic Uses:

  • It is used for both monotherapy and add-on therapy for focal-onset seizures in patients 17 years and older.
  • It is mostly beneficial in hospitalized patients because it is available in an intravenous formulation, has minimal hepatic metabolism, and has no adverse respiratory effects.

questions.text: Which of the following enables antibodies to recognize a diverse group of three-dimensional antigen structures?
questions.solution:
Junctional diversity enables antibodies to recognize three-dimensional antigen structures.

When light and heavy chain genes are transcribed, a few variable nucleotides are introduced in between, which gives rise to junctional diversity. It enables the immunoglobulins to recognize a wide variety of carbohydrates, lipids and proteins in 3D space.

Other options:

Somatic hypermutation results in increasing the affinity of antibodies to antigens by adding of nucleotides in V gene regions of heavy and light chains.

VDJ gene recombination: The heavy chain is coded by a number of VDJC gene segments while the light chain is coded by VJC gene segments. Each of the final antibodies receives product from one of the gene segments in both heavy (i.e., one from V1, V2-V45, one from D1, D2-D23, one from J1, J2-J6 and one from Cμ-Cα) and light chains (one from V1, V2-V45, one from D1, D2-D23 and Cκ). Thus the combination of these VDJ genes provides a wide range of possible antibodies. 

Class switching refers to the change of antibody type from IgM (which is always the first to be produced) to any of IgG,IgA,IgE,IgD etc. It is done by changing the constant region of antibody but keeping same variable region. It is done so because different immunoglobulin class has different functions.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with headache, fatigue, malar rash, and arthralgia. Her blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg. Urinalysis revealed hematuria, proteinuria (4 g/dL), and RBC casts. She has high titers of anti-dsDNA antibodies. A renal biopsy was done, and light microscopy showed sub-endothelial deposits, resembling wire-loop lesions. Findings of immunofluorescence staining are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Hemodialysis and maintenance therapy with azathioprine
Therapeutic plasma exchange and high-dose steroids
Low-dose steroids and azathioprine for 3-6 months
High-dose steroids and mycophenolate mofetil for 2-6 months

questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigation findings are diagnostic of lupus nephritis. The image shows a characteristic full-house pattern of positive staining for all immune reactants. The next best step in the management is to induce remission by administering high-dose steroids, in combination with mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide for 2-6 months. 

This is followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of steroids and mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine. (Option C)

Evaluating the clinical case given in the question:

  • The presence of malar rash and arthralgia is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Urinalysis shows hematuria (>5 RBCs/HPF), and nephrotic range proteinuria (>3.5 g/dL), RBC casts. These findings, along with the presence of high titers of anti-dsDNA antibodies, are indicative of lupus nephritis.
  • Light microscopic examination of the renal biopsy revealed characteristic 'wire-loop' lesions, which are seen due to sub-endothelial immune complex deposition. The presence of wire-loop lesions is suggestive of diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis (class IV).
  • Further, immunofluorescence staining, as shown in the image, revealed positive staining for all immune reactants (IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, kappa, and lambda light chain), commonly known as the "full-house" effect, characteristic of lupus nephritis.

Lupus nephritis:

Lupus nephritis is a serious complication of SLE and is seen in about 30-50% of patients with the disease. Renal involvement may be in the form of glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis. Glomerular lesions develop due to the deposition of the circulating immune complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, and/or throughout the glomerulus.

Depending on the biopsy findings, lupus nephritis is classified into six classes. The details of the classification by the international society of nephrology are provided in the pearl attached below. 

Therapeutic plasma exchange (Option B):

  • It is indicated in patients with severe lupus nephritis who do not respond to conventional therapy.
  • It is also indicated in patients with lupus nephritis who present with anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome.

20% of patients with lupus nephritis will reach end-stage disease and may require dialysis (Option A) or transplantation. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

  • Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli
  • Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus

questions.text: A 15-year old patient was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following presenting features would categorize him to be in the 'A' category of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Hodgkin's lymphoma is classified into A and B categories, A is used to identify asymptomatic patients and B is for patients who exhibit any B symptoms. 

The patient commonly presents with palpable, firm, rubbery, non-tender lymphadenopathy in the cervical or supraclavicular region. Systemic symptoms that are classified as B symptoms are important in the staging of the disease. Hepatosplenomegaly is rarely detected clinically. 

Ann Arbor Staging of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma:

Stage I

Involvement of a single lymph node (I) or of a single extra-lymphatic organ or site (IE)

Stage II

Involvement of 2 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (II) or localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site and 1 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (IIE)

Stage III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm (III), which may be accompanied by

involvement of the spleen (IIIS) or

by localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site (IIIE) or

both (IIISE)

Stage IV

Diffuse or disseminated involvement of 1 or more

extra-lymphatic organs or tissues with or without

associated lymph node involvement
 

B symptoms

  • The presence of fever >38°C (100.4°F) for 3 consecutive days
  • Drenching night sweats
  • Unexplained loss of >10% of body weight in the 6 months

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl who is a known case of sickle cell anemia presented to the emergency department with severe bone pain. An abdominal CT scan shows evidence of splenic infarcts. Which of the following renal diseases is a direct complication of this patient’s vasoocclusive disease?
questions.solution:
Renal papillary necrosis can occur as a complication of sickle cell disease.

Patients with sickle cell anemia may develop episodic painful crises. The rigidity of sickled erythrocytes results in obstruction of the microcirculation, with subsequent hypoxia and ischemic injury in many organs.

Sickle cell nephropathy is various clinical significant abnormalities due to alterations in renal morphology and function due to sickle cell disease. Hematuria and diminished concentrating ability (hyposthenuria) are the most common abnormalities seen in sickle cell nephropathy. 

It occurs due to the accelerated sickling in the hypertonic hypoxic background of the renal medulla. The hyperosmolarity dehydrates red cells and increases intracellular sickle hemoglobin (HbS) concentrations.  This leads to infarcts in the medulla and papillae and causes renal papillary necrosis. 

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. It occurs when negatively charged glutamine is replaced by a neutral valine at the sixth position of the beta-globin chain. This causes deoxygenated hemoglobin to self-associate into long polymers that sickle the red cell.

Vaso-occlusive crises are episodes of hypoxic injury and infraction that causes severe pain in the affected region in sickle cell anemia. Bones, lungs, liver, brain, spleen, penis are the most commonly affected sites. 

Hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of bones of the hand and feet is a painful bones crisis that occurs in children. It is difficult to distinguish it from acute osteomyelitis. Acute chest syndrome is the vaso-occlusive type of crisis involving the lungs that typically present with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Priapism occurs in less than half of affected males after puberty and leads to hypoxic damage and erectile dysfunction. 

Sequestration crisis occurs in the intact spleen of children. Sickled red cells get entrapped in the spleen which leads to rapid splenomegaly and hypovolemia. Transient cessation of erythropoiesis and sudden worsening of the anemia occurs in aplastic crisis in sickle cell patients with parvovirus B19 infection.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female came with difficulty in hearing in her right ear since childhood. On thorough examination, ossicular discontinuity was found with the absence of handle of malleus and incus. What is the type of defect seen in this patient according to Austin’s classification?
questions.solution:
According to Austin's classification, the patient is having Type C ossicular discontinuity, where the handle of malleus and incus is missing.

This patient requires reconstruction of the tympanic membrane, handle of malleus, and incus.

Austin's classification of anatomical defects in the ossicular chain is based on the presence or absence of handle of malleus (M) and stapes suprastructure (S).

  • Type A: Both handle of malleus and stapes suprastructure are present.
  • Type B: Handle of malleus is present but stapes suprastructure is absent.
  • Type C: Only stapes Suprastructure is present. 
  • Type D: All ossicles are missing.

Note: Incus is absent in all the types and the tympanic membrane repair is required in all the cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient underwent hysterectomy a week ago. Postoperatively she complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On examination, a vesicovaginal fistula is observed. Which technique of fistula repair is suitable in this case?
questions.solution:
The preferred technique of repair of the vesicovaginal fistula which occurred post-hysterectomy is Latzko's procedure.

Latzko's procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges, freshening the edges, and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by a cancer cervix. It can lead to the narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia.

Fistula located at the vaginal vault post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.

In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired vaginally.

The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

Other options:

Option A: Chassar Moir technique widely separated the vagina and bladder all around by the flap-splitting method and suturing the bladder and vagina separately into two. It has the advantage of tension-free sutures and avoidance of the superior position of the bladder over the vaginal suture. 

Option C: Ureteric implantation is considered in cases with extensive loss of bladder tissue, or repetitive failures to close the fistula. Here ureters are implanted into the sigmoid colon creating an ileal loop bladder, or rectal bladder. The disadvantage of this procedure is the high incidence of ascending infection to the kidneys and the risk of electrolyte imbalance.

Option D: Kelly's repair is the anterior colporrhaphy with bladder neck plication done for stress urinary incontinence.

Obstetric causes:

  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Vaginal hysterectomy

  • Laparoscopic surgeries

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • Upper swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swab gets stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding pulmonary alveolar proteinosis?

choices.text: It is 3 times more common in males than females
It is characterized by accumulation of pulmonary surfactant
High resolution-CT scan is the gold standard investigation
It is mediated by neutralizing autoantibodies against GM-CSF

questions.solution:
Histopathological examination of lung biopsy is the gold standard for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis in children, not HR-CT.

PAP is a rare, diffuse lung disease that is characterized by the alveolar and interstitial accumulation of a periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain-positive phospholipoprotein that is derived from surfactant.

Infants and children with PAP present with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, weight loss, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Boys are affected 3 times as often as girls.  

A chest X-ray shows ground-glass opacity and computed tomography (CT) shows a crazy-paving pattern.

Treatment options include total lung lavage, inhaled, or subcutaneous granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF).

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient has the following laboratory findings: pH 7.2, plasma sodium 136 mEq/L, chloride 110 mEq/L, bicarbonate 15 mEq/L, and potassium 2.6 mEq/L. Urine studies show a pH of 5.1. Following the administration of intravenous sodium bicarbonate, the urine pH is 5.8. Which of the following conditions is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
The laboratory findings are most likely suggestive of type II (proximal) renal tubular acidosis.

The arterial blood gas analysis shows normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA).

Interpretation:

Step 1: The pH is 7.2 (<7.35) suggestive of acidosis

Step 2: Plasma bicarbonate is 15 mEq/L indicating metabolic acidosis

Step 3: Assessment of the anion gap:

 Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])

= 136 - (110 + 15)

= 136 - 125

= 11 mEq/L (Normal range: 8-12 mEq/L)

Hence, the laboratory findings are suggestive of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Renal tubular acidosis is one of the common causes of NAGMA. The serum potassium is low (hypokalemia), suggestive of either type I or type II renal tubular acidosis. Type III RTA is rare and is seen mostly in children, while type IV RTA is associated with hyperkalemia.

The urine pH is initially 5.1 (<5.5, acidic), which increased to 5.8 (>5.5) following administration of sodium bicarbonate (alkali therapy), suggestive of poor bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules of the kidney, making the diagnosis of type II (proximal) renal tubular acidosis.

Type II RTA is commonly caused due to generalized proximal tubular dysfunction, associated with Fanconi syndrome (glycosuria, aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia). The bicarbonate is poorly reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule, leading to its increased excretion (bicarbonaturia). This leads to decreased plasma bicarbonate levels and metabolic acidosis.

As the plasma bicarbonate levels fall below the renal threshold for reabsorption of the HCO3- in patients with type II RTA, all the bicarbonate is reabsorbed thus maintaining the urinary pH acidic (<5.5). When sodium bicarbonate is administered intravenously, it increases the plasma bicarbonate levels above the limited renal threshold, leading to increased excretion of HCO3- causing increased urinary pH (> 5.5).

Alkali therapy for correcting plasma bicarbonate in type II RTA should be carried out with caution, as sudden increased availability of HCO3- to the distal tubules stimulates the secretion of potassium, further exaggerating the hypokalemia. Hence, potassium salts are usually administered along with alkali therapy. An oral solution of a combination of sodium and potassium citrate is commonly prescribed alkali therapy for this reason.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of warty cutaneous growth on the foot of the farmer and microscopic finding of sclerotic bodies suggests a diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis.

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera Fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutters and farmers. Clinical features include warty, cutaneous nodules which resemble the florets of a cauliflower, usually confined to feet and lower legs. 

Diagnosis is a histopathological examination of the lesions which show the presence of fungus as round, irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae called sclerotic bodies as shown below.

Treatment:- Relapse is very common in this disease. Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice for small lesions. If surgery is not feasible or for larger lesions chemotherapy with flucytosine or itraconazole is efficacious.

Other options:

Option A -  In sporotrichosis patients present with nodulo-ulcerative lesions which spread proximally along the lymphatics. Microscopy shows asteroid bodies. It can be seen as an oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. 

Option B - Mycetoma is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (Actinomycetes). It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which break down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

The image below shows a mycetoma of the foot:

Option D - Phaeohyphomycosis: It is a chronic fungal infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The lesions may be plaques that are verrucous, hyperkeratotic or ulcerated. The fungi implicated are usually of the class Phialophora or Cladophora or other dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Eisenmenger's syndrome except:

choices.text: It is associated with reversal of left-to-right shunt creating bidirectional or right-to-left shunt
Pregnancy is contraindicated due to a high risk of maternal mortality
Routine phlebotomy is indicated in asymptomatic adults
Pulmonary vasodilators like sildenafil or bosentan are efficacious

questions.solution:
Routine phlebotomy is contraindicated in asymptomatic adults with Eisenmenger's syndrome.

Eisenmenger's syndrome:

  • The condition occurs in adult patients with unrepaired CHD, where, long-standing left-right shunt causes excessive blood flow to the pulmonary vasculature leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance.
  • This eventually leads to the reversal of the left-to-right shunt to bidirectional or right-left shunt.

Medical care:

  • Management includes adequate hydration and prevention or treatment of anemia with iron supplementation therapies.
  • Anticoagulation if indicated, should be given with caution, as it predisposes to bleeding and clinical hemoptysis, which may lead to pulmonary vascular thrombosis.
  • Symptomatic patients with elevated hematocrit above the corresponding degree of cyanosis, are managed with hydration alone. Occasionally, phlebotomy with isovolumic replenishment may be done.
  • Routine phlebotomy is contraindicated in asymptomatic patients.
  • Contraception is indicated for women of child-bearing age group. Estrogen is avoided as it is thrombogenic. Pregnancy is contraindicated in women with ES due to a high risk of maternal mortality.
  • Pulmonary vasodilators such as sildenafil or bosentan are proved to be efficacious in the management of patients with ES.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male was diagnosed with clostridium difficile infection due to a prolonged course of antibiotics for intraabdominal infection following a ruptured diverticular abscess. He was treated with metronidazole, and diarrhea resolved. After 2-weeks he developed loose, non-bloody stools about six times a day. Stool toxin assay was done, which was again positive for C difficile. He was treated with vancomycin for 10 days with a resolution. 10 days later, he presented with relapsed C difficile infection. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Metronidazole 500 mg 3 times daily for 7-10 days
Vancomycin 125 mg 4 times daily for 7-10 days

questions.solution:
This is a case of recurrent clostridium difficile infection, for which Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is recommended. The procedure involves transplantation of stool from a healthy donor, into the patient with the disease by enema or colonoscopy. FMT is increasingly being used to restore a more advantageous gut microbiome profile.

Clostridium difficile infection:

It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • The majority of the cases (>80%) occur in patients above 65 years of age with comorbidities.
  • The onset is insidious and may occur within 1 - 6 weeks after the initiation of antibiotic treatment.
  • The symptoms include lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis.

Investigations:

  • Detection of clostridium toxins A or B in the stool.
  • Stool screening is initially done for the detection of glutamate dehydrogenase enzyme (GDH) produced by C. difficile or PCR to detect C. difficile nucleic acid. If the screening is positive, C. difficile toxin ELISA or tissue culture cytotoxicity is usually performed.
  • Sigmoidoscopy reveals characteristic appearance, with erythema, white plaques, or an adherent pseudomembrane.

Management:

  • If the patient is currently prescribed any antibiotics, they should be stopped, and the patient should be isolated.
  • First-line therapy includes immediate cessation of the offending antibiotic along with a 10-day course of oral fidaxomicin for mild cases. Oral vancomycin can also be used, but oral fidaxomicin is preferred as it has a lesser relapse rate.
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin and or glucocorticoids may be administered in patients with most severe disease or those who are unresponsive to the initial therapy.
  • In cases of recurrent C. difficile infection, fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is usually done, which helps in restoring the gut microbiome profile.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.solution:
Given scenario of non-hemorrhagic bullae formation on sites of trauma/friction with sparing of mucosa and nails is likely due to epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

Other options :

Chronic bullous disorder of childhood also known as linear IgA dermatosis also presents with bullae formation on sites of friction but has oral lesions. Moreover, the lesions are grouped like a string of pearl appearance.

Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita is an immunobullous disorder that classically presents in adults and bullae are often hemorrhagic.

Bullous pemphigoid is not classically seen on sites of trauma. Moreover the bullae are seen with a surrounding erythematous halo unlike on normal skin.

questions.text: The strength of domestic sewage is being measured in a particular area. What is the minimum amount of suspended solids that should be there to consider the sewage as 'strong'?
questions.solution:
The strength of sewage is considered as strong if the amount of suspended solids is 500mg/L. If the amount is 100mg/L, then the sewage is considered as weak.

The strength of sewage is expressed in terms of biochemical oxygen demand, chemical oxygen demand, and suspended solids.

Related Pearl: Strength of Sewage

The strength of sewage is expressed by the following.

  • Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD):
    • It is the standard test which is an indicator of the organic content of sewage
    • It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage during a specified period (generally 5 days), at a specified temperature (generally 20 deg.C) for the aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living microorganisms.
    • A high BOD (300 mg/l) indicates a high content of easily degradable, organic material while a low BOD (100mg/l) indicates the presence of content that is not easily degradable, low volume of organic matter or measurement problems.
  • Chemical oxygen demand (COD):
    • This test measures the oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidizer
    • This is mostly used when sewage contains toxic wastes
  • Suspended solids:
    • The amount of suspended solids in sewage may vary from 100 to 500 ppm (mg/litre)
    • If the level of suspended solids is 100 ppm, then sewage is weak and if it is more than 500 ppm, sewage is strong.

questions.text: Which of the following tracts transmit somatosensory information with the highest degree of temporal and spatial fidelity?
questions.solution:
The somatosensory information with highest degree of temporal and spatial fidelity (accuracy) is transmitted by the Dorsal Column–Medial Lemniscal pathway.

Temporal fidelity refers to the ability to perceive two consecutive rapid stimuli. Greater the temporal fidelity, stimuli with lesser time interval can be perceived. For example, to appreciate a vibration sense, it is necessary to recognize the two stimuli that are rapidly applied within a short interval, as separate stimuli.

Spatial fidelity refers to the precision with which a sensory stimulus can be localized.

Sensory information with highest degree of temporal and spatial fidelity are transmitted by the Dorsal Column–Medial Lemniscal pathway. These sensations include:

  • Touch sensations requiring a high degree of localization of the stimulus
  • Touch sensations requiring transmission of fine gradations of intensity
  • Phasic sensations, such as vibratory sensations
  • Sensations that signal movement against the skin
  • Position sensations from the joints
  • Pressure sensations related to fine degrees of judgment of pressure intensity

questions.text: A patient presents to you with palpitations and a heart rate of 150/minute. An ECG is done which is shown below. If the blood pressure is normal, what is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer IV dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker

questions.solution:
The ECG showing sawtooth flutter waves along with the clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of atrial flutter. The next best step is to administer an intravenous (IV) beta-blocker for rate control as the patient is hemodynamically stable.

The initial management of atrial flutter targets rate control through IV atrioventricular (AV) nodal blocking agents. These include beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCB) such as verapamil and diltiazem. Intravenous ibutilide, a class III antiarrhythmic agent can be used for rhythm control.

If the patient presents with severe symptoms or is hemodynamically unstable, electrical cardioversion is the first step. If the episode duration is > 48 hours, or if the patient has an increased risk of thromboembolic stroke based on the CHAD2DS2 -VASc scoring system, anticoagulation must be provided before the cardioversion. The drugs which can be used are direct oral anticoagulants (DOAC) such as apixaban, edoxaban, and rivaroxaban. Dabigatran, an antithrombin inhibitor, and warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist can also be used. 

The first episode does not warrant the continuation of antiarrhythmic drugs after conversion to sinus rhythm. In recurrent episodes, sotalol or amiodarone may be used.

At least 4 weeks of anticoagulation therapy is carried out after electrical or chemical cardioversion, as done in atrial fibrillation. Patients with risk factors for thromboembolism should continue it for longer. The definitive treatment is catheter ablation for recurrent cases.

The ECG shows characteristic sawtooth flutter waves due to the atrial activity in the inferior leads ( leads II, III, and aVF). Positive P waves are seen in lead V1. Conduction of more than 230 impulses/ minute through the AV node is not possible in adults. Hence a 2:1 or greater AV block is almost always associated. So patients present with tachycardia of 130-150 beats/minute. Typically, the atrial rate is around 240-300/minute.

Atrial flutter is more commonly seen in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or structural heart disease. Symptoms include palpitations, dizziness, and fatigue.

questions.text: A month-old neonate was brought to the outpatient department with fever, poor feeding, and lethargy. His respiratory rate was high, and you suspect pneumonia. What respiratory rate would be defined as fast breathing in this child?
questions.solution:
A neonate or an infant within 2 months of age presenting with a respiratory rate of more than 60 breaths/minute is considered to have fast breathing.

If the infant has >60 breaths/minute, it is advised to recount, as respiration in infants is usually erratic, and some infants may stop breathing for a few seconds, and rapidly breathe later.

Three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with a cough or difficulty breathing:

  • Respiratory rate: It distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not. A child is said to have rapid breathing if he/she has
    • >60 breaths/minute for infants aged less than two months.
    • >50 breaths/minute for infants aged 2 months to 12 months.
    • >40 breaths/minute for children aged 12 months to 5 years of age.
  • Lower chest wall indrawing
    • Indicates pneumonia
  • Stridor
    • Indicates severe pneumonia requiring hospital admission

According to the recent WHO guidelines, children with fast breathing with/without chest indrawing are classified as having "pneumonia."

Danger signs of severe pneumonia:

  • Not able to drink
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to phase B of bacterial growth curve?

choices.text: Rapid increase in size of bacterial cell is seen
Viable and non culturable organisms can be seen
Steeper phase B can be possible with lesser generation time
Steeper phase B is seen with fastidious organisms

questions.solution:
In phase B (log phase) bacteria divide by multiplication. The time it takes to multiply is called generation time. With a lesser time taken to multiply, the division is faster, and therefore, phase B would be steeper.

Phases of bacterial growth: 

  • Lag phase (Marked as A): Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media. There is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase. This initial period is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which the necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication to proceed.
  • Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as B): In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 
  • Stationary phase (Marked as C): Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Its a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells forms equals the number of cells that die. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
  • Phase of decline (Marked as D): In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

Other options:

A rapid increase in bacterial cell size is a feature of the Lag phase (Phase A)

Viable and non-culturable cells are seen in stationary phase (phase C)

Fastidious organisms are difficult to grow because of their specific growth requirements, they are less likely to grow fast.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the phenomenon shown in the graph below depicting the dose-response with multiple administrations of the drug.

choices.text: Drugs are given at short intervals in the same dose
Drugs are given at short intervals in gradually increasing doses
This incident is seen with drugs such as ephedrine
This action is rarely seen in clinical practice

questions.solution:
The phenomenon depicted is known as tachyphylaxis. Repeated administration of the drug in the same dose quickly leads to the rapid uptake of these drugs leading to exhaustion of neurotransmitters, thus diminishing the response gradually.

  • This phenomenon is usually demonstrated in experimental set up depicted by indirect-acting sympathomimetics such as ephedrine, amphetamine and tyrosine.
  • Their repeated administration in the same dose usually leads to the uptake of the aforementioned drugs leading to exhaustion of neurotransmitters, thus diminishing in response gradually. Sympathetic amines have no active metabolite to increase such response.
  • Tachyphylaxis may also occur as a result of the change in the sensitivity of target cells.
  • It develops faster due to the repetition of the same dose quickly. However, tolerance is developed slowly that can be encountered in the clinical setting.
  • The original effect of the drug can be recovered by increasing the dose in case of tolerance. However, it is not possible in case of tachyphylaxis due to exhaustion of mediators or due to fast desensitization of the target cell.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient was brought to the emergency department after he lost control of his bike and hit a car while texting and driving. On examination, the patient is disoriented and has a pulse of 120 bpm and a BP of 92/60 mm Hg. There is visible bruising on the chest with breathing difficulty. There is a visible deformity of the right thigh associated with shortening. On palpation, there is a discontinuity in the lower third of the right femur with tenderness. You give IV fluids and order an X-ray shaft of the femur as shown. Which of the following shouldn't be done immediately for the management of this case?

choices.text: Getting an Xray of one joint above and below the fracture bone
Urgent shift to OT for Intramedullary nailing

questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows a fracture of the shaft of the femur with the displacement of fractured ends. Intramedullary nailing is the definitive treatment but can be delayed to avoid 'second hit' in this polytrauma case 

In a polytrauma case, with unstable vitals and disorientation, it is wise to hemodynamically stabilize the patient first with fluids. It is to be followed by getting an X-ray done of the fracture site as well of hip and knee to look for any possible fracture extension or dislocation. Splinting the fractured site using Thomas splint or other traction can be done next. It reduces the bleeding, decreases pain due to movement at the fracture site, and makes transfer easier.

Definitive treatment should be done once the patient is stabilized, other life-threatening injuries like a head injury or bowel perforation has been taken care of. For the meantime, an external fixator can be used. Surgery within 24 hours of fracture in an already compromised patient sets an inflammatory cascade which is termed as 'second hit'. Once the inflammatory markers are decreasing, surgery can be attempted.

In case of an isolated fracture, with no evidence of polytrauma, definitive treatment may be attempted earlier, as it reduces the risk of systemic complications like fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple itchy lesions as shown below. KOH stain revealed the presence of predominant macroconidia and scanty microconidia. Which of the following conditions is also likely to be associated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and microscopic examination point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection.

The given image shows annular lesions with central clearing which is seen in dermatophytosis.

Dermatophytes involve only the superficial cornified layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are of three types:

  • Trichosporum: involves skin, hair, and nails. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum: involves skin and hair. Macroconidia> Microconidia
  • Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. Only Macroconidia.

The clinical variants of tinea capitis are:

  • Endothrix - It is a non-inflammatory type of tinea in which multiple black dots and fine scaling are present within the areas of alopecia; it is most commonly caused by Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum.
  • Ectothrix - It is a mild inflammatory type of tinea in which single or multiple scaly patches with hair loss are seen. Microsporum audouinii, Microsporum canis, Microsporum equinum, and Microsporum ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.
  • Kerion - It is a severe inflammatory type that presents with an inflammatory mass with thick crusting and matting of hair with pus and sinus formation. It is commonly caused by Trichophyton verrucosum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes.
  • Favus - It is characterized by the presence of yellowish, cup‐shaped crusts known as scutula that develop around hair follicles. It is caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: Laparoscopic examination of a female patient with chronic pelvic inflammatory disease showed the uterus and appendages densely adherent to each other forming a fixed hard mass along with pelvic cellulitis. The best term to describe this is _______
questions.solution:
The given description best defines 'Frozen pelvis', which is seen in chronic PID.

Chronic PID:

The previous history of pelvic infection indicates the diagnosis of chronic PID. Symptoms can include low backache, abdominal pain, deep dyspareunia, rectal irritation, congestive dysmenorrhea, etc. Sometimes, infertility due to blockage of fallopian tubes. When the uterus and appendages are densely adherent to each other forming a fixed mass along with pelvic cellulitis, it can be termed as the Frozen pelvis.

Other options:

  • Asherman syndrome: It is due to adhesions formed inside the uterine cavity secondary to D&C procedures.
  • Tubo-ovarian mass: This is seen in stage 3 of PID, where there is a unilateral mass formed involving the fallopian tube and ovary.
  • Endometriosis: It is a disorder where endometrial tissue is found outside the uterine cavity.

questions.text: A senior resident asks you to present the case of a patient classified as class 5 Grave's ophthalmopathy (As per American Thyroid Association). Which of the following grave's ophthalmopathy patients you would choose?

choices.text: 28-year-old patient having extraocular muscle involvement with diplopia

questions.solution:
Among the given options, a 30-year-old patient having exposure keratitis would be classified as class 5 Grave's ophthalmopathy patient.

questions.text: You are a 3rd-year medical student posted in surgery clinics. A patient presents with fever and sharply demarcated skin lesions on the face as shown below. What is the most common causative organism of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever and the clinical image showing edema and sharply demarcated erythema over the face and nose are suggestive of erysipelas. Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A beta-hemolytic Streptococcus) is the most common cause of erysipelas.

The given clinical picture shows a sharply demarcated involvement of superficial skin lymphatics. It is usually associated with a breach of skin continuity. The skin may be tender, erythematous, and swollen.

Ear involvement is called Milian's ear sign. This sign helps to differentiate cellulitis from erysipelas. Cellulitis is an infection of the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissues. The pinna does not have a deeper dermis or subcutaneous tissue. Hence, ear involvement points to a diagnosis of erysipelas.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the electrical state of the cardiac muscle during the T-P interval in an ECG, in a patient with myocardial infarction involving a portion of the left ventricle?

choices.text: The entire ventricle is depolarized except for the damaged portion of the cardiac muscle, which is repolarized
The entire ventricle is repolarized except for the damaged portion of the cardiac muscle, which is depolarized

questions.solution:
During the T-P interval in an ECG, in patient with myocardial infarction, the entire ventricle is repolarized except for the damaged portion of the cardiac muscle, which is depolarized.

T-P interval or T-P segment is the isoelectric interval on the ECG that Is present between the end of the T wave and the beginning of the next P wave. The T-P interval is used a reference to assess whether the ST segment is elevated or depressed.

In normal conditions, the entire ventricle gets depolarized by the end of the QRS complex, denoted by the J point. Between the J point and the beginning of the T wave (called ST-segment), the ventricle remains in the depolarized state.

Repolarization occurs during the T wave, and the ventricle then remains in the repolarized state during the T-P interval.

However, in patients with myocardial infarction, the damaged portion of the cardiac muscle does not undergo repolarization. Hence, the damaged portion will continue to remain in the depolarized state all through the T wave and the T-P interval.

Hence, in patients with myocardial infarction, during the T-P interval, the entire ventricle is repolarized except for the damaged portion of the cardiac muscle, which remains in the depolarized state.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male complained of occasional acute attacks of intense panic and anxiety with marked physical symptoms, including shortness of breath, palpitations, sweating, tremors, and fear of impending doom. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features described are diagnostic of panic disorder, which are commonly treated with benzodiazepines such as Clonazepam.

Benzodiazepines act by binding to specific GABA-A receptor subunits at the central nervous system (CNS) neuronal synapses. This facilitates the GABA-mediated chloride ion channel opening frequency.

Therapeutic uses of benzodiazepines:

  • To treat acute anxiety states, panic attacks, and generalized anxiety disorder.
  • Treatment of insomnia and other sleep disorders.
  • Also used for relaxation of the skeletal muscle, as an adjunct in anaesthesia, and seizure disorders.

Overdose of benzodiazepines may cause dose-dependent depressive effects, which include: sedation, amnesia, hypnosis, anaesthesia, coma, and respiratory depression.

Other options:

  • Propranolol may be used for treating performance anxiety, such as stage fright or fear of public speaking. However, propranolol is not primarily indicated for the treatment of the panic disorder. However, they are occasionally used due to side-effects such as hypotension.
  • Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist. It is indicated in the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose, or for reversal of the sedative effects caused by benzodiazepines.
  • Buspirone is a 5-HT receptor agonist. It is used in the treatment of generalised anxiety states (not for other anxiety disorders or panic attacks).

questions.text: According to the POCSO act, sexual harassment includes:

choices.text: Making a child to exhibit his/her body
Act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration
Sexual assault by a police officer

questions.solution:
According to POCSO act sexual harassment includes making a child exhibit his/her body.

The POCSO Act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines various forms of sexual offences which include:

  • Sexual harassment: A person is said to commit sexual harassment upon a child when such person with sexual intent,
    • Carries out any act with sexual connotations
    • Makes a child exhibit his/her body
    • Shows any object to a child in any form/media for pornographic purposes.
    • Repeatedly or constantly watches or contacts a child through any media.
    • Threatens to use in any form of media, a real or fabricated depiction through any mode, of any part of the body of a child. 
  • Sexual assault
    • Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  • Aggravated sexual assault
    • Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated.
  • Penetrative sexual assault
    • An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration.
  • Aggravated penetrative sexual assault
    • Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated.
  • Pornography - Using a child in any form of media for purposes of sexual gratification. 

The term aggravated is used for those assaults done: 

  • By a person in a position of trust or authority such as a police officer, security force, relative, or hospital staff.
  • In the course of communal violence.
  • On mentally & physically disabled.
  • Gang sexual assault.
  • Using deadly weapons.
  • Causing grievous hurt
  • On child < 12 years.

Other options - 

Option B - Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration is a sexual assault according to POCSO.

Option D - Sexual assault done by a police officer is an aggravated sexual assault according to POCSO. 

Option C - Gang penetrative sexual assault is defined as aggravated penetrative assault according to POCSO.

The International Day of Innocent Children Victims of Aggression is a United Nations observance each 4th June. This day affirms the UN's commitment to protect the rights of children.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents to the clinic with a history of a tingling sensation of hands and feet for the past 3 months. She has no history of diabetes. On examination, the following finding was observed on her hands. Which of the following is least likely to be inhibited in this case of poisoning?
questions.solution:
The image shows mottled pigmentation on the hands of the patient (raindrop pigmentation) suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning. Heme synthesis is not inhibited by arsenic.

The mechanism of action of arsenic poisoning involves the interaction of the trivalent form of arsenic (arsenite) with the sulfhydryl group (-SH) of lipoic acid forming a stable complex and causing inhibition of reactions requiring lipoic acid as a cofactor. Examples:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase (or pyruvate oxidase)
  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Branched-chain α-keto acid dehydrogenase

In another mechanism, the pentavalent form of arsenic (arsenate) competes with inorganic phosphate and inhibits the steps requiring the production of ATP or NADH using Pi. Examples:

  • Glycolysis (inhibition of the conversion of G3P to 1,3 BPG by interacting with Pi).
  • Oxidative phosphorylation (Inhibition of ATP production by interacting with Pi).

Note:

Lead interacts with sulphydryl groups of cysteine in proteins and interferes with the action of the enzyme ferrochelatase required for heme synthesis.

questions.text: A patient suffering from severe depression with suicidal thoughts is refractory to pharmacotherapy. ECT (electroconvulsive therapy) sessions are being planned for this patient. What is the maximum number of ECT sessions that can be conducted in a week?
questions.solution:
A maximum of 3 ECT sessions per week can be administered to a patient undergoing electroconvulsive therapy.

Indications for ECT in depression:

  • Severe depression with risk of suicide
  • Severe depression with either stupor, psychomotor retardation, or somatic syndrome
  • Depression refractory to treatment
  • Intolerance or significant side effects to antidepressants.

Severe depression with suicidality is the first and foremost indication for the use of ECT. The response is usually rapid, resulting in a marked improvement.

ECT can be of 2 types:

  • Direct - without anesthesia and muscle relaxant (very infrequently used)
  • Modified - with anesthesia and muscle relaxant. Currently preferred and is given with adequate spacing i.e., no more than 3 ECT sessions per week.

Thiopentone and succinylcholine are given for anesthesia induction and muscle relaxation respectively. Thiopentone sodium is a barbiturate and acts by opening chloride channels, whilst succinylcholine is a depolarising muscle relaxant.

After adequate preparation, a current of 200-1600mA is given, resulting in an adequate seizure. Therapeutically adequate treatment will have a generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting for not less than 25-30 seconds.

After 6 to 10 sessions, if no improvement is seen, bilateral placement and high-density treatment (three times the seizure threshold) should be attempted before ECT is abandoned.

However, antidepressants are often needed along with ECTs in order to maintain the improvement achieved.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes with chronic vulval itching and pain. On examination, there is a vulval lesion suspicious of vulval cancer. Which of the following lymph node/s should be considered for sentinel node biopsy to look for the metastatic spread?
questions.solution:
The first lymph node/s the vulval malignancy spreads to is superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

The sentinel lymph node, which is the first node in a regional lymphatic basin that receives lymph flow from the primary tumour, is often used to assess the presence or absence of metastatic lesions in the lymph nodes.

The most common type of spread in vulval cancer: Lymphatic. A most important prognostic factor is Lymph node status.

First lymph node involved: Superficial inguinal lymph node > Deep inguinal lymph node > (Gland of Cloquet) Femoral group of lymph nodes to external iliac glands, obturator and common iliac nodes in the advanced stages. The sentinel lymph node biopsy is helpful for evaluating the spread of vulval cancer.

questions.text: A 40-year old male patient was referred to you with the features of testicular and renal tumor. While going through his radiological reports, you identified the presence of parathyroid and pituitary adenoma and hence advised him to undergo chromosomal studies. The gene mutation responsible for this condition is located on ___________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of MEN 4 syndrome which is caused by germline mutations in the CDKN1B gene, located on chromosome 12.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) is characterized by the occurrence of tumors involving two or more endocrine glands within a single patient.

MEN 4 comprises:

  • Reproductive organ tumors such as testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical cancer
  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

Note :

  • MEN 1 is caused by a germline mutation in the MEN1 gene (menin protein),  tumour suppressor gene on chromosome 11.
  • MEN 2(both 2A and 2B) is caused by a germline mutation in the RET proto-oncogene, located on chromosome 10.

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man develops acute renal failure and is admitted to a hospital. He is a known case of diabetes for the past eight years, and was well controlled with diet, exercise, and metformin. He has been taking ibuprofen for diffuse bone pain for the past 6 months.
On examination, he is hemodynamically stable; lungs are clear and cardiac examination is normal. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. He has diffuse bony tenderness over his hips, long bones, and spine. Laboratory examination shows urea 72 mg/dL, creatine 5.4 mg/dL, potassium 4.8 mEq/L, calcium 13.7 mg/dL, haemoglobin 8.8 g/dL, serum protein 9.1 g/dL, and albumin 2.6 g/dL.
A renal biopsy is performed. Hematoxylin and eosin stain sections show many atrophic tubules filled with eosinophilic casts surrounded by giant cell reactions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The renal biopsy shows multiple atrophic tubules filled with eosinophilic casts with giant cell reactions around. This picture is diagnostic of light chain nephropathy due to multiple myeloma.

The eosinophilic casts consist of filtered Bence-Jones proteins that block the tubules. Filtered monoclonal light chains may also cause direct toxicity to proximal tubular cells and intracellular crystal formation.

This may result in renal tubular acidosis or Fanconi syndrome. Light chain cast nephropathy (LCCN) is also known as myeloma kidney. It should be considered in patients who fail to recover when the precipitating factor is corrected.

Patients with multiple myeloma may develop acute renal failure that is precipitated by hypovolemia, infection, hypercalcemia, or drugs (NSAIDs or radiographic contrast media).

The goals of treatment are to correct precipitating factors such as hypovolemia and hypercalcemia, discontinue potential nephrotoxic agents, and treat the underlying plasma cell dyscrasia. Plasmapheresis to remove light chains is of doubtful value for LCCN.

questions.text: During your pediatric rotation, you observe a pediatrician perform the following test on a newborn to check for the neuromuscular maturity. What test is being done?
questions.solution:
The sign shown is the Scarf sign. It is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score.

Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest,

  • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline.
  • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline.

Neuromuscular criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  • Posture
  • Square window (wrist)
  • Arm recoil
  • Popliteal angle
  • Scarf sign
  • Heel to ear

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active woman presents with profuse, frothy vaginal discharge associated with itching. On examination, there are multiple punctate spots on the cervix. The most likely causative organism is a _______
questions.solution:
The given examination finding of multiple punctate spots on the cervix describes strawberry cervix. This, along with features of profuse, frothy vaginal discharge and pruritis is suggestive of trichomoniasis. It is caused by a protozoan, Trichomonas vaginalis.

It is sexually transmissible.

Metronidazole 200mg tablets, TID, for 7 days for both partners is prescribed for the management of trichomoniasis.

The pathological finding shown in the image is colpitis macularis or “strawberry cervix,” which results from microscopic, punctate haemorrhages of the cervix. Trichomonas vaginalis is significantly associated with the clinical finding of colpitis macularis.

questions.text: The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is best made by the dysfunction of which structure?
questions.solution:
The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is made by the dysfunction of the optic nerve (marked as "A")

The optic nerve passes through the optic canal and does not enter the cavernous sinus. Patients with orbital apex syndrome manifest complete ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, decreased corneal sensation, and vision loss. They usually develop optic nerve signs such as relative afferent pupillary defect. Proptosis is often present, but patients do not always complain of pain.

Cavernous sinus syndrome (CSS) is a rare condition characterized by ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, ocular and conjunctival congestion, trigeminal sensory loss, and Horner’s syndrome. These signs and symptoms result from the involvement of the cranial nerves passing through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome affects III, IV, V, and VI cranial nerves. The III, IV, V cranial nerves pass in relation to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. VI cranial nerve passes through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome is a distinctive and frequently life-threatening disorder.

Orbital apex syndrome includes the following:

  • Pain, typically labelled as retro-orbital ache
  • Sensory loss/disturbances in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve
  • Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to the involvement of the 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerve involvement
  • Ptosis, due to 3rd nerve paralysis
  • Features of optic nerve involvement, i.e., early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.

questions.text: In a clinical experiment, individuals in two groups A and B were given equal amounts of glucose orally and intravenously, respectively. The Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GLIP, also known as gastric inhibitory peptide – GIP) is released in response to high carbohydrate, fat, and protein foods.

GIP is released from the K cells of the duodenum and jejunum. The action of GIP is mainly to induce the secretion of insulin, and inhibit gastric acid secretion.
