questions.text: Estimation of glycated hemoglobin at half-yearly intervals in patients diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is part of:
questions.solution:
Estimation of glycated haemoglobin at half-yearly intervals in patients diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is part of secondary prevention.

Prevention and care in diabetes mellitus:

A. Primordial prevention: It involves the prevention of the emergence of risk factors in the countries in which they have not yet appeared.

B. Primary prevention: The scope of primary prevention in diabetes mellitus is currently limited. It involves the elimination of environmental risk factors. The preventive measures include:

  • Maintenance of normal body weight through the adoption of healthy nutritional habits and physical exercise.
  • The nutritional habits include an adequate protein intake, a high intake of dietary fibre and avoidance of sweet foods.
  • Elimination of other less well-defined factors such as protein deficiency and food toxins.

C. Secondary prevention: It involves preventive measures taken up after diabetes is detected. The aims of treatment include maintenance of normal blood sugar and maintenance of ideal body weight. The preventive measures include:

  • Routine checking of blood sugar, of urine for proteins and ketones, of blood pressure, visual acuity and weight.
  • Examination of feet for any defective blood circulation, loss of sensation and the health of the skin.
  • Estimation of glycated (glycosylated) haemoglobin at half-yearly intervals.
  • Self-care, which includes adherence to diet and drug regimens, the examination of his own urine and where possible blood glucose monitoring; self-administration of insulin, abstinence from alcohol, maintenance of optimum weight, attending periodic check-ups, recognition of symptoms associated with glycosuria and hypoglycaemia, etc.

D. Tertiary prevention: It involves limiting the disability occurring in patients with diabetes through its complications, e.g., blindness, kidney failure, coronary thrombosis, gangrene of the lower extremities, etc. The measures include:

  • Establishing specialized diabetic clinics to provide care of the highest order.
  • The clinics should be involved in basic, clinical, and epidemiological research.
  • Establishing local and national registries for diabetics.

questions.text: Your co-intern requests the unit chief leave for the weekend, which is denied by the chief. However, on Saturday morning, he complains of severe pain in the abdomen but examination and investigations could not lead to a diagnosis. Which of the following should be considered?
questions.solution:
The scenario described is suggestive of malingering as the patient falsely complained of abdominal pain to avail leave from work.

Malingering is the intentional falsification of physical or psychological symptoms to achieve some practical gain such as financial compensation, avoidance of criminal responsibility or military service, or leave from work. Usually, there is an obvious discrepancy between the complaints and objective findings. The individual is uncooperative during the evaluation and does not comply with the treatment plan proposed. It can be associated with an antisocial personality disorder. In some circumstances, such as while held captive during a war, it can be an adaptive behavior.

Other options:

Option B: Factitious disorder /Munchausen syndrome is the intentional production of physical symptoms to get medical attention. There is no intention to obtain a practical gain.

Option C: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the presence of general and non-delu­sional preoccupation with developing a serious disease for ≥6 months. It is based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. These preoccupied thoughts cause significant distress and impairment in one's life.

Option D: Dissociative fugue refers to sudden travel away from home associated with partial or complete memory loss about one's identity.

Related Pearl: Somatoform Disorder

(hypochondriasis)

questions.text: The following image shows the superior surface of the first cervical vertebra. The part of the bone marked as 1 gives attachment to:
questions.solution:
The part of the first cervical vertebra (C1) or Atlas that is marked as the number 1 is the posterior tubercle, and it gives attachment to ligamentum nuchae.

Atlas or C1 articulates with the occipital condyles of the skull above and with the axis (C2) below to form the atlantooccipital joint. The atlantooccipital joint allows for the nodding movement of the head on the vertebral column. There is no intervertebral disc between C1 and C2.

Features of the atlas:

  • No vertebral body
  • 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets
  • 2 arches- anterior and posterior arches 
  • 2 large transverse processes

Important attachments:

The anterior arch carries a roughened anterior tubercle on the anterior surface which attaches to the anterior longitudinal ligament. The posterior surface of the anterior arch articulates with the dens. The transverse ligament retains the dens against the anterior arch. The upper and lower borders provide attachment for the anterior atlantooccipital membrane and the diverging lateral parts of the anterior longitudinal ligament.

The superior border of the posterior arch attaches to the posterior atlantooccipital membrane. The inferior border is attached to ligamentum flavum. The posterior tubercle provides attachment for ligamentum nuchae.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male patient is undergoing a clinical assessment for aphasia. He makes errors in word choice frequently and has obvious difficulty in comprehension. The speech is otherwise effortless and melodic. Other neurological examination findings are within normal limits. Which area of brain damage can result in such a type of aphasia?

choices.text: Posterior temporal and parietal lobes, dominant hemisphere
Frontal and parietal lobes, dominant hemisphere
Posterior parietal and temporal lobes, non-dominant hemisphere
Prefrontal and frontal regions, dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
The patient described above has Wernicke’s aphasia (WA). This usually occurs as a result of damage in the posterior temporal and parietal regions of the dominant hemisphere, which are supplied by the lower division of the middle cerebral artery.

Aphasia is an acquired disorder of language. Wernicke's aphasia is characterized by fluent language output but impaired comprehension. Gestures do not improve communication. The patient may not realize that their language is incomprehensible and may be associated with severe agitation and paranoia.

Many specific aphasic syndromes have been reported. The most common are Broca, Wernicke, conduction, and global aphasias. Other are non-perisylvian aphasias that include anomic, transcortical motor, transcortical sensory, and mixed transcortical.

questions.text: A peri-menopausal woman was brought to the hospital with a history of difficulty in performing activities of daily living. She is emotionally labile, depressed, and often cries. She is distressed because her mother and elder brother died earlier and had the same symptoms. Her physical examination reveals intact cranial nerves, no sensory-motor deficit except the presence of choreiform movements of limbs. Her memory is good. What is the most likely genetic abnormality present in this woman?

choices.text: Decreased level of hexosaminidase A enzyme

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Huntington’s disease which is caused due to abnormal expansion of the trinucleotide CAG in the Huntington gene on chromosome 4.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a progressive brain disorder that causes uncontrolled movements, emotional problems, and loss of thinking ability. HD is a progressive degenerative disorder due to atrophy, with loss of neurons and gliosis in the caudate lobe, putamen, and globus pallidus.

It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. HD is caused by an abnormal expansion of the trinucleotide CAG in the Huntington gene on chromosome 4. The HTT mutation involves a DNA segment known as a CAG trinucleotide repeat. This segment is made up of a series of three DNA bases (cytosine, adenine, and guanine) that appear multiple times in a row. There may be 40 to 55 copies in patients with typical Huntington disease and 70 repeats in patients with earlier onset of the disease.

Other options:

About 10% of cases of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease are genetically determined, with the inheritance of an abnormal prion protein that leads to spongiform encephalopathy in later adult life.

Tay-Sachs disease of infancy and childhood is caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A.

Mutations in presenilin genes cause familial Alzheimer's disease. The risk of this disease increases with increased levels of apolipoprotein E.

questions.text: A patient presenting with poor appetite and weight loss along with a few episodes of hematemesis is diagnosed with Siewert type 3 adenocarcinoma. Which of the following is the correct anatomical location of adenocarcinoma seen in this patient?

choices.text: Adenocarcinoma located 4 cm proximal to GE junction
Adenocarcinoma located 3 cm distal to GE junction
Adenocarcinoma located 2 cm proximal to GE junction
Adenocarcinoma located 1 cm distal to GE junction

questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma located 3 cm distal to GE junction indicates the location of adenocarcinoma seen in patients diagnosed with Siewert type 3 tumours.

Siewert classification system is based on the anatomical location of adenocarcinoma which is in close proximity to the GE junction. Type 3 tumours are also called sub-cardinal tumours and are located 2 to 5 cm below the GE junction. These tumours are usually treated according to the guidelines for gastric adenocarcinoma. Type III adenocarcinomas generally have a worse prognosis. Siewert types I and II tumours are treated similar to oesophagal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Select the true statement regarding ammonia production and excretion:

choices.text: It increases in metabolic acidosis and in metabolic alkalosis
It decreases in metabolic acidosis but increases in metabolic alkalosis
It increases in metabolic acidosis but decreases in metabolic alkalosis
It decreases in metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
Ammonia production increases in metabolic acidosis but decreases in metabolic alkalosis.

In cases of metabolic acidosis, to maintain the pH of the body, excess of H+ in the body is excreted from the body. Either via respiratory route by the elimination of CO2 (hence fewer chances of forming H2CO3, carbonic acid) or via renal route.

Renal elimination of acid occurs as:

Loss of titratable acid (as acid phosphate NaH2PO4) - this increases the acidity of urine, leading to loss of pH.

Loss of ammonia (as ammonium chloride NH4Cl)- large amounts of acid or H+ can be excreted by forming ammonia without decreasing the pH of urine further.

Ammonia is formed by the action of glutaminase in distal convulated tubular epithelium.It then combines with H+ and Cl- to form NH4Cl, which is then excreted. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding digoxin, except:

choices.text: It is one of the cardiac glycosides
It can cause premature ventricular depolarisations
Hypermagnesemia increases the risk of digitalis induced arrhythmia

questions.solution:
Hypomagnesemia increases the risk of digitalis-induced arrhythmia. 

Digoxin is one of the cardiac glycosides which is derived from the digitalis plant and used clinically.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter to increase intracellular sodium. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

Digoxin is 65–80% absorbed after oral administration. An almost two-third of the metabolite is excreted unchanged by kidney with half-life of 36-40 hours.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity include atrioventricular junctional rhythm, premature ventricular depolarizations, ventricular bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and second-degree AV blockade. After cardiovascular system, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea i.e., GIT effects are more pronounced. Altered color perception can also be seen in case of digoxin toxicity.

Factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity are:

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypokalemia- It increases the binding of the digoxin to the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. 
  • Drugs causing hypokalemia- Diuretics, amphotericin B, corticosteroids
  • Drugs that decrease digoxin elimination (inhibitors of P-glycoprotein)- Amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, itraconazole, propafenone, and flecainide
  • Renal failure
  • Hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with the history of polyuria and polydipsia was diagnosed to be suffering from type 1 DM. What will be the effect of this condition on the free fatty acid(FFA) level in this boy?

choices.text: Decreased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to Low glucagon: insulin ratio
Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio
Decreased FFA level due to low glucagon: insulin ratio

questions.solution:
In type I diabetes mellitus, there is an Increased FFA level due to High glucagon: insulin ratio.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state and hence glucagon: insulin ratio will be high. The level of FFA, in turn, is controlled by glucagon:insulin ratio. Glucagon increases the FFA level and insulin has the opposite effect.

Note: Low insulin state also causes increased fatty acid oxidation leading to increased ketone body production and ketosis.

questions.text: A woman with a known cardiac disease on anticoagulant therapy is found to be pregnant. She needs advice regarding the anticoagulants to be taken during pregnancy and breastfeeding. Which of the following about warfarin and low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) is true?

choices.text: LMWH is teratogenic but not contraindicated in breast feeding
LMWH is teratogenic and also contraindicated in breast feeding
Warfarin is teratogenic but not contraindicated in breast feeding
Warfarin is teratogenic and also contraindicated in breast feeding

questions.solution:
Warfarin is teratogenic during pregnancy but is safe during breastfeeding. LMWH is not teratogenic, and also safe during breastfeeding.

The American College of Chest Physicians guidelines for anticoagulation of pregnant women are given below:

  • The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and replace it with heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to the 12th week. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) can also be used.
  • After the 12th week, it is replaced by warfarin and continued up to 36 weeks.
  • Thereafter it is replaced by heparin which is discontinued just before delivery.
  • Heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) is restarted 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after the cesarean section.
  • UFH (unfractionated heparin), LMWH, and warfarin therapy are not contraindicated during breastfeeding.

These adjustments are done because warfarin is the most effective anticoagulant during pregnancy but it is teratogenic. Hence, we use warfarin for the majority of the duration of pregnancy excluding the first trimester to avoid teratogenic effects. All anticoagulant therapy is discontinued during the expected time of delivery to avoid severe blood loss during delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following changes occur in response to an increase in the shear stress in a blood vessel?
questions.solution:
Increase in the shear stress in a blood vessel will stimulate increased release of the nitric oxide, leading to the dilatation of the blood vessel.

Shear stress is the frictional force exerted on the endothelial cells caused by the flowing blood. When the blood flow increases through a blood vessel, it causes an increase in the shear stress, which activates the endothelial nitric oxide synthase that synthesizes NO from L-arginine and oxygen. The NO then activates the soluble guanylate cyclase, which converts the cyclic GTP to cyclic GMP. The increased levels of cGMP cause relaxation of the vascular smooth muscle.

questions.text: An elderly long-standing diabetic patient was admitted for a serious COVID infection. Over the course of treatment, he developed the following clinical picture. Biopsy revealed broad aseptate fungal hyphae with sporangiums. The most appropriate drug for the treatment of this patient is ________
questions.solution:
The description of the patient typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.

Patients with severe COVID are at risk for developing invasive fungal infections like aspergillus, candida, and mucormycosis. A high index of suspicion should be kept as these may alter the course of the disease by causing a fatality.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection in diabetes mellitus, leukemia, lymphoma patients. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. It has broad-based aseptate hyphae and is identified by sporangium and cottony colonies.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman has a serum hCG level of 800 IU/L. On transvaginal ultrasound, the gestational sac of 2cm is found in the right fallopian tube, there is no fetal heartbeat and no evidence of bleeding or rupture. Her subsequent hCG levels were decreasing. She is hemodynamically stable and is willing for close follow-up. What management should be considered in her?
questions.solution:
This patient has an ectopic pregnancy, the given indications suggest that she can be considered for expectant management.

Expectant management means that only observation is done hoping for spontaneous resolution.

Indications for expectant management in a diagnosed unruptured ectopic gestation are:

  • Initial serum hCG level less than 1000 IU/L and the subsequent levels are falling.
  • The gestation sac size is less than 4 cm.
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS.
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS.

Methotrexate is used in the medical management of ectopic pregnancy. It has certain absolute and relative contraindications. When used in conditions that are relatively contraindicated, the risk of failure is high. 

Factors that would make one opt for surgical management are:

  • Sac >4 cm
  • beta HCG:>3000 IU/L
  • Fetal heart rate (FHR) present
  • Patient hemodynamically unstable

An unstable patient should undergo urgent surgical consultation and exploration ie, laparotomy. It reduces haemorrhage and hemodynamic instability, also giving a better view of the operating field for the surgeon.

questions.text: Identify the underlying lung pathology from the given flow volume loop:
questions.solution:
Obstructive sleep apnoea.

The flow volume loop given depicts small rapid oscillations in flow during both expiration and inspiration. This type of flow volume loop is seen in obstructive sleep apnoea commonly referred to as saw-tooth pattern.

Asthma: The flow volume loop has a concave upward pattern, sometimes called "scooped-out" or "coved," on the expiratory portion of the flow-volume loop.
Silicosis and Sarcoidosis are restrictive lung disorders. They are characterised by decrease in vital capacity, increased expiratory flows when corrected for lung volume. The resulting shape of the flow-volume curve is a tall, "witch's hat" appearance with a steep descending limb.

questions.text: A 45-yr-old man with a history of major depressive disorder presents to the psychotherapist after an episode of depression triggered by the death of his wife. By the end of session, the patient unconsciously starts developing feelings towards the therapist similar to the one which he had for his wife. This is an example for____________
questions.solution:
The above-given scenario, in which the patient starts projecting his feelings onto the therapist, is an example of transference.

Transference involves the patient projecting his feelings, thoughts and wishes onto the therapist. It is a process wherein the patient, unconsciously and inappropriately, displaces behavioral and emotional patterns experienced with other people in his or her life (often during childhood) onto individuals in his or her current life.

The therapist needs to recognize that transference may be causative of the patient's behaviors and not react inappropriately by perceiving it as a personal attack by the patient. In the above clinical scenario, the therapist is equated to a partner figure as the man displaces his feelings towards his deceased wife onto the therapist.

When patients in a group direct such feelings toward one another, it is called multiple transferences.

Other options:

Option B. Parapraxis involves the patient unconsciously revealing his feelings via a fault, like a slip of the tongue. It was attributed to unconscious motives by Freud.

Option C. Counter-transference involves the therapist unconsciously displacing onto the patient, behavioral or emotional patterns of a significant figure from the therapist's earlier life. 

Option D. Catharsis is characterized by a sense of relief produced by an emotional response to the expression of suppressed emotions, ideas, and thoughts. In catharsis, the patient reveals information voluntarily and consciously whereas, in parapraxis, patient details are revealed unconsciously, by slip of the tongue.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male was diagnosed with end-stage renal disease and was initiated on hemodialysis. A tunneled central venous catheter was inserted for dialysis access. One week later, the patient complained of fever and chills. The catheter insertion site shows signs of inflammation. Which of the following is the next best step in the evaluation or management of the patient.

choices.text: Blood culture from peripheral vein and catheter tip
Empirical therapy with vancomycin and linezolid

questions.solution:
The clinical case described is suggestive of catheter-related bloodstream infections. The first step in the management of the patient is to order blood cultures from peripheral veins and vascular catheter tip.

Catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBIs):

The condition occurs due to the migration of the cutaneous microorganisms extraluminally, to the catheter tip. It usually occurs during the first week after the catheter insertion. Most patients present with fever and chills.

The venous catheters may be tunneled or non-tunneled.

  • Tunneled catheters are inserted surgically by creating a subcutaneous track before entering the vein. They are usually used in hemodialysis and chemotherapy.
  • Non-tunneled catheters are temporary central venous catheters that are inserted percutaneously. They are commonly used and account for most (CRBIs).

Diagnosis and Management:

  • The first step is to order a Blood culture from a peripheral vein and catheter tip. Preferably two samples drawn from peripheral veins by separate venipunctures.
  • Until the culture reports are obtained, the patient is initiated on empirical therapy with antibiotics based on the local susceptibility data.
  • The therapy is directed based on the pathogen recovered from the blood or infected site.
  • Transesophageal echocardiography is done to evaluate the patient for endocarditis, duration of therapy, and the need for removal of infected catheters.
  • In cases of bacteremia or fungemia due to non-tunneled CVC, the catheter is removed.
  • In some cases, clinicians may prefer to salvage a CVC, by a technique called antibiotic lock in addition to systemic antibiotics. The antibiotic lock technique involves instilling high concentrations of antibiotics into the catheter lumen for extended periods, which prevents the penetration of the infected biofilm.

questions.text: The characteristic sign shown in the echocardiography below, is diagnostic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The echocardiography shows “swinging heart”, which is characteristically seen in cases with large pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion refers to the accumulation of excess fluid in the pericardial space.

Radiographic findings in pericardial effusion

Greater than 200 mL of pericardial fluid is usually required to become radiographically visible. Radiographic signs include

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (pericardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign
  • Serially enlarging cardiothoracic ratio

Echocardiography is considered the primary imaging investigation for the evaluation of pericardial effusion.

An anechoic separation of pericardial layers can be identified on transthoracic echocardiography when pericardial ﬂuid exceeds 50 mL. In a supine patient, the effusion will first appear posteriorly, tracking anterior to the descending aorta and left atrium. The parasternal long-axis and subcostal four-chamber views are typically favored for inspection of the pericardial space.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male noticed a nodule on his arm 8 months ago. On examination, a reddish violet ulcer is also noted on his right forearm measuring 3 x 5 cm. Non-tender enlarged lymph nodes were palpated over the right axilla and left groin. On chest x-ray, a 3 cm left pleural mass was seen. CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 6cm retroperitoneal mass. The excision biopsy of the inguinal lymph node shows large cells, some showing horseshoe-shaped nuclei and plenty of cytoplasm as shown in the image below. These tumor cells are seen especially around venules and infiltrating the sinuses. The patient responds very well to chemotherapy. Which of the following markers is most likely to be positive in the tumor cells?
questions.solution:
The above patient has developed a T-cell neoplasm called anaplastic large cell lymphoma that is commonly seen in children and young adults. This lymphoma usually involves extranodal sites.

The genetic defect is found on chromosome 2p23 that results in the production of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) with tyrosine kinase activity.

The large anaplastic cells containing horseshoe-shaped nuclei and voluminous cytoplasm are called hallmark cells. The tumor cells often cluster about venules and infiltrate lymphoid sinuses, thereby appearing as metastatic carcinoma.

T-cell lymphomas with ALK rearrangements affect children or young adults. They involve extranodal soft tissues and the prognosis is good. They are very sensitive to chemotherapy with a cure rate of 75% to 80%. Recently ALK inhibitors have been developed and are useful in cases not responding to conventional chemotherapy.

Other options:

  • CD10 is a B-cell marker.
  • The c-KIT proto-oncogene has been associated with some NK cell lymphomas.
  • The IL-2 receptor is associated with lymphohistiocytosis with macrophage activation.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the hospital after her mother notices red blood in her stool. On examination, you notice mucocutaneous pigmentation around her lip, as shown in the picture below. Radiography with oral contrast reveals multiple, small- to medium-sized polyps in the small intestine. Which type of polyp is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with the image are suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Hamartomatous polyps are seen in this condition.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant, hereditary disorder characterized by intestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous dark blue to brown melanin pigmentation, which is particularly evident on the face, buccal mucosa, hands, feet, and perianal and genital regions. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years. Germline loss of function mutations of STK11 is usually associated with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

The hamartomatous polyps of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome are most common in the small intestine. Grossly, the polyps are large and pedunculated with a lobulated contour. Histologically, they are characterized by an arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception, which is occasionally fatal.
  • It is associated with a markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Lifetime risk is approximately 40% and regular surveillance is recommended for sex cord tumors of the testes (from birth); gastric and small intestinal cancers (during late childhood); colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers (2nd and 3rd decade).

Other options: Hyperplastic polyps, tubular adenoma, and villous adenoma are principally colonic polyps that are derived from the luminal epithelium.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: In which of the following parasitic infection, man doesn't serve as a definitive host?
questions.solution:
Among the above options, the definitive host for Echinococcus granulosus is dog (not man).

The definitive host is where the sexual stages of lifecycle occur. Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, but humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human to human transmission.

Echinococcus granulosus is the most common causative agent in hydatid cysts, while Echinococcus multilocularis and Echinococcus ligartus account for a small number of cases.

Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver and are solitary. The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is largely asymptomatic until complications occur. The most common presenting symp­toms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presented with complaints of pain in her left calf and thigh muscles. Doppler ultrasonography revealed deep vein thrombosis. She was started on enoxaparin. A week later, enoxaparin was discontinued, and was started on warfarin. Two months later she returned with complaints of severe nose bleed. Her INR was 7.0. To prevent severe hemorrhage, warfarin should be discontinued, and the patient should be immediately started on which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Warfarin should be immediately discontinued, and vitamin K1 should be started to accelerate the formation of the vitamin K-dependent factors.

Elevated level of international normalized ratio (INR) is suggestive of severe anticoagulation.

Reversal of Warfarin action:

  • Moderate anticoagulation caused by warfarin, without any bleeding can be treated with cessation of the drug alone.
  • An excessive anticoagulant effect and bleeding caused due to warfarin can be reversed by stopping the drug immediately and administering oral or parenteral vitamin K1 (phytonadione), fresh frozen plasma, prothrombin complex concentrates, and recombinant factor VIIa (rFVIIa).
  • In case of severe bleeding, administration of prothrombin complex or rFVIIa coupled with intravenous vitamin K, rapidly reverses the effect of warfarin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of progressive difficulty in breathing for the past 5 days. Her physical examination reveals a temperature of 37.2° C, heart rate of 88/min, respiratory rate of 22/min, and a blood pressure of 155/96mm Hg. The percussion note over both lung bases is stony dull and the chest x-ray shows a bilateral pleural effusion. Laboratory findings show Hemoglobin 11.2 g/dl, WBC count 3460/mm3, blood urea 27 mg/dl, and serum creatinine 3.4 mg/dl. Her ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA antibody test results are positive. Which of the following cardiac illness is most likely to be present in her?
questions.solution:
Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) and anti-double-stranded DNA antibody test is positive indicating the diagnosis of Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a complication of SLE, characterized by small, sterile vegetations that may occur anywhere over valves, chordae and endocardium.

Vegetations are often associated with severe valvulitis, characterized by fibrinoid necrosis of the valve and reflects the activation of complement and recruitment of Fc-receptor-bearing cells.

Other options:

  • Calcific aortic stenosis may be seen in older individuals as a consequence of age-associated wear and tear, involving tricuspid or bicuspid valves.
  • Although pericarditis is common in SLE, it is serous, not hemorrhagic.
  • Rheumatic heart disease is an immunologic disease and serologic tests would be positive for antistreptolysin O (ASO), not ANA.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with rigidity, frequent falls, slowness in his movements, tremors, and had short stepping gait when he entered the doctor's room. Which of the following areas, is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease, which is associated with the degeneration of substantia nigra (marked as "C").

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Postural instability along with bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Notable gait abnormalities are:

  • Short stepped gait- parkinsonism
  • Scissoring gait- spasticity i.e. UMN lesion
  • High-stepped, slapping gait- posterior column or peripheral nerve disease
  • Waddling gait- proximal muscle weakness
  • Wide stepping gait - cerebellar dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is indicated for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, adenosine is the drug of choice for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.

  • Adenosine is an ultra-short acting drug with half-life being less than 10 seconds.
  • It activates an inward rectifier K+ current along with inhibition of calcium current. The results of these actions are marked hyperpolarization and suppression of calcium- dependent action potentials.
  • When given as a bolus dose, adenosine directly inhibits AV nodal conduction but has lesser effects on the SA node.
  • Currently, Adenosine is used for prompt conversion of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to sinus rhythm because of its high efficacy (90–95%) and very short duration of action. It is usually given in a bolus dose of 6 mg followed by a dose of 12 mg, if required.
  • Flushing, shortness of breath and chest burning are some of its adverse effects.

questions.text: A gynecologist is examining a 38-year-old female patient with a retroverted uterus. What is the lowest part of the cervix palpated by the examining finger in this case?
questions.solution:
In a retroverted uterus, the external os of the cervix is directed downward and forward; therefore, the lowest part of the cervix is either the external os or the posterior lip.

In anteversion, the external os is directed downward and backwards; therefore, on vaginal examination, the lowest part of the cervix felt by the fingers is the anterior lip.

Anteflexion of the uterus is at the level of Internal os. 

Angle of Anteversion Angle of Anteflexion
The angle between the cervix and vagina The angle between cervix and uterus
90o 120o
(Remember: V for version, V for vagina)

questions.text: A 79-year-old male with long-standing hypothyroidism was initiated on T4 therapy. It is important to initiate the therapy in low doses, to prevent which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Low doses of levothyroxine (T4) should be started in patients with long-standing hypothyroidism, especially in elderly patients to prevent cardiac overstimulation.

Elderly patients are highly sensitive to the stimulatory effects of T4 and may lead to increased risk of atrial fibrillation and accelerated osteoporosis.

Dosage:

  • In older patients (> 50 years) without cardiac disease, levothyroxine can be started at a dosage of 50 mcg/d.
  • In older patients with long-standing hypothyroidism and underlying cardiac disease, levothyroxine should be started at 12.5–25 mcg/d for 2 weeks, which can be increased by 12.5–25 mcg/d for every 2 weeks until euthyroidism or drug toxicity is observed.

questions.text: Overdose of which of the following anti-arrhythmic drugs is correctly paired with its ECG side effects?

choices.text: Diltiazem – Increased PR interval and QRS duration

questions.solution:
Flecainide causes increased QRS duration. All other drugs are matched incorrectly.

The effect of various prototype antiarrhythmic drugs on ECG are as follows:

Group 1 Drugs:

Procainamide, disopyramide, quinidine (Group 1A):

  • PR interval may decrease due to antimuscarinic action or increase due to channel-blocking action.
  • Increase in QRS duration and QT interval.

Lidocaine, mexiletine (Group 1B):

  • There is normally no change in PR interval, QRS duration or QT interval.
  • However, they can slow conduction through ischemic, depolarized ventricular cells.

Flecainide (Group 1C) causes a slight increase in PR interval, increased QRS duration, and no change in QT interval.

Group 2 drugs:

Propranolol and esmolol cause an increased PR interval.

Group 3 drugs:

  • Amiodarone is often classified as group 3 but also has some group 1A properties. It causes increased PR interval, QRS duration, and QT interval.
  • Ibutilide, dofetilide causes increased QT interval.
  • Sotalol causes an increase in PR interval and QT interval.

Group 4 drugs such as verapamil and diltiazem cause an increase in PR interval. The QRS duration and QT interval are unaffected.

questions.text: A factory where 600 workers are being employed (of which 100 are women workers) requires all the following facilities/measures except ______
questions.solution:
A safety officer has to be employed if the number of employees is > 1000, this factory is employing just 600.

  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 employees – safety officer
    •  > 500 employees – welfare officer
    • > 250 employees – canteen
    • > 50 employees – creche

The term 'employees' has been used to make the provision gender neutral, because though a woman is biologically endowed to give birth, however, the responsibility to take care of a child lies with both the father and the mother. Therefore, even if an establishment consists of only males, such establishment should have a creche facility so as to enable fathers to bring their children to the creche.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

The Motor Response score of the given patient is 3.

questions.text: During the examination of a patient diagnosed with heterotropia, you noticed an increased amount of deviation in upward gaze and a decreased amount of deviation in downward gaze as shown in the below image. The pattern of heterotropia seen in this patient is known as _________
questions.solution:
The given image shows a convergent squint or esotropia in the upward gaze. Since the deviation is more in the upward gaze it depicts an A pattern esotropia.

A or V pattern heterotropia:

The term A or V pattern heterotropia is used when there is a variation in the amount of deviation in the squinting eye between upward and downward gaze. This difference is considered significant when it is more than 10 degrees in the A pattern and more than 15 degrees in the V pattern. These conditions are assessed by measuring the horizontal deviations in the primary position, upgaze, and downgaze.

  • In esotropia, if the amount of deviation increases in upward gaze and decreases in downward gaze, it is known as "A" pattern esotropia. The reverse occurs in ‘V’ pattern esotropia.
  • In exotropia, if the amount of deviation decreases in upward gaze and increases in downward gaze, it is known as "A" pattern exotropia. The reverse occurs in ‘V’ pattern exotropia.

questions.text: Which is the last region to show changes in rigor mortis?
questions.solution:
Fingers and toes is the last to show changes in rigor mortis.

The rigor mortis changes begins in the left chamber of the heart. 

Rigor mortis/cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening refers to stiffening and shortening of muscles following death.

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head down the body, in that order. It disappears in the same order of appearance.

The order of appearance of rigor mortis:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

questions.text: A 17-year-old female comes to the OPD with complaints that her periods have not started yet since puberty, but she gets abdominal pain every month. On examination, she has normal development of other secondary sexual characters, there is an abdominal lump present and on parting the labia a bluish bulge is noted. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
A history of primary amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, presence of a palpable abdominal lump, and visualization of a tense bluish bulging membrane on the separation of the labia suggests the diagnosis of Imperforate hymen. Simple cruciate incision of hymen will allow the drainage of menstrual blood.

Cryptomenorrhoea, also known as hematocolpos, is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The most common cause is an intact (imperforate) hymen or the presence of a vaginal septum.

A vaginal septum is differentiated from the imperforate hymen by a pinkish concave covering in contrast to the bluish convex bulge in the latter.

An ultrasound scan of the pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Treatment:- A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function, in cases of imperforate hymen.

In the case of a vaginal septum (i.e atresia), more extensive dissection and vaginoplasty are required.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Friedreich's ataxia?

choices.text: Skin lesions represent a common manifestation of this disorder
The molecular defect involves the expansion of a trinucleotide repeat sequence
The onset of symptoms occurs after age 25 years
It is transmitted in an autosomal dominant manner

questions.solution:
Friedreich's ataxia (FA) is a rare genetic disease that occurs due to spinocerebellar degeneration. It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder due to a molecular defect on chromosome 9 that involves a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion.

It is the most common of the autosomal recessive ataxias. There is a loss of large myelinated axons in peripheral nerves, though the unmyelinated fibers in sensory roots and peripheral sensory nerves are spared.

It results in difficulty in walking, loss of sensation in the upper and lower limbs, and impairment of speech. The patients develop ataxia usually before the age of 25 years. Other features include:

  • Progressive dysarthria
  • Bilateral extensor plantar responses
  • Sensory polyneuropathy with absent deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities.
  • Scoliosis and pes cavus

The patients may also develop certain ECG abnormalities such as like supraventricular tachyarrhythmias secondary to cardiac involvement. Diabetes mellitus is more common and this syndrome is associated with an increased incidence of cancer.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a fever and chronic cough is administered 0.1 mL of purified protein derivative intradermally over the forearm. After a few hours, the injection site appears as follows.  Which of the following does this represent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a positive tuberculin test. It is a classical example of type IV or delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

Tuberculin test involves intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. In a previously sensitized individual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside. 

Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation of mononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules. The cell-mediated type of hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cells and cell killing by CD8+ T cells.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

questions.text: The appearance of the gross-specimen of the lung shown below, is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Bronchiectasis is a lung pathology characterized by irregular and irreversible dilatation of bronchi and bronchioles (shown in the lower left part of the gross specimen in the image) due to the permanent destruction of smooth muscle and elastic components in their walls. 

Common predisposing factors include necrotizing pneumonia, bronchial obstruction, autoimmune disorders, and congenital conditions that increase the risk for chronic infections (such as cystic fibrosis and primary ciliary dyskinesia). Obstructive bronchiectasis is caused by numerous conditions such as tumors, foreign body, mucous plugs, and enlarged external lymph nodes. The pathology develops distal to the point of obstruction.

Non-obstructive bronchiectasis is usually the result of chronic lung infections and the accompanying defect in airway clearance.

These patients present with chronic cough and production of copious, foul-smelling purulent sputum.

Mucus plugging and subsequent infection with P. aeruginosa is a common complication of cystic fibrosis. Bronchial obstruction caused by such infections are chronic and result in bronchiectasis despite antibiotics and other treatments.

Other options:

  • Empyema is a collection of purulent material in the pleural cavity.
  • Atelectasis is due to the collapse of the lung parenchyma. This results in poor oxygenation.
  • Pneumothorax is a collection of air in the pleural space.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman has the following flow pattern of umbilical arteries on a doppler. What does this pattern indicate?
questions.solution:
The given flow pattern of umbilical arteries represents an absence of end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical arteries.

In case of absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF), the waves just touch the baseline, but do not appear below it. This is associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). 

Pregnant women having intrauterine growth restriction with AEDF in the umbilical artery are managed expectantly until delivery at 34 weeks. 

Umbilical artery vessels usually have forward flow throughout the cardiac cycle.  As gestation increases, there is a gradual fall in all the placental resistance indices, so the amount of the forward diastolic flow increases and the S/D ratio (systole to diastole ratio) decreases as the period of gestation increases.

Note: Reverse end-diastolic flow has seen an insignificant increase in resistance to blood flow within the placenta. They are managed expectantly until delivery at 32 weeks.

The below image shows various patterns of end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery on Doppler.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with a history of heartburn after heavy meals for the past 4 years. A biopsy of the lower esophageal mucosa is obtained by upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. The microscopic picture is shown below. What is the most likely cellular adaptation observed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing the replacement of stratified squamous epithelium with intestinal-type columnar epithelium with goblet cells is suggestive of Barret's esophagus. The most likely cellular adaptation observed is metaplasia. 

Metaplasia is a reversible cellular adaptation characterized by the replacement of one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) by another cell type. It usually represents an adaptive response in which one cell type is replaced by another more capable of handling the stressor. 

The various types of metaplasia are:

  • Squamous metaplasia - 
    • Airways - normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. It may occur due to chronic smoking or a deficiency of retinoic acid
    • Urinary bladder - normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. It may occur due to bladder stones 
  • Columnar metaplasia - 
    • Esophagus - normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barret's esophagus). It may occur in patients with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease
  • Connective tissue metaplasia - 
    • Muscle - formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans. This may occur secondary to intramuscular hemorrhage

The images below show squamous and columnar metaplasia, respectively. 

Other options:

Option B: Hyperplasia is a cellular adaptation characterized by an increase in the number of cells, thereby, resulting in an increase in organ size. Such an example is the glandular hyperplasia of the female breast during puberty and pregnancy.

Option C: Atrophy is a decrease in the size of the tissue or organ due to the reduction in the cell number and size. Such an example is muscle atrophy after nerve injury.

Option D: Dysplasia is a cellular adaptation characterized by disordered cellular architecture (increased mitoses, increased nucleus: cytoplasm ratio) and growth that predisposes to malignancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient came to you with the complaints of swelling of the right lower limb. During the examination, you noticed that the edema was non-pitting, and you were not able to pinch the skin on the dorsum of the toes on the right foot, as shown in the image given below. The edema did not reduce upon elevation of the limb, however, there were no irreversible skin changes. What is the Brunner grading in this patient?
questions.solution:
Non-pitting oedema, which does not reduce on elevation, having a positive stemmer sign (as shown in the above image) with no irreversible skin changes would be classified as grade II according to Brunner's grading.

Stemmer’s sign is seen in lymphedema. When the skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched, the stemmer's sign is said to be positive. It occurs due to subcutaneous fibrosis.

Clinical classification of lymphedema: Brunner's Grading

Grade Clinical features

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in labor with a previous history of LSCS presents with acute onset scar tenderness, cardiotocography shows fetal bradycardia. Examination reveals maternal tachycardia and hypotension, vaginal examination reveals abnormal vaginal bleeding. There is a suspicion of scar dehiscence. Which of the following is considered as the most consistent finding of scar dehiscence during labor?
questions.solution:
Abnormal cardiotocography/CTG (abnormal FHR, bradycardia, variable and late decelerations) is the most consistent finding seen in scar dehiscence.

Uterine scar tenderness

Early diagnosis of scar dehiscence or rupture needs prompt laparotomy and resuscitation to reduce mortality and morbidity in mother and infant.

questions.text: Which of the following bone tumours is radioresistant?
questions.solution:
Metastasis to bone are generally radiosensitive, except for Renal cell carcinoma which is conventionally regarded as radioresistant.

In patients aged more than 50 years, metastatic bone tumors are more common than primary bone tumors. It should be suspected in any lytic bone lesion. Osteoblastic lesions are uncommon and seen in prostate carcinoma. Primary tumors are most often found in breast, prostate, kidney, lung, thyroid, bladder and GIT. These metastasize to the vertebra, pelvis, femur and humerus.

It presents more often as only pain or may be discovered incidentally in a pathological fracture. Treatment is usually a combination of chemoradiation and surgery. Bauer's criteria define the prognosis, the more the score, the better the prognosis.

Related Pearl: Important radiosenstive and radioresistant bone tumours

Radiosensitive tumors:

  1. Metastasis (except metastasis from renal cell carcinoma which is radioresistant)
  2. Ewing's sarcoma
  3. Multiple myeloma
  4. Lymphoma

Radioresistant tumors:

  1. Osteosarcoma
  2. Chondrosarcoma
  3. Fibrosarcoma
  4. Malignant fibrous histiocytoma

questions.text: Dracunculiasis is transmitted through _______

choices.text: Bathing and soaking feet in water containing cyclops
Contact transmission of worms from an infected person
Direct transmission of worms from cuts or wounds

questions.solution:
Dracunculiasis (Guinea worm) is transmitted entirely through the consumption of water containing cyclops harbouring the infective stages of the parasite. It is a totally water-based disease and doesn't have an alternate pathway of transmission.

The life cycle of Dracunculus medinensis:

Treatment:

  • No drug cures the infection but metronidazole and mebendazole are sometimes used to limit inflammation and facilitate worm removal.
  • Worms are removed by sequentially rolling them out over a small stick.
  • Wet compresses may relieve discomfort. Occlusive dressings improve hygiene and limit shedding of infectious larvae.
  • A simple surgical procedure can be done to remove the worm.
  • Topical antibiotics may be used to limit bacterial superinfection.

Eradication:

Guinea-worm disease is amenable to eradication. The eradication strategy comprises the following elements :

  • Provision of safe drinking water (e.g., piped water, installation of hand pumps).
  • Control of cyclops
  • Health education of the public in matters relating to boiling or sieving drinking water through a double thickness cotton cloth for personal protection, and prevention of water contamination by infected persons.
  • Surveillance: Active search for new cases.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with an increased nighttime itching and lesions that are more during the winter months?
questions.solution:
Skin lesions that increase during the winter months and that cause more itching during the nighttime are seen with scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei. Allergic sensitivity to the mite or its products appears to play an important role in determining the development of lesions other than burrows, and in producing pruritus. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared.

Diagnosis is made through clinical examination and microscopic examination of scrapings obtained from lesions. The presence of eggs and mites of Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis is seen under the microscope and this confirms the diagnosis of scabies. However, the absence of eggs and mites under a microscope does not exclude the disease.

Treatment:

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% Lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.

Other options:

Tinea corporis - Lesions are more during the summer months 

Psoriasis - Lesions are more during the winter months but no diurnal variation is seen

Photodermatosis - Lesions are more on exposure to sunlight during daytime

Timing of pruritus in arthropod bites:

Lice - Anytime

Spider - No itching, painful during bite

Tick - No symptoms

Bedbugs - Morning

Fleas - daytime

Mosquitoes: Anopheles spp. night; Culex spp. night; Aedes spp. Day

Scabies: Night

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: A newborn was born with the deformity as shown in the image below. You apply a cast as per Ponseti's technique and ask them to return for complete treatment. The patient is however lost to follow-up and is brought to you 2 years later. Which of the following will you do?
questions.solution:
The image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV). Since the child is less than 3 years old, posteromedial soft tissue release procedures should be done as per the agewise management protocol of CTEV.

The first line of management for CTEV is Ponseti's technique in which gradual correction of deformities is done by plaster cast. The sequence of correction is given as:

C- Cavus 

A- Adduction

V- Varus

E- Equinus

In addition to the above procedure, we can provide the child with CTEV shoes as the child has started walking to retain the correction.

Features of CTEV shoes:

  • Straight inner border prevents adduction
  • Outer shoe raise prevents foot inversion
  • Absence of heel prevents equinus
  • Used once the deformity is corrected and when the child starts walking, upto 5 years of age

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient presents with delayed puberty. Investigations reveal increased levels of gonadotropins. Which among the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient has increased levels of gonadotropins pointing towards Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and Klinefelter's syndrome is the only condition in the given choices causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Klinefelter's syndrome is the most common sex chromosomal aneuploidy in males. Most of them have 47 XXY chromosomes. The diagnosis is rarely made before puberty, behavioral or psychiatric disorders may be apparent long before the defects in sexual development.

Causes of delayed puberty:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Secondary/central):

Hypogonadism due to the impaired secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland and the resultant lack of sex steroid production

  • Malnutrition, systemic diseases
  • Kallmann (anosmia), Prader–Willi syndrome (mental retardation, obesity, low intelligence)

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Primary gonadal failure):

Hypogonadism due to an impaired response of the gonads to the gonadotropins (FSH and LH), which in turn leads to a lack of sex steroid production and elevated gonadotropin levels (as an attempt of compensation by the body)

  • Sex chromosome anomalies (Turner's, Klinefelter's syndrome)
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Ovotesticular dysgenesis

questions.text: An old hypertensive male patient had a recent change in his anti-hypertensive drug. He now comes with complaints of dizziness on standing for few minutes. This started soon after taking the new drug. Which of the following class of drugs would have most likely caused this effect?
questions.solution:
The patient is having drug-induced orthostatic/postural hypotension and it is caused by the effect of alpha1 - selective receptor blocker.

Alpha1 receptor blockers, such as prazosin, cause a reduction of peripheral resistance as well as venous pooling of blood. This causes a decrease in venous return and cardiac output leading to a fall in blood pressure. Postural reflex causes marked postural hypotension which leads to syncope. This dizziness and fainting are known as the first dose effect and can be minimized by starting with a minimal dose and titrating it thereafter. Other side effects include reflex tachycardia, miosis, nasal congestion, and impotence. 

They are used as an antihypertensive agent and in benign hypertrophy of the prostate to decrease prostatic tone.

Other options:

Option A: Nonselective Beta receptor blockers, such as intravenous propranolol, is used to treat life-threatening arrhythmias, etc. It produces side effects such as bradycardia, exacerbating heart failure and chronic obstructive lung diseases, etc.

Option B: Alpha2 selective receptor agonists, such as apraclonidine, are used to reduce intraocular pressure and have minimal systemic effects. Side effects include dry mouth, sleepiness, and conjunctival hyperemia. 

Option C: Beta2 selective receptor agonists, such as salbutamol, act as a bronchodilator, vasodilators, and uterine relaxants. They have side effects such as muscle tremors, palpitations, etc.

questions.text: During the ophthalmology postings, you were asked to check for the primary, secondary, and tertiary actions produced by the extraocular muscle innervated by the trochlear nerve in a 50-year-old diabetic female. You would look for which of the following actions respectively?
questions.solution:
Trochlear nerve innervates superior oblique muscle. The primary, secondary, and tertiary actions produced by this muscle are Intorsion, Depression, and Abduction respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curves correspond to the normal blood (dark-blue), and foetal blood (light-blue)?
questions.solution:
The O2-Hb dissociation curve of the fetal blood is shifted to the left compared to the adult blood, as shown in graph C.

The RBCs of the fetal blood consists of fetal haemoglobin (Hb-F), which is structurally similar to the adult haemoglobin, except that, Hb-F consists of Gamma (γ) chains instead of the Beta (β) chains seen in adults.

Hence structurally, Hb-F constitutes α2γ2. Soon after birth, the fetal haemoglobin is replaced by the adult form of haemoglobin.

There are three reasons that allow the fetal blood to transport almost as much oxygen to the fetal tissues, despite low Po2:

  • The Hb-F has a higher affinity for oxygen, and hence binds more avidly than the adult haemoglobin, even at a lower partial pressure of oxygen. Hence, the oxygen-Hb dissociation curve is shifted to left. The increased affinity of Hb-F for oxygen plays a vital role, as the fetal blood leaving the placenta has a low Po2 (30 mm Hg). At low P2 levels in fetal blood, the fetal haemoglobin can carry 20% to 50% more oxygen than can maternal haemoglobin.
  • The haemoglobin concentration of fetal blood is about 50% greater than that of the mother. This helps in enhancing the amount of oxygen transported to the fetal tissues.
  • According to the Bohr effect, haemoglobin can carry more oxygen at a low P2 than it can at a high P2. As the fetal blood reaches placenta, the CO2 diffuses from fetal to maternal blood, making the fetal blood alkaline, and maternal blood acidic. These changes increase the capacity of fetal blood to combine with oxygen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an early complication of fracture?
questions.solution:
Complex regional pain syndrome -CRPS(earlier known as Reflex sympathetic dystrophy or Sudeck's dystrophy or algodystrophy) is a late complication of fracture. Rest options are early complications

CRPS is divided into 2 types. CRPS type 1 occurs after trivial trauma or fracture and is explained below.

It occurs as a sequela of trauma and presents as a swollen, tender, and painful condition. It progressively undergoes atrophy of skin, muscle, and even nail over weeks resulting in fixed deformity at last. X-rays classically show spotty or patchy rarefaction. Earlier recognition and treatment initiation makes the prognosis relatively better.  Long term physiotherapy together with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs form the mainstay of treatment. Ganglion blockers in resistant cases can improve the condition.

CRPS type 2 is related to causalgia after nerve injury.

questions.text: Given below is the structure of malic acid. What will be the number of stereoisomers possible for this compound?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the chemical structure of malic acid having one asymmetric carbon atom. Using Van't Hoff rule, the number stereoisomers is 2 to the Power n (where n is the number of asymmetric carbon atoms). As there is only 1 asymmetric carbon here, A total of 2 stereoisomers will be possible.

Compounds having the same structural formula, but differing in the spatial configuration are known as stereoisomers.

Malic acid has 4 carbon atoms but just one of them is asymmetric. Asymmetric carbon means that four different groups are attached to the same carbon atom.

questions.text: A 25 year old male is brought by the police for suspected internal concealment of drugs. Abdominal X ray was unclear. CT scan showed smooth, well circumscribed foreign bodies measuring about 2-3 cm in the intestines. The patient is asymptomatic. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Single dose of activated charcoal and initiate whole bowel irrigation

questions.solution:
The givien clinical features are suggestive of this person being a body packer. Since he is asymptomatic, the next step in management would be to give single-dose activated charcoal and institute whole-bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol electrolyte solution to gently hasten packet elimination.

CT imaging is the best modality to identify cocaine packets in a body packer. 

  • Body stuffer: Patients who swallow cocaine following police pursuit to conceal the evidence are termed “body stuffers.” The swallowed packets are often poorly wrapped and can leak or perforate.
  • Body packers: swallow a large number of well-sealed packets in order to smuggle drugs across international borders.
  • Both methods can result in severe toxicity and death.
  • CT is the best imaging modality to identify the packets.
  • If the patient shows no signs of toxicity, give single-dose activated charcoal and institute whole-bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol electrolyte solution to gently hasten packet elimination.
  • For symptomatic patients, provide sedation and symptomatic care, and obtain immediate surgical consultation for operative removal of the packets.
  • Do not consult for endoscopy or colonoscopy because endoscopic manipulation may rupture the packets.

questions.text: An intern commits a negligent act in the hospital. You as his senior doctor will be held responsible for the negligent act as the intern is working under you. This is explained by _____.
questions.solution:
The senior doctor is responsible for the negligent act of a junior doctor, resident, intern, or assistant working under him by vicarious liability.

Vicarious liability is by which the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer).

When two doctors practice as partners, they are both responsible for each other's negligent acts. When 2 or more doctors independently attend a patient, each may be held liable for the negligence of others that he observes or in the ordinary course should have observed and allows it to continue without objection.

When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily loses his control over this worker and the borrowing employer temporarily assumes control. This is known as borrowed servant doctrine.

Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care from the patient's part or from the attendant. This act, along with the negligent act of the doctor has contributed to the injury. If there was no contributory negligence, the injury would not have occurred. The doctor's negligence is not the direct cause of the injury. Eg. refusal to take required treatment, getting discharged against the doctor's advice, etc.

Res ipsa loquitur in Latin means "the thing speaks for itself". If an untoward result happened that is thought to be due to deviation from the normal standards of care, or negligence, then the doctor should admit the problem. The doctor should take the responsibility to explain the issue to the patient and their family, and solve the problem by either initiating treatment or transferring care. There should be no charge for additional care or for further procedures.

questions.text:
Which of the following indicators and/or lab reports are required to assess the blood volume?

1. RBC count and 125I-albumin 2. 51Cr-labeled red blood cells 3. Evans blue and hematocrit 4. Inulin 5. Antipyrine
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 3 are correct.

Blood volume can be assessed by either of the following two methods:

  • 51Cr-labeled red blood cells: In this method RBCs labelled with radioactive material such as chromium (51Cr), are injected into the circulation. After the injected RBCs mix with the circulation, the radioactivity of the mixed blood sample is measured, and the blood volume is calculated by using the indicator-dilution principle.
  • Plasma volume and haematocrit: Plasma volume is measured using indicators such as Evans blue dye (also called T-1824), serum albumin labelled with radioactive iodine (125I-albumin). Haematocrit is the fraction of the total blood volume that is composed of the cells. Blood volume can be calculated from the plasma volume and haematocrit, by the formula:

Blood volume = Plasma volume / (1-hematocrit),

For example, if the plasma volume is 3 litres and haematocrit is 0.40, then,

Blood volume. = 3 / (1-0.4) = 3/0.6 = 30/6 = 5 litres.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with HIV-AIDS. His CD4 count is 46/mm3. Which of the following drugs is initially recommended for prophylaxis against M avium complex?
questions.solution:
Once weekly oral azithromycin is recommended.

Prophylaxis against M avium complex (MAC) in AIDS patients:

  • The prophylactic therapy against MAC in patients with a CD4 count < 50/mm3 is monotherapy with oral azithromycin 1200 mg once a week or clarithromycin 500 mg twice a day.
  • If the patient is intolerant to macrolides, then rifabutin can be administered.
  • If the CD4 count is >100/mm3 for three months, then, MAC prophylaxis should be discontinued.

Treatment:

Triple-drug-therapy for M avium complex regimen includes rifampicin, ethambutol, and a macrolide, like clarithromycin or azithromycin.

questions.text: In a child with a suspected foreign body in the trachea, which of the following investigations would be most useful in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a child with a tracheal foreign body, PA and lateral soft tissue neck X-ray(airway films) are abnormal in 92% of children. Whereas, the chest radiographs, are abnormal in only 58%.

A child with a tracheal foreign body will present mostly with aspiration, choking, stridor, and/or wheezing.

questions.text: Passive immunization can be given if an individual is unable to mount an immune response. In which of the following diseases hyperimmune immunoglobulins are not given?
questions.solution:
In Hepatitis A, pooled immunoglobulins are given, while in other options hyperimmune immunoglobulins are given.

Human sera are mainly of two types: Hyperimmune or Pooled immunoglobulins.

Hyperimmune globulins are antibodies that are extracted from the patients who are in convalescent or recovery phase. They have already formed antibodies against the disease pathogen. These antibodies can be used in patients who cannot mount an adequate immune response or the presentation is very acute. These type of antibodies are given in hepatitis B, tetanus, rabies, vaccinia, etc.

Other type of immunoglobulins used in passive immunization are pooled immunoglobulins. These are used for short term prophylaxis in case of hepatitis A or measles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about iodine-based contrast media?

choices.text: They do not interfere with the clotting times.
Iohexol is an ionic iodine-based contrast.
They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.
They are used in magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.solution:
Iodine-based contrast media are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media:

Iodine provides the radio-opacity, while the other compounds act as carriers of iodine. They are commonly used in angiography and computed tomography. They interfere with the clotting times. Hence, clotting tests are usually avoided until 6 hours after the administration of contrast media. They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media are classified as ionic and non-ionic, based on the nature of the compound to which the iodine is bound. Ionic media consists of iodine bound to inorganic compounds, while non-ionic media consists of iodine bound to an organic compound. The common examples of ionic and non-ionic iodine-based contrast media are iothalamate and iohexol, respectively.
