questions.text: A 52-year-old male with chronic kidney disease was found to have an elevated serum PTH concentration and a low serum concentration of 25-hydroxyvitamin D. He was treated with ergocalciferol. After few months, his kidney disease progressed and required maintenance hemodialysis and his serum PTH concentration became markedly elevated. Which of the following drugs can be used to lower the patient’s serum PTH concentration?
questions.solution:
The patient requires administration of calcitriol, which acts directly on parathyroid to inhibit the PTH production.

In patients with CKD requiring hemodialysis, there is impaired production of active vitamin D due to the reduced activity of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase that converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D  to its more active form 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). As a result, there is deficiency of the active form of vitamin D. This causes impaired absorption of calcium from the GIT.

The decreased serum calcium levels trigger the secretion of PTH, which maintains the calcium level through resorption of the bone. Also, these patients have elevated serum phosphate due to renal impairment, which leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Administration of the calcitriol acts directly on the parathyroid to inhibit PTH production. Cholecalciferol is not effective in patients with advanced renal disease who cannot form adequate amounts of active vitamin D metabolites.

questions.text: A male patient complains of a foreign body sensation, irritation, and lacrimation in the right eye. During the evaluation, you notice the following findings with normal lid margins. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the above image is suggestive of trichiasis.

Trichiasis refers to the inward misdirection of cilia, which usually rub against the eyeball with the normal position of the lid margin. These patients present with foreign body sensations and photophobia. They experience troublesome irritation, pain, and lacrimation.  On examination, one or more misdirected cilia touching the cornea are seen. The conjunctiva may be congested.

Treatment includes:

  • Epilation: Mechanical removal with forceps
  • Electrolysis: Method of destroying the lash follicle by electric current.
  • Cryoepilation
  • Surgical correction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old athlete presents with posterior shoulder pain and paresthesia over the right lateral arm. Following the investigations, after excluding all other causes, you diagnose it as quadrangular space syndrome due to hypertrophy of Teres major. This hypertrophied muscle forms which boundary of the quadrangular space?
questions.solution:
Teres Major forms the inferior boundary of the Quadrangular space.

Quadrangular space (Foramen of Velpeau) is a passageway for the nerves and vessels between the axilla anteriorly and the scapular region posteriorly.

Boundaries: Formed by 4 borders (Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral):

  • Superiorly by Capsule of the Shoulder joint, Teres Minor
  • Inferiorly by Teres Major
  • Medially by the Long head of Triceps and
  • Laterally by Surgical Neck of Humerus.

Contents: Axillary nerve and Posterior circumflex humeral artery and vein.

Quadrangular space syndrome: The condition is caused by hypertrophy or fibrosis of the quadrangular space muscles which impinge on the axillary nerve. The patient presents with weakness of the shoulder movements. Since many other conditions can mimic QSS, it is often a diagnosis of exclusion. Conservative treatment is often first trialled, including physical exercise modification, physical therapy, and therapeutic massage. If unrelieved by conservative measures, surgical decompression of the quadrilateral space may be indicated.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy with developmental delay and seizures was diagnosed with Lennox Gastaut syndrome. On performing an EEG, which of the following is not a typical EEG finding that you would expect to see?

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male came to the emergency department with complaints of fever, low backache, and swollen legs. He gives a history of passing dark brown colored urine multiple times in the past 24 hours. This began after strenuous training in the gym. The investigation results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of acute renal failure?
  • Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL,
  • Potassium 6.8 mEq/L
  • Creatine kinase: elevated
  • Urine dipstick: hematuria present
  • Urinalysis: no cells or casts
questions.solution:
The clinical features and laboratory findings are suggestive of acute renal failure due to rhabdomyolysis.

Rhabdomyolysis is a severe life-threatening condition, caused due to skeletal muscle damage. 

Causative factors include:

  • Traumatic crush injuries
  • Muscle ischemia during vascular or orthopedic surgery
  • Compression during coma or immobilization
  • Prolonged seizure activity
  • Excessive or strenuous exercise
  • Heatstroke or malignant hyperthermia
  • Infections
  • Metabolic disorders such as hypophosphatemia or severe hypothyroidism
  • Myopathies (drug-induced, metabolic, or inflammatory).

Skeletal muscle damage causes excessive release of myoglobin, which acts as an endogenous toxin and can cause acute renal failure.

Laboratory features include elevated myoglobin, and creatine kinase. Hematuria on dipstick examination without red cells indicates the presence of myoglobin. Cellular damage in rhabdomyolysis causes increased blood levels of intracellular ions such as potassium and phosphate.

Other options:

Option A: Acute interstitial nephritis is seen in patients who had recent exposure to medications such as PPIs, NSAIDs, and antibiotics. Laboratory features include eosinophilia, and sterile pyuria. It is often non-oligiuric.

Option B: The laboratory features in hemolytic uremic syndrome include schistocytes on the peripheral blood smear, elevated LDH, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Acute kidney injury due to athero-embolic disease occurs in patients who had recent manipulation of the aorta or other large vessels. It may occur spontaneously or after anticoagulation therapy. Clinical features include retinal plaques, palpable purpura, livedo reticularis, GI bleeding. Investigations reveal hypocomplementemia, eosinophiluria, and variable amounts of proteinuria.

questions.text: Mr X suffered a sudden collapse in a busy market. CPR was attempted by locals presuming cardiac arrest and shifted promptly to nearby hospital. He still suffered death. What could be the possible reason?
questions.solution:
In patients on whom CPR is attempted but still suffer death, brain injury is the most common cause.

The guidelines are being developed, so that we may know which patient has more chances of survival after the brain injury. This is done by multimodal neuroprognostication. It should be done after initial stabilization of the patient and at least 72 hours after normothermia is achieved.

Brain injury, commonly manifested as a comatose state, is a marker of poor outcome and a major basis for unfavourable neurological prognostication. In such cases, when the poor outcome is inevitable, CPR would be futile.

Newer approaches for neuroprognostication are needed to save futile attempts in patients already having a poor outcome.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a history of Raynaud’s phenomenon that has worsened over the past 6 months. She noticed hard whitish bumps over her thumb, as shown in the image. She also reports joint pains involving her hands and wrists and difficulty in swallowing solid food. On examination, there is a hardening of the skin of the hands with claw-like appearance. Laboratory study reveals high titers of anticentromere antibodies. What is the most likely condition involving her hands?
questions.solution:
Calcinosis cutis is a condition in which calcium salts are deposited in the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The combination of calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia, is termed CREST syndrome. This syndrome is a variant of systemic sclerosis.

Dystrophic calcification is the most common cause of calcinosis cutis and is associated with normal laboratory values of calcium and phosphorus. It may involve the skin, subcutaneous, and soft tissues and occur in about 40% of the patients, most commonly seen in patients with long-standing anti-centromere antibody-positive limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc).

The calcific deposits are composed of calcium hydroxyapatite crystals and vary in size from small punctate lesions to large masses. The deposits usually occur in tissues damaged due to inflammation, hypoxia, and local trauma. They can be visualized on plain radiography and dual-energy CT.

Calcinosis cutis is commonly seen over the finger pads, palms, extensor surfaces of the forearms, and the olecranon and prepatellar bursae. The lesions cause pain and nerve compression. They may ulcerate through the skin, cause drainage of chalky-white material, and lead to secondary infections.

questions.text: In a 65-year-old female patient with carcinoma of the breast, overexpression of which of the following miRNAs will be linked with her condition?
questions.solution:
Overexpression of miR-21 is linked with cancers of the lung and breast. Other options are tumor suppressor miRNAs, whose underexpression may lead to cancer.

microRNAs (miRs):

  • Small non-coding, single-stranded RNAs, approximately 22 nucleotides in length
  • Mediate inhibition of messenger RNA (mRNA) translation through the action of the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  • Control normal cell growth, differentiation, and cell survival
  • miRNA can be of 2 types:
    • Tumor-suppressive miRNAs: Increased expression of certain miRs decreases the translation of oncogenic mRNAs.
    • Oncogenic-miRNAs: Overexpression of some miRs represses tumor-suppressor genes, promoting tumor development.

They are frequently found altered in various cancers. Oncogenic-miRNAs are overexpressed while tumor suppressor miRNAs are found to be underexpressed. They might serve as potential targets of chemotherapy, where oligonucleotides are used to enhance the expression of tumor suppressor miRNAs or antisense oligonucleotides are used to counter onco-miRNAs. They might also serve as biomarkers for diagnosis, classification and prognostication of various cancers.

List of oncogenic-miRNAs:

  • miR -17-92: ca lung, breast, pancreas, colon
  • miR -21: ca lung, breast
  • miR 155: ca lung and lymphoma

List of tumor suppressor miRNAs:

  • miR -15 and miR -16: CLL
  • let7: ovarian and lung cancer
  • miR - 34: various cancers

Other noncoding RNAs:

  • piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs): the most common type of small noncoding RNAs; involved in post-transcriptional gene silencing.
  • sncRNAs: maturation of rRNA and the assembly of ribosomes and long, intervening, non-coding RNAs.
  • lncRNAs: regulate the activity of chromatin “writers,” which modify histones and thus control gene expression.

questions.text: A child with severe mental retardation was found to have a total absence of myelin in the central nervous system. Laboratory investigations reveal the accumulation of galactosylceramide. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Krabbe’s disease and the enzyme deficient in this disease is β-galactosidase. 

Sphingolipidoses are a group of lysosomal storage disorders characterized by the accumulation of sphingolipids. Krabbe’s disease is an autosomal-recessive sphingolipidosis. It is a neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to a deficiency in β-galactosidase.

Galactosylceramide is the main content in a myelin sheath. It is synthesized by oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells by galactosylation of ceramide. It is broken down by the enzyme β-galactosidase, a lysosomal hydrolase.

In Krabbe’s disease due to deficiency of the enzyme β-galactosidase, galactosylceramide accumulates in oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. This accumulation causes the formation of globoid cells (hematogenous often-multinucleated macrophages containing undigested galactosylceramide). This results in the destruction of oligodendroglia and hence total loss of myelin in the central nervous system.

The image given below shows globoid cells seen in Krabbe's disease.

It is characterized by mental retardation, irritability, tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation, seizures, hypertonia, and later flaccidity. Optic atrophy is also present. Investigations reveal increased protein in the CSF.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been found to be effective as a treatment modality for Krabbe's disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman was diagnosed with Burkitt lymphoma. Cytogenetic studies demonstrated a t (8;14) chromosomal translocation. Which of the following best explains the role of this translocation in the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
The activation of the proto-oncogene MYC due to translocation is mainly responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

In Burkitt lymphoma, the MYC gene is translocated from its normal locus 8q24 to chromosome 14q32. The MYC gene at its normal locus is controlled and expressed in actively dividing cells. When the MYC gene is moved to 14q32, it is usually placed close to the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) gene. This movement is associated with the loss of regulatory sequences of the MYC gene, which are replaced by the control regions of the IGH gene, which is highly expressed in the B cells. The translocation is denoted as t (8;14) (q24; q32).

As a result, the MYC coding sequence is intact with the loss of regulatory control. The activation of the proto-oncogene leads to overexpression of the MYC protein, which is responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text: You shifted to the USA for research opportunities after MBBS. The government there targets massive influenza vaccination to protect you against the flu. Which of the following is true

choices.text: The flu vaccine helps prevent occurence of seasonal epidemic
The flu vaccine helps prevent occurence of pandemic
The flu vaccine does not provide immunity against influenza because it undergoes antigenic drift
The flu vaccine provides lifelong immunity against the influenza

questions.solution:
Flu vaccine takes into account antigenic drift and is able to provide cross-protection. It hence prevents the occurrence of seasonal epidemics.

Influenza virus undergoes antigenic variation in its surface proteins (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase). Antigenic drift causes a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure.

Antigenic Shift Antigenic drift
Results in pandemics and major epidemics Results in periodic epidemic and sporadic cases

Flu vaccine needs to be massively revised to be effective Flu vaccine may provide cross-protection against a similar antigen
Occurs every 10- 20 years Occurs every 2- 3 years.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents to the psychiatric OPD with a persistent and significant sense of discomfort regarding his anatomic sex(male) and a feeling that it is inappropriate to his perceived-gender(female). What do you think is the most likely term that suits the gender identity disorder in this case?
questions.solution:
Transsexualism is the gender identity disorder in this case.

Transsexualism is the severest form of gender identity disorders. It is characterized by:

  • Normal anatomic sex.
  • A persistent and significant sense of discomfort regarding one’s anatomic sex and a feeling that it is inappropriate to one’s perceived-gender.
  • Constant wish to get rid of one’s genitals and secondary sex characteristics, and to adopt sex characteristics of the other sex (perceived-gender).
  • Diagnosis is made after puberty.

It is of two types:

  1. Primary: onset in early childhood and they are more preoccupied with sex-change or sex-reassignment surgery than the secondary type.
  2. Secondary: onset is later in life and less severe and more heterogeneous category.

Other options:

  • Transvestism: People who wear clothing traditionally associated with the opposite gender.
  • Intersexuality: The patients with this disorder have gross anatomical and/or physiological aspects of the other sex.
  • Gender identity disorder: This is similar to transsexualism but is characterized by an early age of onset (2-4 years of age) and a strong denial of anatomic sex accompanying the distress, unlike transsexualism where there is no denial associated with the distress.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with lesions on her face as shown in the image. Similar lesions were absent in the chest and back. What management plan is suitable for her?
questions.solution:
The image shows typical erythematous papules and small nodules along with a few whiteheads are suggestive of moderate acne vulgaris. It should be treated with oral antibiotics and topical retinoids.

The severity of acne can be classified as:

Mild Open and closed comedones with few inflammatory papules and pustules
Moderate Papules and pustules mainly on the face, occasional inflamed nodules on the chest and back also
Severe Many large, painful nodules and pustules

The clinical severity and approach to treatment are decided based on the type of lesion and based on extensiveness.

Only comedonal types can be treated with topical retinoids.

Papulopustular type can be treated with topical retinoid combined with an antibiotic (topical or oral) based on severity. More oily skin and the occurrence of nodules should prompt oral antibiotics.

Nodular or conglobate type can be treated with oral isotretinoin.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has been recently approved by FDA for the treatment of HIV-1 infection?
questions.solution:
Fostemsavir has been recently approved (2020) by FDA for the treatment of HIV-1 (human immunodeficiency virus-1) infection.

Fostemsavir is an HIV-1 gp120-directed attachment inhibitor. It is used in combination with other antiretrovirals. It is indicated in patients with multi-drug resistant HIV-1 infection whose current antiretroviral agents have failed due to resistance, intolerance or safety considerations.

It is available as 600mg extended-release tablets. The recommended dosage is one tablet taken twice daily with or without food.

It is contraindicated in patients with a prior hypersensitivity reaction. Co-administration with strong cytochrome (CYP) P450 and CYP 3A inducers is not indicated as it may cause a significant reduction in the plasma concentration of fostemsavir.

Adverse reactions to this drug include immune reconstitution syndrome. In some patients, especially with hepatitis B or C virus co-infection, the plasma transaminase levels may be elevated. Fostemsavir should be given with caution in patients with a history of QTc prolongation or with relevant pre-existing cardiac disease or those taking drugs with a known risk of Torsade de Pointes. 

Other options:

Option B: Maftivimab has been recently approved (2020) by the FDA as part of a combination drug containing atoltivimab, maftivimab, and odesivimab-ebgn for the treatment of the Ebola virus.

Option C: Baloxavir in combination with marboxil got FDA approval in 2018 to treat acute uncomplicated influenza in patients who have been symptomatic for no more than 48 hours.

Option D: Tecovirimat got FDA approval in 2018 to treat smallpox.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz

  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

questions.text: Which of the following is not characteristic of the disease shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The images shows zebra pattern that is seen in Fabry's disease, which causes nephrotic syndrome (not nephritic syndrome).

Fabry's disease 

  • X-linked recessive disorder of globotriaosylceramide metabolism secondary to deficient lyososmal alpha galactosidase A activity resulting in excessive intracellular storage of globotriaosylceramide 
  • Classically it presents in childhood with acroparathesias, angiokeratoma, and hypohydrosis
  • Over time patients develop restrictive cardiomyopahty 
  • Renal biopsy reveals enlarged glomerular visceral epithelial cells packed with small clear vacuoles containing globotriaosylceramide. These vacuoles are arranged in parallel arrays known as zebra bodies which can be easily seen on electron microscopy
  • On urine analysis, oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarised light are seen known as maltese cross.
  • Treatment is recombinant alpha galactosidase A.

questions.text: A senior resident asks you to incise and drain the abscess in a 20-year-old student during your surgery postings. Which of the following blades you would use for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The blade marked as '2' in the image, represents the 11 size-blade which is often used to incise and drain the abscess.

11 size-surgical blade has an oblique edge with a sharp pointed tip and hence it is known as "Stab knife".

Uses:

  • Commonly used to incise skin, subcutaneous tissue, deep fascia to open the abscess cavity in a single stroke, during  I & D of an abscess.
  • This blade can also be used for arteriotomy.

Other options:

The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions.

The 15-blade is often used for minor surgical procedures.

questions.text: A young man presented with a rapidly moving serpiginous track like erythema as shown below. It started perianally and has spread in a few hours.  Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given clinical picture and history points towards a diagnosis of larva currens.

The term larva currens (meaning ‘racing larvae’) has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. They move rapidly as fast as (up to 10cm/hr)

Other options:

Scabietic burrows caused by itch mite of scabies due to laying of eggs are also serpiginous in form but do not move rapidly as described in the question. They usually follow the circle of hebra.

Flagellate dermatitis is a misnomer as there is no flagellated organism involved. It is rather caused as a side effect of anticancer drug bleomycin

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by hookworms (except Ancylostoma duodenal or necator americanus). It may look serpiginous but does not move as rapid as larva currens.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman suddenly develops dyspnea, cyanosis, and hypotension during the vaginal delivery of a full-term infant. She develops generalized seizures and passes into a coma. Her condition continues to remain unstable. Lung biopsy revealed the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present in her lungs?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid embolism is a condition in which the amniotic fluid that surrounds a fetus in the uterus during pregnancy enters the mother's bloodstream through a tear in the placental membranes or rupture of uterine veins. Though this condition is uncommon, it has high morbidity and mortality. It also results in permanent neurologic disability in 85% of the survivors.

The classic autopsy finding shows the maternal pulmonary microvasculature filled with shed fetal epithelial squamous cells, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract.

The above picture shows pulmonary arterioles packed with laminated swirls of fetal squamous cells. There is marked edema and congestion. Small thrombi are visible consistent with disseminated intravascular coagulation.

Other options:

Aggregates of platelets represent localized thrombosis, an unlikely event in the lungs.

Fat globules are seen in fat embolism, usually after severe trauma. 

Gas bubbles in vessels from air embolism can be a rare event in some obstetric procedures, but it is an unlikely event in natural deliveries.

questions.text: A high-resolution CT image of the chest is shown below. Which of the following conditions is it most likely suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The HRCT image shows sandstorm appearance and black pleura sign characteristic of pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis.

Pulmonary alveolar microlithiasis occurs due to the deposition of small calcium and phosphate stones (<3mm) within the alveoli. The stones are of unknown origin.

Radiological features:

  • CXR/CT shows widespread, discrete, high-density opacities, resembling the grains of sand in both the lungs. The appearance is commonly described as sand-storm appearance.
  • Profuse infiltration may appear as white-out, with obscuration of the heart borders and diaphragm.
  • The presence of small cysts (5-10 mm) or paraseptal emphysema, may cause the pleura to appear a black, lucent line lying between the pulmonary infiltrate and the adjacent ribs, referred to as ‘black-pleura sign’.
  • Bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities with nodular thickening along the fissures and interlobar septa produce a crazy-paving pattern.

questions.text: Four drugs A, B, C, and D are being studied in research. Drugs A and B are full agonists while drugs C and D are partial agonists. Based on the EC50 values given for each drug, select the drug which is most potent and efficacious.
questions.solution:
Drug B with EC50 = 5, is the most potent and efficacious drug.

Potency of the drug is defined as the ability of a drug to produce a desired response at minimal concentration. Greater the potency, lesser is the concentration of the drug required to produce a response. To compare potency of two drugs, the concentration required to achieve half the maximal response, usually denoted as EC50 is commonly used. Therefore, drug with lesser EC50 is more potent.

Efficacy is the ability of a drug to produce the maximal desired response. A drug with high efficacy may be a full agonist, which produces a full response (100%), while, a drug with lower efficacy may be a partial agonist, which doesn't produce a full response (between 0% and 100%) at any dose. An antagonist is a drug that binds to a receptor and exhibits zero efficacy (0%).

In the given example, Drugs A and B are full agonists, thus they are more efficacious than drugs C and D.

Among the drugs A and B, drug B has the least EC-50, hence is more potent than drug A.

Therefore, drug B is the most efficacious and potent.

questions.text: The image below shows the effect of a drug 'X on blood pressure and heart rate. The drug 'X' is likely to be:
questions.solution:
The drug shown in this kymograph tracing is phenylephrine.

  • Phenylephrine is a pure alpha-adrenergic agonist.
  • By means of acting over α1, it increases the peripheral arterial resistance, and decreases the capacity of venous capacitance vessels, leading to an increased venous return to the heart.
  • However, the cardiac action is negligible by pure alpha-agonist except for minor inotropic action.
  • There is baroreceptor reflex mediated increase in vagal tone due to which there is marked bradycardia. However, due to increased venous return, stroke volume remains high and so is cardiac output.
  • There is a minor effect of α2 over vasoconstriction, as the primary location of such receptors is in the central nervous system.

Other options:

  • Epinephrine and norepinephrine are non-selective and activate both α and β receptors.
  • Isoproterenol is a very potent beta-receptor agonist with very little action over the alpha receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is ansa cervicalis and thyrohyoid is not supplied by it. Thyrohyoid is supplied by the C1 fibers through the hypoglossal nerve.

The muscles supplied by ansa cervicalis are:

  • Sternothyroid
  • Sternohyoid
  • Omohyoid both inferior and superior belly

The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop embedded in the anterior wall of the carotid sheath. It is formed by two roots:

  • The superior root is a continuation of the descending branch of the hypoglossal nerve. It is derived from the 1st cervical nerve (C1) and supplies the superior belly of the omohyoid.
  • The inferior root is derived from the 2nd and 3rd cervical spinal nerves (C2, C3).

questions.text: A child, while playing in a field, stepped his right foot over a sharp-pointed stone. Immediately, as a reflex action, he lifted his right leg and extended the left leg. The action of the left leg is attributable to which of the following reflexes?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, when the right foot is placed on the sharp stone, the right leg is lifted off due to the flexor withdrawal reflex, while the left leg is extended due to the crossed-extensor reflex.

When a painful stimulus is applied to a limb, then the limb is immediately flexed to pull away from the danger. This reflex is called the flexion withdrawal reflex. Within 0.2 to 0.5 seconds, the extensor muscles of the opposite limb contract, to shift the weight of the body onto the other side, in the case of the lower limb, or to push the dangerous stimulus away from the body. This reflex is called the crossed-extensor reflex.

After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has a longer period of after-discharge when compared to the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells.

The image below shows the flexor reflex

The image below shows the crossed extensor reflex

Other options:

Option A- The patellar tendon reflex, which is activated by tapping the patellar tendon, is a type of stretch reflex.

Option C- Positive supportive reaction is a primitive postural reflex, wherein the pressure applied on the footpad causes extension of the limb.

Option D- The Golgi tendon reflex provides a negative feedback mechanism that prevents the development of excessive tension in a muscle.

questions.text: A young woman presented to the emergency with epistaxis due to multiple episodes of continuous violent sneezes. To control the bleeding the following technique was performed as shown in the image given below. This method helps her to control bleeding from the septal branches of all of the following arteries, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image shows Trotter’s method. This method helps her to control bleeding from all of the given arteries, except the septal branch of the posterior ethmoidal artery. 

Trotter's method is a step to control epistaxis from Little’s area. Here, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth and pinching the nose with the thumb and index finger for about 5 minutes. The septal branch of the posterior ethmoidal artery does not take part in the vascular anastomoses seen in this area. Hence, it fails to prevent bleeding from this artery.

Little’s area is situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults. Septal branches of four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus. The arteries include:

  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery
  • Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine artery

Note: Woodruff's plexus is a site of posterior epistaxis in adults. It is a plexus of veins situated inferior to the posterior end of inferior turbinate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient is very conscious about her body image. She started a diet having only 20 g per day of carbohydrate or less, but with unlimited consumption of fats and proteins. Her previous diet usually had an average of 100-120 g/day of carbohydrate. What will be the effect of this new diet plan?

choices.text: Inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes weight loss
Increases gluconeogenesis and promotes weight loss
Inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes weight gain
Increases gluconeogenesis and promotes weight gain

questions.solution:
The given patient has adopted a very low carbohydrate diet as a new diet plan and this promotes weight loss and gluconeogenesis.

A very low carbohydrate diet, that is less than or equal to 20 grams per day of carbohydrates with unlimited consumption of fat and protein, has been promoted as an effective regime for weight loss. Since a lower amount of carbohydrates are consumed and there is a continual demand for glucose, gluconeogenesis from amino acids occurs. The associated high ATP cost is then met by the oxidation of fatty acids.

A ketogenic diet is similar. It consists of high fats, moderate proteins, and very low carbohydrates. In a 2000 kcal per day ketogenic diet, carbohydrates should be 20-50 grams per day.

When there is low carbohydrate availability, gluconeogenesis and ketogenesis come into action. When glucose availability drops further and, the endogenous gluconeogenesis cannot keep up with the needs of the body, ketogenesis begins. Ketone bodies replace glucose as a primary source of energy.

During ketogenesis, due to low blood glucose feedback, insulin secretion is also low, which reduces fat and glucose storage. There is also an increased breakdown of fats that result in fatty acids, which get metabolized to ketone bodies. This metabolic state is referred to as 'nutritional ketosis.' The nutritional ketosis state is considered safe, as ketone bodies are produced in small concentrations without changes in blood pH.

questions.text: When found in water source, the organism in the image indicates remote contamination of water. The organism is:
questions.solution:
Clostridium perfringens is an indicator of remote contamination of water. Whereas, Faecal streptococci indicates recent contamination of water.

E. coli is the most important bacterial indicator of water quality.

Multiple tube method is test to estimate the Most Probable Number (MPN) of coliform organisms in 100 ml water sample

The test is done by inoculating measured quantities of water sample in MacConkey's Lactose Bile Salt broth with Bromocresol blue as the indicator.

questions.text: A diagnosis of retinal detachment is made in a patient who presented with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision. A senior resident shows Shaffer's sign to all the interns, which is seen in this patient. As you were one of the interns, you were shown _________

choices.text: Presence of shifting fluid in superonasal retinal breaks
Presence of shifting fluid in superotemporal retinal breaks
Presence of pigment cells in posterior vitreous
Presence of pigment cells in anterior vitreous

questions.solution:
Shaffer’s sign seen on slit-lamp examination refers to the presence of pigment cells in anterior vitreous in the case of rhegmatous retinal detachment.

It is also known as tobacco dusting.

Retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

Retinal detachment is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment: Fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina.
  • Tractional retinal detachment: Fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing vitreous hemorrhage exert traction on the retina.
  • Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative fluid from the choroid, collects in the subretinal space, leading to retinal detachment.

Note:

Shifting fluid sign is seen in serous or exudative retinal detachment.

In serous retinal detachment, there is a subretinal accumulation of the serous fluid mostly due to the breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier. When the position of the head is altered, the fluid shifts to the dependent portion.

questions.text: Ripretinib is a new drug, recently approved by FDA for the treatment of _________
questions.solution:
Ripretinib has been recently approved by FDA in 2020, for the treatment of advanced gastrointestinal-stromal tumors. It is the first-new drug specifically approved as a fourth-line treatment for GIST.

It is a kinase inhibitor indicated for the treatment of patients with GIST, who have received prior treatment with 3 or more kinase inhibitors, including imatinib.

Adverse reactions:

  • In patients who develop Palmar-Plantar Erythrodysesthesia Syndrome, the drug should be withheld, or dose reduced.
  • Some patients may develop new cutaneous malignancies.
  • It should be given with caution in patients with uncontrolled hypertension, and cardiac dysfunction, as it may aggravate the conditions.
  • The drug may delay wound healing. Hence, it should be withheld for at least week before and 2 weeks after a surgery.
  • It should be avoided in pregnant woman, as it may cause fetal toxicity.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon while performing stapedectomy in a patient uses the endomeatal approach by putting a small vertical incision at 12 o’clock position near the annulus and a curvilinear incision starting at 6 o’clock position to meet the first incision in the posterosuperior region of the canals, 5–7 mm away from the annulus as shown in the below image. The incision being used in this patient is:
questions.solution:
The incision being used in the above patient is Rosen's incision.

Rosen’s incision is the most commonly used for stapedectomy. It consists of two parts:

  • A small vertical incision at 12 o’clock position near the annulus and,
  • A curvilinear incision starting at 6 o’clock position to meet the first incision in the posterosuperior region of the canals, 5–7 mm away from the annulus

Rosen’s incision is used for endomeatal approach or transcanal approach to the middle ear.

It is also used for exploratory tympanotomy to find the cause of conductive hearing loss.

Other options:

Lempert I and II incision: Used in Endaural approach

  • Lempert I is a semicircular incision, made from 12 o’clock to 6 o’clock position in the posterior meatal wall at the bony–cartilaginous junction.
  • Lempert II start from the initial incision made at 12 o’clock. It then passes upwards in a curvilinear fashion between the tragus and the crus of the helix. As the incision passes through the incisura terminalis, it does not cut the cartilage.

Wilde’s incision: Postaural approach

  • It starts at the highest attachment of the pinna and follows the curve of retroauricular groove, lying 1 cm behind it. The incision ends at the mastoid tip.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist suspects endometriosis. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the investigation that will be most helpful in the diagnosis is laparoscopy.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. The patient usually presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. The presence of puckered spots in the posterior fornix is pathognomonic of endometriosis. It is an estrogen-dependent disease of the childbearing age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary, followed by the pouch of Douglas.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/tattooing seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas. 

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation, removal.

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels are raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels are raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an echo-free cyst, low level echoes or clumps of high-density level echoes representing clots.

The image below shows powder burns/tattooing appearance of endometriosis on diagnostic laparoscopy.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text:
According to the recent guidelines published by ECS (European cardiology society) for the diagnosis and management of Non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS), routine measurement of which of the following biomarkers is not required if the hs-cTn is measured?

1. CK 2. CK-MB 3. h-FABP
questions.solution:
According to the recent guidelines published by ESC (European Society of Cardiology), for diagnostic purposes of Non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS), hs-cTn (high-sensitivity cardiac troponin) should be used, and it is not recommended to routinely measure additional biomarkers such as CK, CK-MB, h-FABP, or copeptin.

The advent of high-sensitivity cardiac troponin (hs-Ctn), has made it the preferred modality to cardiac specific troponins T (cTnT), and I (cTnI).

Other major recommendations for diagnosis of NSTE-ACS include:

  • Cardiac computed tomography angiography (CCTA) is recommended as an alternative to invasive angiography to exclude ACS, when there is less likelihood of CAD, or if the cTn and ECG are inconclusive.
  • Rhythm monitoring is required up-to 24 hours or up to performing PCI, for patients with low risk of arrhythmias, and >24 hours for patients with increased risk of arrhythmias.

questions.text: Given below is a dissected heart specimen of a middle-aged man showing the internal structure of the right atrium and ventricle. The structures marked as 1 and 2 are the remnants of which of the following structures respectively?
questions.solution:
The structures marked as 1 and 2 are the limbus and floor of fossa ovalis, which are the remnants of septum secundum and septum primum respectively.

Fossa ovalis is an oval-shaped depression in the septal wall of the right atrium just above the opening of the inferior vena cava. It marks the location of the embryonic foramen ovale. 

  • The floor of fossa ovalis is the remnant of the septum primum.
  • The limbus of the fossa ovalis is the prominent upper margin of the fossa ovalis. It is a remnant of the septum secundum.

Related Pearl: Development of Interatrial septum

  • The Inter-atrial septum develops from Septum Primum and Septum Secundum
  • The septum primum begins to develop at 28 days. It is a thin, crescentic fold of endocardium that arises craniodorsally and grows down to the AV cushions, leaving an ostium primum below its free edge.
  • Septum primum fuses with the AV cushions at approximately 35 days, obliterating the ostium primum.
  • The ostium secundum is an opening in the upper part of the septum primum. It forms at about 33 days, i.e., before the ostium primum closes.
  • The septum secundum is a thick muscular septum that arises to the right of the septum primum. It grows from the roof of the atrium but does not reach the AV cushion. The gap between the two septa is known as foramen ovale.
  • After birth, the foramen ovale is obliterated by the fusion of the septum primum with the septum secundum.
  • In terms of adult anatomy, the annulus ovalis/limbus of fossa ovalis is the lower free edge of the septum secundum, while the floor of fossa ovalis represents the septum primum.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with weakness and muscle cramps involving both legs. He also reported difficulty in swallowing food. On examination, he is found to be alert and oriented. Both lower limbs exhibit fasciculations with significant atrophy and extensor plantar reflex. The reflexes in both upper and lower limbs are exaggerated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a type of progressive motor neuron disease. The pathological hallmark is the destruction and death of both upper (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN). Irrespective of what is involved first, eventually ALS will involve both UMN and LMN. The motor neuron disease involving selectively the upper motor neurons is called primary lateral sclerosis, while the one involving selectively the lower motor neurons is called spinomuscular atrophy.

Patients present with insidious onset asymmetric bilateral weakness of the distal part of the lower limbs. There may be a history of cramping, particularly early in the morning. Lower motor neuron death causes muscle atrophy and fasciculations. Upper motor neuron involvement presents as exaggerated tendon reflexes and spasticity. Some of the patients also tend to develop frontotemporal dementia. However, the sensory, bowel and bladder functions and cognition is preserved even in the late stages of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Guillain-Barre syndrome is an acute inflammatory demyelinating peripheral neuropathy that occurs 1-3 weeks following an acute infectious process. It results in LMN type of palsy with the absence of deep tendon reflexes. It is also associated with sensory findings like loss of proprioception and autonomic features such as lability of blood pressure. These findings are absent in ALS because only the motor neurons are involved.

Option B: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to abnormalities in the posterior and lateral column function that results in loss of vibration and position sense, progressive spastic weakness, and sensory ataxia. Loss of deep tendon reflexes due to associated peripheral neuropathy can also be seen. However, there is an extensor plantar response due to the involvement of the corticospinal tracts.

Option C: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is a paraneoplastic neuromuscular disorder that presents with proximal muscle weakness, arreflexia, and autonomic dysfunction. In 60% of patients, there may be associated cancer, usually small cell lung cancer.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with complaints of cough with sputum, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. There is a history of repeated lung and sinus infections since childhood. His BMI is 18 kg/m2 and has bilateral nasal polyps. Both lungs have coarse rhonchi and a chest radiograph shows evidence of bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis. To confirm the suspected diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, which of the following is the next best investigation of choice?

choices.text: Isolation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on repeated sputum cultures

questions.solution:
In a suspected case of cystic fibrosis, a sweat chloride value is the investigation of choice. Values >60 mmol/L are diagnostic. 

The primary clinical manifestations of cystic fibrosis (CF) are due to the effects of the mutated cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, and pancreas. This protein is a large transmembrane protein involved in the transport of chloride and other ions. Hence, abnormalities of the CFTR lead to abnormalities of salt and water transport.

In the lungs, abnormal CFTR leads to thick, sticky mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance. The patient will have recurrent respiratory infections with the development of bronchiectasis.

The standard test commonly performed to diagnose CF is the sweat chloride test. Elevated values are pathognomonic of this condition, with a cut-off of >60 mmol/L in adults being diagnostic. Values in the range 30–59 mmol/L fall within the indeterminate range.

A large number of mutations can cause CF, therefore genetic testing can be expensive and is not the first test performed for diagnosis when CF is suspected. A negative sweat chloride test does not exclude the diagnosis. In case of high suspicion of CF and a negative sweat test, alternative diagnostic studies such as measurement of nasal membrane potential difference, semen analysis, or assessment of pancreatic function may be done. All patients diagnosed with cystic fibrosis should undergo CFTR genotyping.

Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is common in adults with CF but is not specific for the diagnosis because bronchiectasis from any other cause can lead to P. aeruginosa infection.

Categories of CFTR mutations

Classes of defects in the CFTR gene include:

  • the absence of synthesis (class I)
  • defective protein maturation and premature degradation (class II)
  • disordered gating/regulation, such as diminished adenosine triphosphate (ATP) binding and hydrolysis (class III)
  • defective conductance through the ion channel pore (class IV)
  • a reduced number of CFTR transcripts due to a promoter or splicing abnormality (class V)
  • accelerated turnover from the cell surface (class VI).

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your OPD with lesions as shown below. The parent says he also had similar lesions in childhood. The lesions are present on the forearm, face, and flexures and are very itchy on the background of dry skin showing signs of lichenification. Grattage test or scratching reveals oozing of serous fluid. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image showing eczematous lesions on the forearm, and flexures. This along with the history of them being very itchy and being located on the dry skin showing signs of lichenification and a grattage test revealing oozing of serous fluid points towards atopic dermatitis as the likely diagnosis.

Atopic dermatitis can be divided into 3 phases: Infantile, childhood, and adult phases.

Infantile phase: The lesions of Atopic Eczema most frequently start on the face but may occur anywhere on the skin surface. Often, the napkin area is relatively spared.

  • When the child begins to crawl, the exposed surfaces, especially the extensor aspect of the knees and elbows are most involved.
  • The lesions consist of erythema and discrete or confluent oedematous papules. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.
  • Secondary infection and lymphadenopathy are common.

Childhood Phase: From 18 to 24 months onwards, the sites most characteristically involved are the elbow and knee flexures, a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper‐ and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification may be seen depending on the skin type on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles.

  • The sides of the neck may show a striking reticulate pigmentation, sometimes referred to as atopic dirty neck.
  • The erythematous and oedematous papules tend to be replaced by lichenification.

Adult Phase: The picture is essentially similar to that in later childhood, with lichenification, especially of the flexures and hands.

Other options:

Option A: Lichen simplex chronicus usually presents as an itchy plaque. Chronic itching produces secondary lichenification. It may be associated with the history of atopy. It is less likely to appear as oozing on scratching. A predilection for flexural aspect in childhood as in this case is not classically seen.

Option B: Psoriasis classically involves extensor aspect unlike flexures as in this child. Moreover, it is associated with silvery scaling and grattage reveals fresh bleeding points (Auspitz sign) and not oozing of serous fluid.

Option D: Scabies is caused by itch mites laying eggs in burrows made in the skin. The burrows are visible as serpiginous erythematous lesions. It classically causes itching more during the evening and involves lesions in the circle of hebra unlike flexures as in this case.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presents with vasomotor symptoms. She underwent hysterectomy 5 years ago. The gynecologist plans to put her on hormone therapy. Which of the following would be preferred in her case?
questions.solution:
In hysterectomized patients progesterone is not needed, therefore they can be treated with estrogen-only therapy.

Hormone therapy is only indicated for the treatment of vasomotor symptoms, osteoporosis (prevention and treatment), and vaginal atrophy.

Other treatments: 

Hormonal Non-Hormonal Non-prescriptive

Estrogen therapy (Most effective)

Oestrogen+Progesterone (HRT)

Tibolone

Clonidine 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor like Fluoxetine

Dopamine antagonist

Vitamin E

Soya 

Isoflavones

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. For women without uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.

questions.text: You suspect a nutritional deficiency in a chronic alcoholic patient. Investigation showed reduced erythrocyte transketolase activity. All of the following ocular manifestations are seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Thiamine or Vitamin B1 nutritional deficiency is consistent in a patient with reduced erythrocyte transketolase activity. Corneal vascularisation is not seen in thiamine deficiency. It is a manifestation of riboflavin deficiency.

Ocular manifestations of thiamine deficiency includes:

  • Corneal Anaesthesia
  • Conjunctival dystrophy
  • Corneal dystrophy
  • Acute retrobulbar neuritis

Remember:

Ocular manifestations of riboflavin deficiency:

  • Photophobia
  • Burning sensation in the eyes due to conjunctival irritation
  • vascularisation of the cornea

questions.text: You made a diagnosis of abductor dysphonia in a 30-year-old female who presented with the complaints of interruption of normal voice by voiceless segments or breathy breaks in the voice. You treat this patient by injecting botulinum toxin to the affected muscle but she fails to respond. Your next line of management should include:
questions.solution:
Patients who do not respond to botulinum toxin injection are treated with type I thyroplasty.

Abductor dysphonia:

  • It is due to spasms of posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, which is the only abductor, and hence the glottis remains open in this condition.
  • Patient complains of breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice.
  • The symptoms get aggravated during the periods of stress or when the patient uses telephone.
  • Treatment includes injection of botulinum toxin in posterior cricoarytenoid muscles. It can be done by percutaneous or endoscopic route
  • Patients who do not respond to toxin injection can be treated by thyroplasty type I or fat injection.

Remember:

There are four different types of thyroplasty procedures described by Isshiki:

  • Type I: Medialization of vocal cord
  • Type II: Lateralization of vocal cord
  • Type III: Shortening or relaxation of vocal cord
  • Type IV: Lengthening or tightening of the vocal cord

questions.text: As a surgeon, you plan to perform the following surgeries on four of your patients. In which of the following procedures will you be extra cautious due to the higher risk of surgical site infection (SSI)?
questions.solution:
Extra precautions should be taken while performing a colorectal surgery as it belongs to the category of clean-contaminated wound (class II) with an expected infection rate of 4-14%.

Elective cholecystectomy also belongs to the category of clean-contaminated wound (class II) but it is associated with a lesser infection rate of 2-9%

Class I: Clean wounds: Surgical site infection (SSI) rate is least in clean wounds, i.e. in operations where there is no inflammation and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Examples include:

  • Elective herniorrhaphy is a clean wound categorized as class I (as the prosthetic mesh is placed)
  • Breast biopsy 

Class II: Clean-contaminated wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination. Examples include:

  • Elective cholecystectomy
  • Elective gastrointestinal surgeries (eg: Fundoplication)
  • Colorectal surgery (higher infection rate)

Class III: Contaminated wounds include open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract; and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered.

Class IV: Dirty wounds include old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera.

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a history of a right breast lump for the past 2 weeks. On examination, it is found to be 1 cm in size and is non-tender. A breast biopsy shows lobular carcinoma in situ. In comparison to the normal epithelial cells of the breast lobule, these malignant cells show decreased expression of which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Cadherins are calcium ion dependent transmembrane glycoproteins that mediate the cohesion of normal epithelial cells in the breast and other glandular tissues.

E-cadherin is expressed on the surface of all epithelial cells and mediates cell adhesion by “zipper-like” interactions. E-cadherin functions as a tumor suppressor protein and may be lost in neoplastic proliferation through a variety of mechanisms including mutation of the E-cadherin gene (CDH1). Overall, cadherins suppress invasion and metastasis. Thus, it is perhaps not surprising that the expression of E-cadherin is reduced in most carcinomas.

Other options:

Desmin is an intermediate filament protein found in cells of mesenchymal origin.

Lysyl hydroxylase is involved in the post-translational modification of collagen.

P selectin is a cell adhesion molecule that mediates the margination of neutrophils during acute inflammation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient suffering from chronic venous insufficiency presents with the feature as shown in the below image. According to the recent 2020 update to the CEAP system, the clinical classification for this patient would be ____________
questions.solution:
The above image shows Corona Phlebectatica or Malleolar flare, which is classified as C4c under the recent 2020 update in the CEAP system.

Corona phlebectatica is a term used to describe an accumulation of tiny telangiectasias or venous flare, usually located at the medial malleolus or the dorsum of the foot. It is thought to be an early sign of advanced venous disease.

Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system includes,

  • C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  • C4c for Corona phlebectatica
  • C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.

questions.text: Clascoterone has been recently approved by FDA, for the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Clascoterone is an androgen receptor inhibitor, indicated for the topical treatment of acne vulgaris in patients aged 12-years and older. It recently got FDA approval (in 2020).

The mechanism of action of the drug is unknown.

Dosage & Administration:

It is available as 1% cream. About 1 gram of the cream, can be applied topically over the affected area twice daily, in the morning and evening.

Adverse effects:

  • It may cause local irritation, associated with pruritus, burning, skin redness, or peeling.
  • Hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal(HPA) axis suppression may occur.
  • If the drug is administered in pediatric patients, it may lead to systemic toxicity.
  • Hyperkalemia may occur in some patients.

questions.text: A 36-year-old pregnant woman presented with sudden onset of difficulty in breathing. She developed an altered state of consciousness and weakness of her right arm. The patient previously had of two spontaneous abortions. A pulmonary ventilation/perfusion scan showed evidence of pulmonary embolism. Cerebral angiography shows occlusion of a branch of the left middle cerebral artery. Investigations revealed platelet count 104,000/mm3, PTT 48 seconds, positive anticardiolipin antibody, and a negative ANA test. The serologic test for syphilis is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies, vascular thromboses, recurrent miscarriages, unexplained fetal mortality, and premature birth. Antibodies target proteins like Cardiolipin and Beta-2-glycoprotein I.

APS can be either primary or secondary.

In primary antiphospholipid syndrome, patients exhibit only the manifestations of a hypercoagulable state and lack evidence of other autoimmune disorders.

Those with a well-defined autoimmune disease, such as systemic lupus erythematosus are classified as having the secondary antiphospholipid syndrome.

Other options:

Thrombophlebitis occurs more frequently in pregnancy, but this explains only venous thrombosis and not the anticardiolipin antibodies.

Anticardiolipin antibody often leads to a false-positive serologic test result for syphilis. Thrombocytopenia is often present.

Trousseau syndrome is a hypercoagulable state associated with an underlying malignancy, and may be associated with arterio-venous thromboses, but not the anticardiolipin antibodies.

Related Pearl: Hypercoagulable states

Primary (Genetic Conditions):

  • Mutations in factor V (Most common)
  • Antithrombin III deficiency
  • Protein C or S deficiency
  • Fibrinolysis defects
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Allelic variations in prothrombin levels
  • Mutations in the methyl tetra hydro folate (MTHF) gene

Secondary (Acquired Conditions):

  • Prolonged bed rest or immobilization
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Tissue damage (Surgery, fracture, burns)
  • Cancer
  • Myocardial infarction, Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest radiographic sign of TB spine?

choices.text: Accumulation of pus in paradiscal space

questions.solution:
Narrowing of disc space is the earliest sign of TB spine, especially in the paradiscal type.

In earlier stages of disease, disc space reduction might not be so apparent, but in later stages, disc space might be completely lost. A lateral X-ray of the spine is better to evaluate disc space. This is an important sign because disc space is generally preserved in spinal metastasis and helps in differentiating both of these.

Other radiographic signs of TB spine include:

  • Destruction of vertebral body. It starts with erosion of contiguous margins, followed by wedging of vertebra and then destruction of whole of vertebral body leading to kyphosis. But Posterior elements are rarely involved
  • Appearance of cold abscess. In cervical spine disease, retropharyngeal abscess may be evident. In lower spine involvement, paravertebral abscess may be seen in either a fusiform or globular shape. Thoracic spine disease may be seen as widened mediastinum on AP view.
  • Rarefaction above and below the vertebra
  • Signs of healing - the bone becomes sclerotic and regains its density. The adjacent vertebra may undergo fusion.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with enlargement of neck nodes. Examination of the left ear reveals conductive hearing loss with the tympanogram showing the following type of curve. Involvement of which of the following cranial nerves completes the features of trotter's triad seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with type B typanogram is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Conductive deafness (i.e. eustachian tube blockage) along with the involvement of 5th and 10th cranial nerve together constitutes Trotter's triad seen in this condition.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can cause,

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube blockage),
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of CN V and
  • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of CN X

This is collectively called as Trotter’s triad.

Commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. It is mostly seen in fifth to seventh decades with Males being more prone than females.

Presenting symptoms include,

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common)
  • Hearing loss
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis
  • Cranial nerve palsies - 6th Cranial nerve is most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves.
  • Headache
  • Earache
  • Neck pain
  • Weight loss

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department after suffering severe injuries in a motorcycle accident. His blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg. Ultrasound examination revealed a ruptured spleen. Arterial blood gas analysis was suggestive of metabolic acidosis. The patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffered from hypovolemic shock due to an internal hemorrhage caused by the ruptured spleen.

Shock is a state of circulatory failure resulting in tissue hypoperfusion and hypoxia. Prolonged shock eventually leads to irreversible tissue damage. Shock progresses through a series of well-defined stages:

  1. Initial nonprogressive stage: Compensatory neurohumoral mechanisms come into play to preserve tissue perfusion.
  2. Progressive stage: Tissue hypoperfusion leads to circulatory and metabolic disturbances. Acidosis occurs due to intracellular anaerobic glycolysis. This causes peripheral pooling, thereby leading to reduced cardiac output and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  3. Irreversible stage: Tissue injury cannot be reversed even with hemodynamic correction. There is worsening myocardial contractility, renal function impairment, and bacteremia (due to the release of intestinal flora into the circulation).

Hypovolemic shock occurs due to massive hemorrhage or fluid loss from vomiting, diarrhea, and severe burns. This results in low blood volume and cardiac output. Patients present with hypotension, a weak rapid pulse, tachypnea, and cool, clammy, cyanotic skin (due to cutaneous vasoconstriction, which shunts the blood away to vital organs like the heart and brain). More than 90% of otherwise healthy individuals recover with appropriate fluid resuscitation.

Other options:

Option A: Cardiogenic shock occurs due to myocardial pump failure, resulting in low cardiac output. It can be seen in myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, and pulmonary embolism. Patients present with symptoms similar to hypovolemic shock, but treatment outcome is poorer in comparison.

Option B: Septic shock occurs due to systemic infections like bacterial and fungal infections, toxic shock syndrome, pancreatitis, etc, massive trauma, and severe burns, resulting in fatal organ failure. A massive release of inflammatory cytokines causes peripheral vasodilation and pooling, which causes the skin to look flushed. Vascular damage and DIC also occur frequently. Shock lung can be seen due to alveolar damage. Septic shock is also associated with poorer patient outcomes.

Option D: Neurogenic shock occurs due to spinal cord injuries. There is acute vasodilation, which leads to hypotension and tissue hypoperfusion.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

 

Related Pearl: Compensatory responses to hemorrhagic shock

  • Baroreceptor reflex
  • CNS Ischemic response
  • Reverse stress relaxation
  • ↑ secretion of renin by kidneys and formation of Angiotensin II
  • ↑ secretion of ADH
  • ↑Norepinephrine and epinephrine
  • Compensatory mechanisms that return the blood volume back toward normal, including
    • Absorption of large quantities of fluid from the intestinal tract
    • Absorption of fluid into the blood capillaries from the interstitial spaces of the body
    • Conservation of water and salt by the kidneys
    • Increased thirst and increased appetite for salt

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the characteristics of elimination plotted in orange?

choices.text: Fixed amount of drug is cleared per unit time
Exhibited by drugs such as phenytoin

questions.solution:
In the given image, the orange line depicts zero-order elimination. The incorrect statement about this type of elimination is that t½ remains constant. In zero-order elimination, the t½ is not constant and is less at low concentration and more at high concentration.

Zero-order kinetics denotes that the rate of elimination is constant regardless of the concentration of the drug. Here a fixed amount of drug is cleared per unit time. This is usually seen when the drugs saturate their elimination mechanisms. Therefore, as the concentration of the drug increases beyond metabolic saturation, clearance of the drug decreases as depicted by the orange line. Drugs such as phenytoin, and aspirin follow this type of elimination at higher concentrations. 

First-order kinetics denotes that the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration of the drug. Here a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated. The drugs following this elimination have a constant  t½. As the dosage of the drug increases, the clearance remains constant as the fraction of drug eliminated is constant as depicted by the black line. Most drugs follow this type of elimination. 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain and vomiting. X-ray abdomen reveals characteristic sign as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows rows of several air-filled spaces between the valvulae conniventes of fluid-filled, dilated small bowel loops, giving a ‘string of pearls’ or ‘string of beads’ appearance, characteristic of small bowel obstruction.

Radiological features of small bowel obstruction:

X-ray:

  • On erect X-ray, there may be presence of more than 2 fluid levels within the dilated small bowel loops.
  • Supine X-ray shows a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes, within fluid-filled dilated small bowels, resembling a string of beads.

Ultrasound:

It can detect fluid-filled loops of the small intestine.

CT:

  • The presence of angulated and tethering of the bowel loops on CT may indicate adhesions, most likely due to a neoplasm.
  • Small bowel ‘feces sign’ may be seen due to the presence of faeces-like material in the small bowel loops proximal to the obstruction. It can occur due to prolonged stasis, and water reabsorption.
  • In simple obstruction, a definite point of obstruction, called ‘transition point’ may be seen, with dilated small bowel loops proximally, and collapsed loops distally.
  • In closed-loop obstruction, a U- or V-shaped configuration of the dilated loops may be seen with a fixed radial distribution.
  • A strangulated bowel represents the incarceration of the proximal and distal limbs of mechanical small bowel obstruction, with subsequent ischemia.

questions.text: The following finding was seen on performing DATscan in a patient who presented with bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremors. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
The DATscan image shows normal ‘comma-shaped’ pattern of the striatal nuclei, which rules out degenerative parkinsonism, suggesting a secondary parkinsonism such as drug-induced parkinsonism.

DAT (Dopamine transporter) is a presynaptic transporter that transmits the dopamine from the synaptic cleft, back into the presynaptic nerve terminal. The DATscan is an imaging technique which uses ioflupane iodine-123 injection, a contrast agent that is taken up by the DATs in the presynaptic neurons in the striatal nuclei. The uptake of DAT is visualized by SPECT (Single-positron emission tomography) scan.

In normal DATscan result, the striatal nuclei appear as coma shaped. However, the normal result may also be seen in post-synaptic (secondary) parkinsonism such as parkinsonism secondary to vascular lesions or drug-induced parkinsonism.

In pre-synaptic (degenerative) parkinsonism, such as, idiopathic Parkinson's disease, progressive supranuclear palsy, multiple system atrophy, Lewy body dementia, and corticobasal degeneration, the striatal nuclei appear abnormally, as a ‘dot’ or ‘period’ shaped.

questions.text: In a nuclear family cycle, the phase from the 1st child leaving the parental house until the last child leaving the house of parents is termed as ________
questions.solution:
The phase of a nuclear family cycle starting from the first child leaving the house and ending with the last child leaving the house of parents is called Contraction.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

2
