  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: An HIV patient was found to have a CD4 count of 184 cells per microliter. Which of the following is used for prophylaxis against pneumocystis carinii infection?
questions.solution:
Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is offered to HIV patients with CD4 below 200cells/μL as primary prophylaxis against P. carinii infection.

Alternatively, they can also be given aerosolized pentamidine or dapsone.

Patients who develop P.carinii infection on a particular prophylactic regimen should be switched to the other drug or should receive a combination regimen.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in multiple joints involving both the hands and knees for over 2 months of duration. Her investigations revealed elevated ESR and CRP with negative rheumatoid factor assay. Her blood showed the presence of anti-CCP antibodies. Which of the following joints will likely be spared?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Rheumatoid arthritis. It usually shows sparing of the DIP joint.

The given patient presenting with multiple joint pain (small and large) for a duration of more than 6 weeks points towards a diagnosis of RA. Her lab reports show negative Rheumatoid factor but anti-CCP positive (more specific). Raised ESR and CRP point towards an inflammatory process going on in the body. 

Xray finding shows a reduction in joint space, periarticular osteopenia and deformities of hand (swan neck deformity). The diagnosis of RA can be done by ACR/EULAR grading.

In this case, the ACR classification score would be 6 or more, making the diagnosis definite RA.

Duration >6 weeks - 1

Abnormal ESR/CRP - 1

Elevated antiCCP    - 2 (at least- since values are not mentioned)

Joint involvement   - 3 (atleast - as both knees and almost all PIP joints and wrist involvement is seen in Xrays)

Total - atleast 7

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the structure marked with "?" in the image given below?

choices.text: Bartholin’s duct is the major duct
Lymphatic drainage is to the submental nodes
Obstruction of the duct causes ranula
It is seromucous but predominantly serous

questions.solution:
The structure marked "?" is the sublingual gland and it is seromucous but predominantly mucous.

The sublingual gland is the smallest of the main salivary glands. Small rami from the anterior part of the gland sometimes form a major sublingual duct (Bartholin’s duct), which opens with, or near to the orifice of the submandibular duct.

The sublingual gland is not removed in radical neck dissection.

If the ducts of any salivary gland become obstructed they can develop a retention cyst. If such cysts occur due to the obstruction in the sublingual salivary gland, it is called a ranula. A ranula usually presents as a large, tense, bluish swelling on the floor of the mouth to one side on the midline.

If the obstruction happens in the ducts of minor salivary glands such as labial or buccal, it is termed mucocele.

The clinical condition shown in the image given below is a ranula.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with fissured tongue and cheilosis. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Among the following co-factors of enzyme complexes, which one is most affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario suggests riboflavin/vitamin B2 deficiency. Both FAD and FMN require riboflavin for their synthesis. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC. FAD-dependent enzymes include succinate dehydrogenase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, xanthine oxidase, and acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesised in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence, riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries (the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularisation, cheilosis, magenta-coloured tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. 

Other options:

Options B and C: NAD+ and NADP+ are derived from niacin.

questions.text: According to the AHA 2020 guidelines for the Pediatric Basic and Advanced Life Support which of these is true?

choices.text: Use uncuffed ET tubes to prevent laryngeal damage
Use cuffed ET tubes with cuff pressure of <20mm Hg

questions.solution:
For infants and children with a pulse but an absent or inadequate respiratory effort, it is reasonable to give 1 breath every 2 to 3 seconds (20-30 breaths/min).

Older guidelines suggested the rate of breathing to be 12-15 breaths per minute.

Other options:

It is reasonable to choose cuffed ETTs over uncuffed ETTs for intubating infants and children. The cuff pressure should be <20-25cm H20 (not mmHg).

Moreover, routine use of cricoid pressure is not recommended during the endotracheal intubation of pediatric patients

For pediatric patients in any setting, it is reasonable to administer the initial dose of epinephrine within 5 minutes from the start of chest compressions.

questions.text: During triaging of casualties from a building collapse, you find a patient who is able to walk but has sprained his ankle along with abrasions on the legs and a laceration on the face. You would classify him under:
questions.solution:
This patient is classified under the green code, according to triage color coding. In triage, green signifies low-priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.

Triage is done to categorize the need for priority of patients in cases of mass casualties. The aim of triage is the identify patients who would benefit the most by being treated earlier.

Priority Color Medical need Clinical status Examples
First (I) Red Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if treated early
  • Severe facial trauma
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Profuse external bleeding
  • Hemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed
  • Extradural hematomas
Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive treated  within hours
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Ruptured abdominal viscus
  • Pelvic fractures
  • Spinal injuries
Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed hours- days
  • Simple fractures
  • Sprains
  • Minor lacerations
Last (0) Black Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help
  • Severe brain damage
  • Very extensive burns
  • Major disruption/loss of chest or abdominal wall structures

questions.text: A 1-week-old lethargic neonate was brought to the pediatric OPD, he sleeps more than 3 hours after a feed, passes urine 7-8 times a day, and passes stools up to 5 times a day. He has a weight loss of 5% compared to his birth weight. Which of the following points is a sign of inadequate breastfeeding?

choices.text: Weight loss of 5% to birth weight
Sleeps more than 3 hours after a feed

questions.solution:
Lethargy(sleeping more than 2-3 hours after a feed) is an indicator of inadequate breastfeeding in an infant.

Indicators of inadequate breastfeeding in an infant:

  • Weight loss >7-10% of birth weight
  • Lethargy (sleeping longer than 2–3 hours)
  • Delayed stooling (Less than 4 times/day)
  • Decreased urine output (urinating less than 5–7 times/day)
  • Hypernatremic dehydration
  • Inconsolable crying and increased hunger

Insufficient milk intake could be due to insufficient milk production, failure of established breastfeeding, and health conditions in the infant that prevent proper breast stimulation.

Breastfed neonates usually feed 8–12 times a day, with a minimum of 8 times per day. However, the neonate should be breastfed on demand.

questions.text: A 30-year-old officer, who was serving duty in Mumbai (sea level) has been posted to Amarnath (13,048 feet above sea level). After a few months of duty in Amarnath, his blood reports showed raised levels of bisphosphogylcerate (BPG) as a result of adaptation to high altitude. Identify the true statement regarding the physiologic change seen in this patient?

choices.text: Elevated BPG increases the affinity of HbA for O2 and increases P50
Elevated BPG lowers the affinity of HbA for O2 and increases P50
Elevated BPG increases the affinity of HbA for O2 and decreases P50
Elevated BPG lowers the affinity of HbA for O2 and decreases P50

questions.solution:
At high altitudes, Elevated BPG lowers the affinity of HbA for O2 and increases P50, which indicates that there is an increased release of O2 at peripheral tissues. 

Physiologic changes that accompany prolonged exposure to high altitude include:

  • Increases in the number of erythrocytes,
  • Increase in concentration of hemoglobin within the erythrocytes,
  • Increased synthesis of BPG.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting 2,3 -DPG

  • Chronic hypoxia
  • Anemia
  • Acclimitization (high altitude)
  • Thyroid hormone
  • Growth hormone
  • Androgens
  • Exercise
  • Stored blood
  • Acidosis

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to you with the complaints of frequent painful urination with a history of weight loss. On rectal examination, a hard, irregular nodule was palpated within his prostate. Lab reports show PSA levels as 7.0 ng/ml. You suspect prostatic carcinoma in this patient and plan for TRUS-guided biopsy. The standard biopsy template usually includes ________
questions.solution:
The standard biopsy template usually includes 12 core-biopsies.

Patients who have either an elevated total PSA level (i.e in excess of 2.5 - 4.0 ng/ml) or abnormal findings on digital rectal examination (DRE) or both are advised to undergo TRUS-guided biopsy of the prostate.

The standard biopsy template involves 12 core biopsies with a spring-loaded biopsy instrument.

Site of biopsy: The tissue is usually obtained from the base, mid, and apex regions, medially and laterally from the left and right sides.

Patients are asked to stop anticoagulants to prevent bleeding complications.

Common adverse effects that follow TRUS biopsy include rectal bleeding, gross hematuria, and hematospermia, all of which are usually self-limited. Fever, urinary infection and retention occur in less than 5% of patients.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman was admitted for right knee arthroplasty. On the 7th postoperative day, she developed a fever and cough with purulent, blood-tinged sputum. Her chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would be the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the chest-Xray showing lobar consolidation with bulging fissure sign are suggestive of late-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia most likely caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae.

K. pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. The patient characteristically presents with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission. It can further be classified as:

  • Early-onset HAP, which occurs within 4-5 days of admission and is commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, Escherichia coli, etc.
  • Late-onset HAP occurs >5 days after hospital admission and is usually caused by gram-negative bacteria like Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii.

Pneumonia caused by Klebsiella species shows the following classic chest X-ray findings:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor. 

The following image shows a bulging fissure sign.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be used for treatment and include third-generation cephalosporins and beta-lactam antibiotics with beta-lactamase inhibitors. Nosocomial infection with Klebsiella is difficult to treat in many situations as they produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamase and are resistant to many antibiotics.

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common causative agent of community-acquired pneumonia.

Option C: Legionella pneumophila causes community-acquired pneumonia and early-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia.

Option D: Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of Q-fever.

questions.text: You have been allotted a patient with an upper limb fracture in the orthopedics ward. The patient fell on his elbow and complains of pain on elbow movement. On examining, the 3 bony point relationship is reversed. The examiner gives you xrays as shown below and asks you to pick up the one belonging to the patient.
questions.solution:
The given patient with a fall on the elbow and reversed 3 bony point relationship is likely a case of Olecranon fracture. The x-ray D corresponds to the displaced transverse olecranon fracture.

The three bony points are the tip of the medial epicondyle, the tip of the lateral epicondyle and the olecranon. When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, they form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line. 

Since supracondylar fracture (X-ray: C) occurs above any of these bony landmarks, the 3 bony point relationship is preserved in this.

Other options:

A - Galeazzi fracture 

B - Monteggia fracture

C- Supracondylar fracture

 

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A college-going student comes with complaints of muffled speech with throat pain, fever, and painful swallowing. The examination of the oral cavity reveals frank pus from tonsillar crypts. In order to drain the pus, the treating doctor should make an incision just lateral to the junction of which of the following 2 lines?

choices.text: Vertical line through superior constrictor and Horizontal line through base of uvula
Vertical line through superior constrictor and Horizontal line through tip of uvula
Vertical line through anterior pillar and Horizontal line through tip of uvula
Vertical line through anterior pillar and Horizontal line through base of uvula

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Quinsy, also known as Peritonsillar Abscess.  In order to drain the pus in this condition, the treating doctor should make an incision just lateral to the junction of the vertical line through the anterior pillar and horizontal line through the base of uvula.

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

Clinical features: 

  • Sore throat, which is usually unilateral
  • Odynophagia - The patient is unable to swallow even his own saliva, which may drool from the mouth.
  • Trismus - due to spasm of pterygoid muscles which are in close proximity to the superior constrictor.
  • Ipsilateral otalgia - due to referred pain via CN IX which supplies both the tonsil and the ear.
  • Foul breath due to sepsis in the oral cavity and poor hygiene.
  • The speech is usually muffled and thick often called “hot potato voice".

Investigations:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI reveals abscess and its extent.
  • Needle aspiration of the abscess to collect pus for culture and sensitivity.

Management:

Peritonsillar abscess may be cured with conservative measures, which include:

  • Hospitalization
  • IV fluids to combat dehydration
  • Antibiotics in large IV doses, covering both aerobic and anaerobic organisms.
  • Analgesics like paracetamol, or sometime pethidine. Aspirin is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.
  • Oral hygiene, maintained by hydrogen peroxide or saline mouthwashes.

If the above conservative measures fail, and a frank abscess has formed, then incision & drainage would be required.

  • Incision and drainage of the abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

 

  • Interval tonsillectomy can be done, where tonsils are removed 4–6 weeks following an attack of quinsy.
  • Abscess or hot tonsillectomy: In some cases, the doctor may choose to perform tonsillectomy, without draining the abscess first. The procedure carries risk of rupture of abscess during anaesthesia and excessive bleeding during the operation.

questions.text: An unknown disease of suspected infectious origin has come up in your town. As a microbiologist, you collect the relevant samples and detect the etiological cause. Which of the following types of PCR would you do?
questions.solution:
Multiplex PCR can be used to identify an unknown infectious agent.

Types of PCR:

  • Multiplex PCR: Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. 
  • Nested PCR: It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity. Used in GeneXpert to detect Mycobacterium TB and resistance to rifampicin.
  • Quantitative PCR: Apart from just detecting the target sequences, it also  tells the number of such target sequences. We can quantify the HIV viral load with this technique.
  • Reverse transcriptase PCR: The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complimentary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR. Unlike conventional PCR which can only amplify DNA, this one can even amplify RNA. It is used to detect H1N1 from Nasopharyngeal swab.
  • Real-time PCR: This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR).

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient was infused 1500 mL of 2% dextrose. His body weight is 82 Kgs, and BMI is 26.5 Kg/m2. Which of the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams correctly represents the state of distribution of the body fluids after infusion? (The graph A is the normal state, while the dotted lines in graphs B to D, indicates altered distribution. The arrows indicate the direction of change).
questions.solution:
2% Dextrose is a hypotonic solution. Infusion of hypotonic solution causes the body fluids to re-distribute as depicted by the Darrow-Yannet diagram, marked C.

When a hypotonic solution is infused, the osmolarity of the extracellular fluid decreases, and the volume of ECF increases. The water shifts from ECF to ICF, until the osmolarity of both sides becomes equal. This results in increased volume and decrease osmolarity of ICF as well.

Similar changes are seen in water retention, as in SIADH.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic female patient presents to you with complaints of greenish nipple discharge for the past few months. Examination reveals the presence of discharge from multiple ducts with para-areolar lump and advised for mammography. Which of the following mammography findings, you would expect in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of duct ectasia and mammogram of a patient with duct ectasia shows typical Broken-needle type of calcification.  This is due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in nonlactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation.

Other options:

  • Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma.
  • Egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis.
  • Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease.

Popcorn calcification:

Egg-shell calcification:

Tea-cup calcification-On a lateral magnification view, layering of calcific fluid contained within microcysts can be appreciated, producing a characteristic ‘teacup’ appearance.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of weight loss, joint pain, and occasional fever. She has a malar rash, oral ulcers, telangiectatic vessels, non-blanching purpuric papules over her legs. She has elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine. An indirect immunofluorescence test was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the staining pattern?
questions.solution:
This patient with weight loss, joint pain, malar rash, oral ulcers, non-blanching purpuric papules over her legs, elevated blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine is likely to have systemic lupus erythematosus.

The image shows a homogenous or diffuse stained immunofluorescence pattern, indicating anti-nuclear antibodies, especially, antibodies against dsDNA, nucleosomes, chromatin, and histones, seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs, with a vast array of autoantibodies, particularly antinuclear antibodies (ANA). The lesion occurs mainly by deposition of immune complexes and binding of antibodies to various cells and tissues.

Clinical criteria of SLE include:

  • Malar rash
  • Discoid rash
  • Diffuse thinning or hair fragility in the absence of other causes
  • Oral or nasopharyngeal ulceration
  • Nonerosive synovitis involving two or more peripheral joints
  • Pleuritis
  • Persistent proteinuria
  • Seizures, psychosis
  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Leukopenia
  • Lymphopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia

Anti-nuclear antibodies are seen in autoimmune diseases and are directed against nuclear antigens. They are broadly divided into four categories depending on their specificity for the nuclear components like DNA, histones, non-histone RNA bound proteins, and nucleolar antigens.

The test used for the detection of a specific type of ANA is called indirect immunofluorescence, in which the pattern of nuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient’s serum.

Four basic patterns are recognized:

Homogeneous or diffuse staining of nuclei occurs with antibodies specific for dsDNA, nucleosomes, and histones. This is seen in systemic lupus erythematosus

The image below shows a homogenous or diffuse stained immunofluorescence pattern seen in SLE.

 

Speckled pattern is seen in the presence of antibodies reactive with nuclear antigens such as Smith(Sm) and ribonucleoprotein as shown below

 

Centromeric pattern is the characteristic for the presence of anti-centromere antibodies as seen in some cases of systemic sclerosis and Sjögren syndrome

The image below shows a centromeric pattern.

 

The nucleolar pattern is seen with antibodies against nucleolar proteins as shown below

The below image shows the basic patterns of ANA.

Other options: 

Option B- Sjogren syndrome shows specific antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens, SS-A(Ro) and SS-B(La). It is characterized by dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) resulting from immunologically mediated destruction of the lacrimal and salivary glands. It occurs most commonly in women between 50 and 60 years of age.

Option C- Systemic sclerosis shows specific antibodies directed against

  • DNA topoisomerase I
  • Centromeric proteins A, B, c
  • RNA polymerase III

Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder that results in interstitial and perivascular fibrosis of the skin, and various other internal organs along with widespread damage to blood vessels. It occurs commonly in women between 50 to 60 year age group.

Option D- Autoimmune myositis shows specific antibodies directed against Jo I and MDA5. These patients present with raynaud phenomenon, dermatomyositis, skin rash, and interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: You are working in the ICU of a local hospital. The hospital reports a high number of hospital-acquired infections. Which of the following practice will you adopt apart from hand hygiene to prevent hospital-acquired infection?

choices.text: Wearing a surgical mask before doing a spinal tap
Washing gloves with sanitiser before examining the next patient
Using the same syringe for one patient for medications
After using the syringe, immediately capping the needle to avoid needle stick injury

questions.solution:
A surgical mask should be worn before placing a catheter or doing a spinal tap.

Other infection control practices are:

  • 5 moments of Hand hygiene - before dong aseptic procedure, before and after touching a patient even if gloves are to be worn, after contact with body fluids, after touching patient surroundings.
  • Gloves should not be washed for the purpose of reuse.
  • Wearing a gown if body fluid contact is anticipated, using one gown for one patient only.
  • To not cap needles after use, as needlestick injury occurs while capping. Instead, dispose of the needle in needle burner or cutter.
  • Single-use vials, ampoules, bottles, fluid administration set to be used for one patient only. A syringe should not be reused even for a single vial.
  • Avoid usage of multi-dose vials for more than one patient.

questions.text:
Which of the following events are responsible for increased vascular permeability during acute inflammation?
1. Chemical mediators like histamine, kinins, and other mediators produce gaps between vascular endothelial cells.
2. Direct injury of endothelial cells caused by microbial toxins, leucocytes, or thermal injury.
3. Contraction of endothelial cells.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct. Acute inflammation is associated with three types of vascular effects. These include vasodilatation, increased permeability, and passage of white blood cells into the injured tissues.

The vasodilatation allows increased blood flow so that inflammatory cells can reach the site of injury as well as cater to increased metabolic demands by supplying more oxygen-carrying red call and proteins for repair. Increased vascular permeability allows the inflammatory and other cells to reach the site of trauma to mount an inflammatory response that helps in healing.

All three events are induced relatively quickly, and are divided into three patterns, immediate, early, and delayed.

The immediate response: It is transient and lasts for 15-30 minutes. Contraction of endothelial cells resulting in the appearance of gaps between endothelial cells of capillaries and is the most common cause of vascular leakage.  It is elicited by histamine, bradykinin, leukotrienes, and other chemical mediators.

The delayed response occurs due to contraction of endothelial cells or mild endothelial damage as seen classically in sunburns.

questions.text: A physician uses the following instrument to measure temperature in one of his patients and he wants to disinfect it before using it on another patient. It can be best disinfected by _______
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a clinical thermometer, and it is best disinfected using Savlon.

Savlon is a quaternary ammonia compound (QAC) that contains Cetavlon (cetrimide) and Hibitane (chlorhexidine). Plastic items can be disinfected by keeping them in normal strength Savlon for 20 minutes. Clinical thermometers can be disinfected in savlon in just under 3 minutes.

Other options: 

Option A - Cresol is a coal-tar disinfectant that is best used in 5-10% strength for disinfection of feces and urine.

Option B - Chloroxylenol (Dettol) is an antiseptic that is active against streptococci. A 5% solution is suitable for disinfection of instruments and plastic equipment, with minimum contact of 15 minutes required for disinfection.

Option D - Lysol is a "saponified cresol" where cresol is emulsified with soap. It contains 50- 60 percent cresol and is a powerful disinfectant. A 2 percent solution of Lysol may be used for the disinfection of feces.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for premature cataracts, thinning of skin, alopecia, osteoporosis, and atherosclerosis. She is found to have a hereditary genetic mutation in the WRN gene. This gene encodes which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of Werner syndrome, a premature aging disorder. The mutated gene encodes a DNA helicase. 

Werner syndrome is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the WRN gene. This gene encodes a protein with multiple DNA-dependent enzymatic functions including:

  • ATPase
  • Helicase
  • Exonuclease

DNA helicase is involved in DNA replication and repair. A defect in this enzyme causes rapid accumulation of damaged chromosomes that may mimic the injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging. Affected persons show various manifestations of premature aging including:  

  • Atherosclerosis
  • Senile cataract
  • Skin atrophy
  • Alopecia
  • Osteoporosis

They are also at risk for the development of a variety of cancers. Patients typically die in the 5th decade from either cancer or cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: The image below shows finding seen on eliciting plantar reflex in a patient in the neurology ward. All of the following signs may be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign), suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Fasciculations are seen in lower motor neuron lesions (not UMN).
 
UMNs refer to corticospinal tract neurons and brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Injury to UMNs lead to:
  • Spasticity
  • Hypertonia 
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign).
Babinski sign refers to dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. It is a sign of an upper motor neuron lesion. In normal adults, the response is plantar flexion of all the toes.
 

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot.

The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

questions.text: You notice the following test is being performed by your senior on a 30-year-old patient having an Alvarado score of 7. The patient complained of pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen on performing the test. What is the name given to this clinical sign?
questions.solution:
The name given to this clinical sign is the Psoas sign.

The Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. A score of 7, as seen in this patient, suggests probable appendicitis. 

Various clinical signs have been described which are used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. Abdominal pain with hyperextension of the right hip is known as the Psoas sign. This is because of psoas muscle spasm, due to the inflamed appendix being in contact with this muscle. The patient often lies in a posture with the right hip flexed for pain relief.

Other options-

Option (B): Rovsing sign: Presence of pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen during palpation of the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.

Option (C): Dunphy’s sign: Abdominal pain on coughing.

Option (D): Aaron's sign- Firm pressure over McBurney's point in acute appendicitis causing pain in the epigastrium, left hypochondrium, umbilical and precordial regions.

questions.text: Which of the following events occur when a normal person makes an inspiratory effort against a closed airway?
questions.solution:
Tension in the diaphragm increases, when an inspiratory effort is made against a closed airway. All other options are incorrect.

The primary inspiratory muscles, which include the diaphragm and external intercostal muscles (not internal intercostal), become active.

When the inspiratory effort is made against the closed airway, air does not enter the lungs, and all the pressures inside the thorax fall, including the pulmonary vascular pressures.

The contraction of the inspiratory muscles will cause a slight increase in the lung volume. According to Boyle’s law, the product of pressure and volume remains constant (at constant temperature). Therefore, as the volume of the lung increases, the intrathoracic pressure decreases.

The intrapleural pressure will fall (becomes more negative). If the lung volume does not change, the alveolar pressure will fall equally with the intrapleural pressure. However, if the lung volume increases, due to the action of the inspiratory muscles, then the intrapleural pressure will fall more than the alveolar pressure due to increased elastic recoil.

questions.text: The pattern of DEJ causing pointy rete pegs, as shown in the histopathology image below, is most likely to be suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given histopathology picture shows saw toothing as seen in lichen planus.

Saw toothing: This refers to an alteration in the pattern of the dermal–epidermal junction where dermal papillae are expanded and the tips of the rete pegs are pointed. The resulting pattern bears a superficial resemblance to the teeth of a saw and the change is seen in lichen planus and other lichenoid reactions.

Papillamatosis: This change is characterized by upward elongation of the dermal papillae, giving an accentuated and sometimes irregular, undulating configuration to the dermal–epidermal junction. The feature is commonly seen in psoriasis, and a wide variety of other inflammatory and neoplastic cutaneous disorders.

Parakeratosis: Parakeratosis can be defined as the retention of keratinocyte nuclei within stratum corneum. It represents a disturbance of keratinization. It is commonly seen in Psoriasis.

Spongiosis - refers to intercellular edema or intrapidermal fluid. It is characteristically seen in acute or subacute eczematous reaction.

questions.text: Your senior consultant advises you to prescribe a painless topical antimicrobial for a patient suffering from burn wounds. You can consider prescribing any of the following topical antimicrobials in this patient except __________
questions.solution:
All the above topical antimicrobials have painless action when used for the treatment of burn wounds except Mafenide acetate.

Mafenide acetate:

  • Mafenide acetate either in cream or solution form is an effective topical antimicrobial.
  • It is effective even in the presence of eschar as it can penetrate burn eschar to reach the interface with the patient's viable tissue.
  • It has the disadvantage of being painful on topical application.
  • It is also a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and can result in metabolic acidosis when it is applied over large surfaces.

Other options:

Option b: Silver sulphadiazine: It is a most commonly used agent having a wide range of antimicrobial activity because it's silver and sulfa moieties cover gram-positive, most gram-negative, and even some fungal forms. In a few patients, transient leukopenia develops 3 to 5 days after its continued use. This leukopenia is generally harmless and resolves with or without treatment cessation.

Option c: Neomycin: Painless but antimicrobial spectrum is not as wide as the above agents.

Option d: Silver nitrate: Effective against Pseudomonas colonization. It has the advantage of being painless on application. However prolonged topical application leads to electrolyte extravasation with resulting hyponatremia. It also causes staining of all the furniture surrounding the patient.It may cause methemoglobinemia in few.

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student sustained a knee injury in the basketball match in the sports fest. The orthopaedic resident performed the Lachman test which turned out to be positive. Identify the ligament affected.
questions.solution:
The positive Lachman's test is suggestive of injury to the anterior cruciate ligament, which is marked as 'A' in the image shown.

The anterior cruciate ligament is attached to the anterior intercondylar area of the tibia. It ascends posterolaterally, twisting on itself and fanning out to attach high on the posteromedial aspect of the lateral femoral condyle.

Lachman's Test:

The patient’s knee is flexed 20-30 degrees, with one hand grasping the lower thigh and the other the upper part of the leg. The joint surfaces are shifted backwards and forwards upon each other.

The abnormal movement, as shown in the video below, suggests an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. If the knee is stable, there should be no gliding.

questions.text: An elderly lady is experiencing gradually worsening memory problems for the past 4-5 years, which now affect her daily activities. Recently, she lost her way back home from the church that she has been visiting for the past 30 years. No personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances were observed. Which of the following drugs is not recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of insidious loss of episodic memory followed by slowly progressive dementia is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease. Benztropine (anticholinergic) is not recommended for this patient.

The characteristic feature of Alzheimer's is the degeneration of cholinergic neurons leading to reduced levels of acetylcholine. Therefore, anticholinergic drugs like benztropine are not used. Benztropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that blocks acetylcholine receptors and is used in the management of Parkinsonism.

Treatment of Alzheimer's disease includes:

  • NMDA antagonist: Memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: Donepezil, Galantamine, Rivastigmine

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the Emergency room with a 3-day history of fever with chills, cough with production of rusty sputum, and dyspnoea on exertion. There is no history of contact with an infected person. His examination reveals fever 103° F, heart rate 112/min, respiratory rate 27/min, blood pressure 84/42 mm Hg, oxygen saturation on room air 82%. The blood test shows leucocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and elevated parameters of coagulation. He has metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. The chest x-ray shows focal consolidation bilaterally. Due to the worsening of his condition, he is intubated and placed on a ventilator. He is diagnosed to have acute respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following statements is true in this case?

choices.text: Respiratory failure is the most common cause of death in ARDS
The pulmonary consolidation affects lung apices predominantly
Responds to increasing concentration of oxygen inhalation
A high level of neutrophils is seen in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid

questions.solution:
In patients with ARDS, there is an inflammatory response in the lungs leading to high levels of neutrophils and their secretory products in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. This is characteristic of non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is characterized by rapid onset dyspnea, hypoxemia, and diffuse lung infiltrates resulting in respiratory failure. ARDS is caused by diffuse lung injury due to varied causes like inhalation injury, pneumonia, gastric aspiration, pulmonary contusion, burns, pancreatitis, and sepsis.

An early chest x-ray typically reveals diffuse opacities due to consolidation. Later these opacities progress to more extensive and asymmetrical consolidation. The CT scan of lungs shows heterogeneous involvement and predominantly affects gravity-dependent areas.

The affected airspaces are filled with fluid and cannot contribute to ventilation, leading to hypoxaemia (due to increased pulmonary shunt) and hypercapnia (due to inadequate ventilation in some areas of the lung); resulting in, ventilation–perfusion mismatch.

The hypoxemia in ARDS is refractory to increasing concentration of inhaled oxygen that occurs due to increased intrapulmonary shunting of blood.

The most common cause of death is sepsis in ARDS. Due to improvement in ventilator support systems, respiratory failure causes mortality in less than 20% of cases.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presented with difficulty in urination and back pain. His PSA levels were found to be elevated and the x-ray pelvis revealed two osteoblastic lesions in the bony pelvis. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat the given condition?

PSA - Prostate Specific Antigen
questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigations showing elevated PSA osteoblastic lesions in the pelvis are suggestive of metastatic prostate cancer. Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist used in the treatment of prostate cancer.

Androgen deprivation therapy is the primary medical therapy for prostate cancer. The drugs used for this indication are GnRH agonists such as goserelin, buserelin, leuprolide, nafarelin, and triptorelin. The agonist action of the GnRH analogs causes an initial increase in LH, leading to increased testosterone production. This causes a tumor flare. This can be prevented by concomitant administration of an androgen receptor antagonist such as flutamide or bicalutamide.

After the initial period, there is a downregulation of GnRH receptors and changes in the downstream pathways, leading to a decrease in gonadotropins and testosterone (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism). The androgen deprivation therapy with continuous GnRH agonist and an androgen receptor antagonist is as effective as surgical castration in reducing the levels of serum testosterone.

GnRH antagonists such as degarelix can also be used for androgen deprivation therapy. It has the advantage of not having a tumor flare phenomenon. However, because of the long-term safety profile of GnRH agonists, they are the preferred drugs for androgen deprivation therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of advanced breast cancer.

Option B: Desogestrel is a synthetic progestin without androgenic activity. It is used in combination with ethinyl estradiol for oral contraception.

Option D: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is a weak inhibitor of the androgen receptor and causes gynecomastia as a common side effect. It has been used in women to treat hirsutism.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Schroeders' ring?

choices.text: Common cause is injudicious administration of oxytocics
The ring can be felt per abdomen
It is usually formed around the neck of the fetus

questions.solution:
The ring is not felt per abdomen.

Incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin results in the formation of a constriction ring/ Schroeder's ring.

It is usually situated at the junction of the upper and lower segment of the uterus around the neck of the fetus in cephalic presentation. The ring is not felt per abdomen. The uterus never ruptures.

Common causes are:

  • Injudicious use of oxytocics
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • A premature attempt at instrumental delivery

Management

Delivery is usually done by cesarean section. The ring usually passes off by deepening the plane of anesthesia otherwise the ring may have to be cut vertically to deliver the baby.
